Title: Investor-Owned Electric, Gas, and Gas and Electric Companies - Cost Recovery - Limitations
Synopsis: Prohibiting certain public service companies from recovering through rates any costs associated with paying certain employees a bonus unless the employee has a written contract executed by December 31, 2025, or the employee is covered by a valid collective bargaining agreement; prohibiting a certain public service company from recovering through rates any costs associated with a supervisor's annual compensation once the compensation exceeds a certain amount; etc.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits investor-owned electric and gas utility companies from recovering the costs of employee bonuses and high-level supervisor compensation through utility rates, with certain exceptions for existing contracts and collective bargaining agreements. It also requires these companies to adopt policies that limit expenditures on non-essential activities such as entertainment, office renovations, and staff development.
responsible_party: Maryland Public Service Commission and the boards of directors of investor-owned public service companies
stakeholders: Customers of investor-owned electric and gas companies, utility company employees and supervisors, and investor-owned public service companies.

Title: Subtraction Modification - Public Safety Retirement Income
Synopsis: Increasing, from $15,000 to $20,000, the amount allowed as a subtraction modification under the Maryland income tax for retirement income attributable to an individual's employment as a public safety employee; and applying the Act to all taxable years beginning after December 31, 2025.
bill_summary: This bill increases the Maryland income tax subtraction modification for retirement income received by certain public safety employees from $15,000 to $20,000. The modification applies to retired law enforcement officers, correctional officers, and fire, rescue, or emergency services personnel who are at least 55 years old.
stakeholders: Retired public safety employees including law enforcement officers, correctional officers, and fire, rescue, or emergency services personnel who are at least 55 years of age.

Title: Higher Education - Nonresident Tuition - Exemption for Dependents of State or Local Public Safety Employees (Maryland Fallen Heroes Tuition Benefits Act)
Synopsis: Exempting financially dependent children of State or local public safety employees who die as a result of or in the course of performance of duties from paying out-of-state or out-of-county tuition at a public institution of higher education in the State.
bill_summary: The Maryland Fallen Heroes Tuition Benefits Act exempts the financially dependent children of state or local public safety employees who died in the line of duty from paying out-of-state or out-of-county tuition at Maryland public institutions of higher education, regardless of the child's actual state or county of residence.
stakeholders: Financially dependent children of deceased Maryland public safety employees, including firefighters, ambulance or rescue squad members, law enforcement officers, correctional officers, and members of the Maryland National Guard.

Title: Vehicle Laws – Historic Motor Vehicles – Minimum Age
Synopsis: Requiring that a motor vehicle be at least 25 years old in order to be eligible for registration as a historic motor vehicle; and requiring the Motor Vehicle Administration to reinstate, under certain circumstances, the historic motor vehicle registration of a motor vehicle that had its historic vehicle registration suspended or revoked as a result of the change to the definition of "historic motor vehicle" in Chapter 604 of 2025.
bill_summary: This bill changes the eligibility requirements for registering a vehicle as a historic motor vehicle by defining it as a vehicle that is at least 25 years old, rather than using a specific model year. It also requires the Motor Vehicle Administration to reinstate historic motor vehicle registrations that were suspended or revoked due to definition changes made in 2025 and establishes the registration fee schedule.
stakeholders: Owners of historic motor vehicles and the Motor Vehicle Administration

Title: Community Development - Maryland New Markets Development Program - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Maryland New Markets Development Program; requiring the Department of Housing and Community Development to administer the Program; authorizing a credit against the State insurance premium receipts tax and certain State insurance retaliatory taxes, fees, charges, and penalties for certain equity investments in certain community development entities; authorizing the Department to recapture a credit under certain circumstances; limiting the credit amounts that may be issued to $18,750,000 for any taxable year; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Maryland New Markets Development Program to be administered by the Department of Housing and Community Development. The program provides tax credits against the state insurance premium receipts tax and certain retaliatory taxes for business entities that make qualified equity investments in community development entities, which must then invest those funds into qualified active low-income community businesses located in Maryland.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Insurance companies, Maryland Qualified Community Development Entities, and businesses located in low-income communities in Maryland.

Title: Public Institutions of Higher Education - Pregnant and Parenting Students - Plan and Reporting
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Higher Education Commission to collect certain data regarding the parental status of students from each public institution of higher education in the State; requiring public institutions of higher education to collect and report certain demographic data from students; and requiring all public institutions of higher education to adopt a certain plan for pregnant and parenting students.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Higher Education Commission to collect and report data regarding the parental status of students at public higher education institutions. It also mandates that these institutions adopt and publish plans to provide pregnant and parenting students with access to referral networks for healthcare, government assistance programs, and institutional accommodations.
responsible_party: Maryland Higher Education Commission and public institutions of higher education
stakeholders: Pregnant and parenting students at public institutions of higher education in Maryland

Title: State Board of Examiners for Audiologists, Hearing Aid Dispensers, Speech-Language Pathologists, and Music Therapists - Authority to Issue Limited Licenses to Practice Music Therapy
Synopsis: Authorizing the State Board of Examiners for Audiologists, Hearing Aid Dispensers, Speech-Language Pathologists, and Music Therapists to issue a limited license to practice music therapy; providing the purpose of the limited license is to permit an individual to practice music therapy while completing certain licensing requirements; and allowing a licensee with a limited license to practice music therapy under the supervision of a fully licensed music therapist.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the State Board of Examiners for Audiologists, Hearing Aid Dispensers, Speech–Language Pathologists, and Music Therapists to issue limited licenses to individuals practicing music therapy. A limited license allows an applicant who has met all requirements except the examination to practice under the supervision of a fully licensed music therapist for a one-year term, renewable once. The bill establishes application procedures, fees, and requirements for these limited licenses.
responsible_party: State Board of Examiners for Audiologists, Hearing Aid Dispensers, Speech–Language Pathologists, and Music Therapists
stakeholders: Prospective music therapists, licensed music therapists, and the State Board of Examiners for Audiologists, Hearing Aid Dispensers, Speech–Language Pathologists, and Music Therapists

Title: Vehicle Laws - Dangerous Driver Abatement Program - Establishment (Dangerous Driver Accountability Act)
Synopsis: Establishing the Dangerous Driver Abatement Program; establishing the purpose of the Program is to reduce motor vehicle-related deaths by requiring repeat offenders to complete a driver accountability and safety course or be subject to sanctions; requiring the Motor Vehicle Administration to administer the Program and provide a certain notice to repeat offenders; requiring a repeat offender to successfully complete a certain course within 90 days after receiving the notice; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Dangerous Driver Abatement Program, administered by the Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA). It requires 'repeat offenders'—drivers who accumulate multiple violations via automated systems like speed cameras, red-light cameras, and school bus cameras within a 12-month period—to complete an approved driver accountability and safety course. Failure to complete the course within 90 days results in the suspension of vehicle registration renewals, and non-compliance after 180 days may lead to vehicle impoundment. The bill also provides fee waivers for low-income individuals and a hardship appeal process for essential workers.
stakeholders: Motor vehicle owners with multiple automated traffic violations, low-income drivers, essential workers, and the general public.

Title: 3-1-1 Systems - Expansion Program and Oversight Board - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Maryland 3-1-1 Oversight Board in the Maryland Information Network to oversee the expansion of 3-1-1 systems in Maryland; establishing the 3-1-1 Program to use certain artificial intelligence to answer certain questions and route certain calls in certain counties; and requiring the expansion of the 3-1-1 Program to all of the counties in Maryland after a certain time period.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Maryland 3-1-1 Oversight Board and a 3-1-1 Program to modernize and expand nonemergency community information and referral systems across the state. The program will implement artificial intelligence technologies, including chatbots and voicebots, to answer public inquiries and route calls to appropriate government services. The initiative begins with a pilot phase in four counties and requires full statewide expansion by July 1, 2028.
stakeholders: Maryland residents and local county governments

Title: Legal Advertisement or Legal Notice - Publication in Newspaper or Newspaper in General Circulation - Digital Newspapers
Synopsis: Establishing certain requirements for the print or digital publication of legal advertisements and notices in counties and municipalities in the State; requiring digital publications that publish a legal advertisement or notice to maintain an archive of all published legal advertisements and legal notices that shall be available to the public; and requiring digital publications that publish a legal advertisement or notice to employ at least one employee whose duties include reporting, writing, or editing local news and information.
bill_summary: This bill expands the definition of a newspaper or newspaper in general circulation for the publication of legal advertisements and notices to include digital publications. It establishes specific criteria for digital newspapers to qualify, including requirements for original content production, staffing of local residents, minimum publication frequency, and public archiving of notices.
stakeholders: Digital and print news organizations, Maryland residents, county and municipal governments, and legal parties required to publish public notices

Title: Anne Arundel County - Sheriff - Appointment of Majors
Synopsis: Requiring the Sheriff of Anne Arundel County to appoint three majors at a salary determined by the County Council of Anne Arundel County.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Sheriff of Anne Arundel County to appoint three majors with salaries determined by the County Council of Anne Arundel County.
stakeholders: Anne Arundel County Sheriff's Office and the County Council

Title: Juvenile Sex Offender Registry - Qualifying Offenses and Access
Synopsis: Authorizing a local superintendent or the superintendent's designee to access the registry of juvenile sex offenders; and adding certain offenses to the list of offenses for which a person adjudicated delinquent is required to be included in the registry of juvenile sex offenders.
bill_summary: This bill expands the list of criminal offenses for which a juvenile adjudicated delinquent must be included in the Maryland juvenile sex offender registry. It also authorizes local school superintendents or their designees to access the registry, which was previously limited to law enforcement personnel.
stakeholders: Juveniles adjudicated delinquent for sex-related offenses, law enforcement personnel, and local school superintendents.

Title: Income Tax - Subtraction Modification - Public Safety Employee Retirement Income (Supporting Our 9-1-1 Specialists Act)
Synopsis: Altering a certain subtraction modification under the Maryland income tax for retirement income attributable to an individual's employment as a public safety employee to include certain retirement income attributable to an individual's employment as a 9-1-1 specialist; and applying the Act to all taxable years beginning after December 31, 2025.
bill_summary: This bill expands the Maryland income tax subtraction modification for retirement income received by public safety employees to include 9-1-1 specialists. Eligible individuals who are at least 55 years old can subtract the first $15,000 of retirement income attributable to their service as a 9-1-1 specialist from their federal adjusted gross income when determining Maryland adjusted gross income.
stakeholders: Retired 9-1-1 specialists in Maryland aged 55 and older

Title: County Boards of Education - Bullying, Harassment, or Intimidation - Information Collection and Reporting Requirements
Synopsis: Altering the contents of a certain bullying, harassment, or intimidation form to require, if the incident is believed to have been motivated in whole or in substantial part by an actual or perceived personal characteristic including race, national origin, marital status, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, religion, ancestry, physical attributes, socioeconomic status, familial status, or physical or mental ability or disability, the identification of those personal characteristics, if known; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires county boards of education to update bullying, harassment, or intimidation report forms to include whether an incident was motivated by the victim's actual or perceived personal characteristics. It further mandates that each county board publish an annual summary of these reported incidents on its website by January 31 each year, disaggregated by the motivating personal characteristic, while ensuring individual identities remain confidential.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education and County Boards of Education
stakeholders: Public school students, parents, guardians, and school staff in Maryland

Title: Public Information Act - Public Records - Nonprofit Organizations
Synopsis: Altering the definition of a "public record" under the Public Information Act to include certain documentary material made by a nonprofit organization that receives $50,000 or more annually from State grants, State bond proceeds, or local impact grants; and altering the applicability of certain rules and limitations under the Public Information Act to include certain nonprofit organizations.
bill_summary: This bill expands the scope of the Maryland Public Information Act to include certain nonprofit organizations. Specifically, it defines documentary material produced or received by a nonprofit organization as a public record if the organization receives $50,000 or more annually from State grants, State bond proceeds, or local impact grants. Such organizations will be required to limit the personal information they collect to what is necessary for their governmental purpose and must adopt policies for the proactive disclosure of public records.
responsible_party: Official custodians of records within covered nonprofit organizations and the Public Information Act Compliance Board
stakeholders: Nonprofit organizations receiving at least $50,000 in annual State or local funding, employees of those organizations, and members of the public requesting access to records

Title: Correctional Services - Maryland Parole Commission - Members and Hearing Examiners
Synopsis: Altering the number of members of the Maryland Parole Commission from 10 to at least 15 but not more than 20 members; altering the appointing authority and method of appointment of parole commissioners; and repealing the authority of the Commission to appoint and utilize hearing examiners.
bill_summary: This bill increases the size of the Maryland Parole Commission from 10 members to between 15 and 20 members and establishes a nomination panel to recommend candidates to the Governor for appointment. It also eliminates the use of hearing examiners, requiring that parole hearings be conducted by Commission members, and provides for the reallocation of salary funds from hearing examiners to commissioners.
stakeholders: Incarcerated individuals, victims of crimes, and members of the Maryland Parole Commission

Title: Estates and Trusts - Venue for Administrative and Judicial Probate and Application of Inheritance Tax
Synopsis: Altering certain criteria for determining the venue for administrative or judicial probate of decedents who were not domiciled in the State; providing that, for purposes of the application of the Maryland inheritance tax, the situs of intangible personal property is the domicile of the decedent; repealing a certain exemption from the Maryland inheritance tax for personal property that passes from a nonresident decedent; etc.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the legal requirements for determining the venue of probate for individuals who were not domiciled in Maryland at the time of their death. It also clarifies that for Maryland inheritance tax purposes, the location (situs) of intangible personal property is the decedent's place of domicile and repeals an inheritance tax exemption for certain personal property belonging to nonresident decedents.
responsible_party: Maryland Comptroller and the Registers of Wills
stakeholders: Nonresident decedents with property or interests in Maryland, beneficiaries of estates, and personal representatives.

Title: Transportation Network Companies - Transportation Network Operators - Minimum Payments for Passenger Trips
Synopsis: Requiring a transportation network company to pay operators, after July 1, 2026, and for any passenger trip originating in the State,  $1.66 per mile and $0.40 per minute, an additional $1.18 per mile for an operator using a wheelchair accessible vehicle, at least $5.00 for any passenger trip, and at least 80% of any cancellation fee charged by a transportation network company; and adjusting the minimum amount paid per mile and per minute by inflation each year.
bill_summary: This bill requires transportation network companies to provide minimum compensation to operators for passenger trips originating in Maryland. Starting July 1, 2026, companies must pay at least $1.66 per mile and $0.40 per minute, with a minimum trip payment of $5.00, and must also provide additional compensation for wheelchair-accessible vehicles and at least 80% of any cancellation fees. The bill also mandates annual inflation adjustments to these minimum rates based on the Consumer Price Index.
stakeholders: Transportation network companies, transportation network operators (drivers), and passengers in Maryland.

Title: Higher Education - Maryland Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Maryland Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program to assist in the repayment of higher education loans owed by State employees in order to attract, recruit, and retain these employees; requiring the Office of Student Financial Assistance within the Maryland Higher Education Commission to administer the Program; and requiring the Office to report to the General Assembly on or before January 1 of each year on the implementation of the Program and any effects the Program has on State employee recruitment or retention.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Maryland Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program to provide higher education loan repayment assistance to State employees. To qualify, an employee must have graduated from a Maryland college or university and completed at least 10 years of service with the State. The program aims to improve recruitment and retention of State workers by providing awards up to 100% of their remaining loan debt, subject to the availability of funding.
responsible_party: Office of Student Financial Assistance within the Maryland Higher Education Commission
stakeholders: Maryland State employees in the executive, legislative, and judicial branches who graduated from Maryland institutions of higher education and have at least 10 years of state service.

Title: Baltimore City - Alcoholic Beverages - Related Event Promoter's Permit
Synopsis: Reestablishing a related event promoter's permit in Baltimore City; authorizing the Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore City to issue a related event promoter's permit to certain applicants under certain circumstances; and requiring a holder of a State caterer's license to obtain a certain Class C per diem license from the Board before the holder may act as a participating license holder at a related event.
bill_summary: This bill reestablishes the Related Event Promoter’s Permit in Baltimore City for social events related to the CIAA Basketball Tournament involving 75 or more participants. It requires promoters and participating license holders to obtain specific permits from the Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore City, mandates that state caterers obtain local per diem licenses, establishes application and permit fees based on venue capacity, and outlines penalties for non-compliance.
responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore City
stakeholders: Event promoters, Baltimore City alcoholic beverages license holders, State caterer's license holders, and organizers of events related to the CIAA Basketball Tournament.

Title: Social Media Platforms - Vloggers and Video Content Featuring Minors (Child Influencers Protection Act)
Synopsis: Requiring a vlogger who creates video content that is posted on a social media platform and features a certain child to compensate the child under certain circumstances; establishing requirements on social media platforms relating to deleting video content featuring minor children; and applying certain requirements relating to the labor of minors to children compensated by vloggers.
bill_summary: The Child Influencers Protection Act requires vloggers to compensate children who are featured in their social media content if certain viewership or revenue thresholds are met. Compensation must be placed into a trust for the child until they reach the age of 18. The bill also allows individuals who were featured in such content as children to request the permanent deletion of that content once they reach adulthood and ensures that Maryland child labor laws apply to these minors.
stakeholders: Child influencers, vloggers, parents and guardians of child influencers, and social media platforms

Title: Correctional Services - Incarcerated Individuals - Identification Cards and Driver's Licenses
Synopsis: Requiring a certain correctional facility to return a certain identification card or driver's license to a certain incarcerated individual at or before the time of the individual's release from confinement under certain circumstances; requiring the Commissioner of Corrections and the managing official of a local correctional facility to provide certain forms and work with a certain incarcerated individual to ensure a certain identification card or driver's license is available at the time of release from confinement; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires State and local correctional facilities to return a valid photo identification card or driver's license to an incarcerated individual upon their release. It also mandates that, for individuals serving a sentence of one year or more, the Commissioner of Correction or the local facility's managing official must begin working with the individual six months prior to their anticipated release to ensure they have a valid Motor Vehicle Administration-issued identification card or driver's license at the time of release.
responsible_party: Commissioner of Correction and the managing official of each local correctional facility
stakeholders: Incarcerated individuals in State and local correctional facilities

Title: Motor Vehicle Administration - Identification Cards - Issuance to Minors
Synopsis: Prohibiting the Motor Vehicle Administration from requiring a parent or legal guardian of a minor at least 15 years of age to cosign or be present at the time of submission of the minor's application for an identification card; and requiring the Administration to adopt regulations establishing acceptable forms of documentation  establishing proof of residency that a minor at least 15 years of age may use in an application for an identification card.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits the Motor Vehicle Administration from requiring a parent or legal guardian to be present or cosign for a minor at least 15 years old who is applying for an identification card. It also requires the Administration to adopt regulations for acceptable proof of residency for these minors, including school records, documentation from homeless services providers, and court documents.
stakeholders: Maryland residents at least 15 years of age who are applying for a state identification card

Title: County Boards of Education - Volunteer Aides - School Chaplain
Synopsis: Authorizing each county board of education to use a chaplain as a volunteer aide in schools to provide support services to students.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes Maryland county boards of education to use chaplains as volunteer aides in public schools to provide support services to students. The bill clarifies that these chaplains must assist regular employees rather than replace educational personnel and provides them with liability insurance and workers' compensation coverage as agents of the county board.
responsible_party: Maryland county boards of education and county superintendents
stakeholders: Students in Maryland public schools, chaplains interested in volunteering, and local county boards of education.

Title: Family Law - Grandparent Visitation
Synopsis: Altering the circumstances under which an equity court is authorized to grant visitation rights to a grandparent of a child to include that the petition for visitation rights was filed after an action for divorce, annulment, custody, or paternity was filed by a parent of the child; and requiring an equity court to grant certain visitation rights if the child resided with the grandparent for at least 12 months, or the child's parent, who is the child of the grandparent, is deceased, and the court finds it in the best interests of the child.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the criteria and procedures for Maryland equity courts to grant visitation rights to grandparents. It establishes specific scenarios where a court may or must grant visitation, such as when a parent is deceased, the child has lived with the grandparent for at least 12 months, or during divorce and custody proceedings, provided the visitation is in the child's best interest and does not harm the parent-child relationship.
stakeholders: Grandparents, parents, and children involved in custody or visitation proceedings.

Title: Public Schools - Open Enrollment - Policies and Funding
Synopsis: Authorizing a county board of education to adopt an open enrollment policy to authorize certain students to attend, free of charge, a public school in a county other than the county where the student is domiciled with the student's parent or guardian, subject to certain requirements; requiring county boards to include certain students in full-time equivalent enrollment counts; and directing certain funding to the county in which certain students are enrolled in a public school under an open enrollment policy.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes Maryland county boards of education to adopt open enrollment policies, which allow students to attend public schools in a county other than the one in which they reside. It establishes requirements for these policies, including application processes, enrollment preferences for zoned students and siblings, and public reporting of school capacity. The bill also defines a funding mechanism where the sending county transfers per-pupil funds to the receiving county, and the State provides supplemental funding if the sending county's per-pupil expenditure is lower than the receiving county's.
stakeholders: Maryland public school students, parents and guardians, and local school systems.

Title: Maryland Technology Development Corporation - Long COVID Innovation Grant and Loan Program
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Technology Development Corporation to establish a grant and loan program to provide grants and loans for Long COVID innovation; requiring the Corporation to contract with an independent review committee composed of scientific experts in the field of Long COVID; establishing the Maryland Long COVID Research Fund under the administration of the Corporation as a special, nonlapsing fund; and requiring that the interest earnings of the Fund be credited to the Fund.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Technology Development Corporation (TEDCO) to establish the Long COVID Innovation Grant and Loan Program and the Maryland Long COVID Research Fund. The program provides grants and loans to public and private entities in Maryland for research, product development, and manufacturing related to Long COVID treatments, with applications reviewed by an independent committee of scientific experts.
stakeholders: Public and private entities in Maryland involved in medical research and manufacturing, and Maryland residents affected by Long COVID.

Title: Higher Education - Private Career Schools - Advertising
Synopsis: Authorizing the Secretary of Higher Education to allow certain private career schools to advertise certain information and collect contact information from potential new students before receiving a certificate of approval from the Maryland Higher Education Commission to operate a private career school in the State under certain circumstances; requiring an approved private career school to advertise only information relating to the opening of the private career school and include a certain disclosure; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland Secretary of Higher Education to allow private career schools to advertise and collect contact information from potential students before receiving a formal certificate of approval to operate. These schools must disclose that their approval is pending and are prohibited from collecting any fees or entering into enrollment agreements until they are fully certified.
stakeholders: Private career schools and potential students

Title: County Boards of Education - Post College and Career Readiness Pathways - Payment of Costs
Synopsis: Authorizing a county board of education to develop and establish income eligibility guidelines and procedures for payment of costs for a certain post college and career readiness (post-CCR) pathway, except that a county board must provide access to the post-CCR pathway at no cost to the student or student's parents or guardians if the student's family income is below 400% of the federal poverty level.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes Maryland county boards of education to establish income eligibility guidelines for the payment of costs associated with competitive entry college preparatory programs, such as International Baccalaureate or Advanced Placement courses. However, the bill mandates that students whose family income is below 400% of the federal poverty level must be provided access to these programs at no cost to the student or their parents or guardians.
stakeholders: Public school students meeting college and career readiness standards, parents and guardians, and county boards of education.

Title: Public Safety - Department of State Police - Police-Initiated Towing - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering provisions related to the rates the Department of State Police sets for towing companies involved in police-initiated towing of motor vehicles to include the towing and recovery of light-duty vehicles; and defining "light-duty towing" as towing and recovery of a vehicle including trailers or semitrailers with a gross vehicle weight rating of 10,000 pounds or less.
bill_summary: This bill alters the regulations regarding police-initiated towing services overseen by the Maryland Department of State Police. It expands the Department's rate-setting authority to include light-duty towing (vehicles 10,000 pounds or less) and modifies the definition of police-initiated towing to encompass all motor vehicles rather than just commercial ones. It also stipulates that approved rates for light-duty towing may not exceed a certain percentage of the rates for medium-duty towing.
stakeholders: Towing and recovery companies, motor vehicle owners and operators, and Maryland State Police personnel

Title: Police Discipline - Order to Show Cause
Synopsis: Authorizing a police officer who is denied a certain right to apply to the circuit court at any time before a hearing is held by the hearing board for an order that directs the law enforcement agency to show cause why the right should not be granted.
bill_summary: This bill allows a police officer who is denied a right during disciplinary proceedings to apply to the circuit court for an order requiring the law enforcement agency to explain why the right should not be granted. It specifies the appropriate jurisdiction for such applications based on whether the law enforcement agency is local, statewide, or bicounty.
responsible_party: Maryland Circuit Courts and Maryland Law Enforcement Agencies
stakeholders: Maryland police officers and law enforcement agencies

Title: Local Law Enforcement Vehicles - Requirements - Automated External Defibrillators
Synopsis: Requiring all local law enforcement vehicles to carry an automated external defibrillator (AED); and requiring a local law enforcement agency to maintain the functionality of an AED carried by a local law enforcement vehicle.
bill_summary: This bill requires all local law enforcement vehicles in Maryland to be equipped with an automated external defibrillator (AED) and mandates that the local law enforcement agencies maintain the functionality of these devices.
stakeholders: Local law enforcement agencies, law enforcement officers, and the general public in need of emergency cardiac intervention

Title: Income Tax - Itemized Deductions - Charitable Donations
Synopsis: Excluding certain charitable contributions from a limitation on the amount of itemized deductions allowed for certain individuals under the Maryland income tax; and applying the Act to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2025.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the calculation of itemized deductions for Maryland income tax purposes by excluding charitable contributions from the 7.5% reduction that applies to taxpayers with federal adjusted gross incomes exceeding $100,000 for married individuals filing separately or $200,000 for other filers. Effectively, it allows high-income taxpayers to maintain the full value of their charitable contribution deductions.
stakeholders: Maryland taxpayers who itemize deductions and have federal adjusted gross income exceeding $100,000 for married individuals filing separately or $200,000 for all other filers

Title: Municipalities - Open Drainage Inlets - Required Grating Systems (Mason's Law)
Synopsis: Requiring a municipality to construct or install an approved grating system which places a cover over the opening of an open drainage inlet in order to allow stormwater runoff to enter the drainage inlet while preventing large debris from entering the drainage inlet; requiring the approved grating system be installed on a new or existing open drainage inlet within the municipality; etc.
bill_summary: Known as Mason's Law, this bill requires Maryland municipalities to install approved grating systems on all new and existing open drainage inlets with a diameter of 12 inches or more. These systems must allow for stormwater runoff while preventing large debris from entering and must be securely fastened to prevent removal without tools or displacement by flood waters.
stakeholders: Maryland municipalities and the general public

Title: Local Government - Regulatory Powers - Regulation of Tree of Heaven
Synopsis: Authorizing the governing body of a county or municipality to adopt certain ordinances to regulate trees of heaven; and authorizing the governing body of a county or municipality to establish a bounty program to incentivize the removal of trees of heaven.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes Maryland counties and municipalities to regulate or prohibit the sale, planting, and growth of the 'Tree of Heaven,' an invasive plant species. It also permits local governments to establish bounty programs to incentivize the removal of these trees and to enforce regulations through civil fines and mitigation requirements.
responsible_party: Governing bodies of Maryland counties and municipalities
stakeholders: Maryland property owners, local governments, and the agricultural community

Title: Annotated Code - Terminology - Clergy and Churches, Faith Institutions, and Places of Worship
Synopsis: Altering certain terminology throughout the Annotated Code that refers to a clergyman to refer to a member of the clergy and churches to refer to faith institutions and places of worship; and defining "faith institution" as any Christian, Jewish, Islamic, Buddhist, or Hindu congregation, or any other religious society, congregation, or denomination.
bill_summary: This bill updates terminology throughout the Annotated Code of Maryland to replace the term 'clergyman' with 'member of the clergy' and 'church' with 'faith institution' or 'place of worship' to ensure the language is more inclusive of various religious traditions.
stakeholders: Clergy members, faith institutions, religious organizations, and places of worship in Maryland.

Title: General Assembly - Employment and Leave Protection for Members
Synopsis: Prohibiting an employer from depriving of employment or taking certain other actions against an employee who is a member of the General Assembly and who loses employment time to performing responsibilities as a member of the General Assembly; and establishing a penalty of a fine not exceeding $1,000 for a violation of the Act.
bill_summary: This bill establishes employment and leave protections for members of the Maryland General Assembly. It prohibits employers from firing, threatening, or coercing an employee because they lose time from work to perform legislative duties, and it prevents employers from requiring members to use annual, sick, or vacation leave for these responsibilities. Additionally, it restricts employers from requiring shifts immediately following or preceding legislative duties and subjects violators to a fine of up to $1,000.
stakeholders: Members of the Maryland General Assembly and Maryland employers

Title: Financial Institutions - Licensing of Affiliated Insurance Producer-Mortgage Loan Originators - Alteration
Synopsis: Requiring the Commissioner of Financial Regulation to approve a certain mortgage lender that meets certain criteria as an affiliated insurance producer-mortgage loan originator if the mortgage lender is in good standing with the Commissioner and any other regulator to which it is subject and is in material compliance with applicable state and federal law.
bill_summary: House Bill 38 expands the definition of an affiliated insurance producer-mortgage loan originator to include individuals who originate mortgage loans for a single mortgage lender that is not a financial institution. The bill requires the Commissioner of Financial Regulation to approve such mortgage lenders based on their good standing and legal compliance. It also outlines licensing application processes, supervision requirements, and surety bond obligations for these originators.
stakeholders: Licensed insurance producers, mortgage lenders, and mortgage loan originators

Title: Net Energy Metering - Portable Solar Electric Generating Facilities
Synopsis: Authorizing the use of a certain portable solar electric generating facility by an eligible customer-generator for the purpose of net energy metering.
bill_summary: This bill expands Maryland's net energy metering program by authorizing the use of portable solar electric generating facilities. It defines portable solar as a moveable photovoltaic facility with a capacity of no more than 120 kilowatts that is designed to be plugged into a standard 120-volt outlet. The bill allows customers using these portable systems to be considered eligible customer-generators, enabling them to offset their electricity bills and receive credit for excess energy generated.
stakeholders: Maryland electricity customers, portable solar energy equipment owners, and electric utility companies

Title: Public Utilities - Transmission Lines - Advanced Transmission Technologies
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "qualified generator lead line" for provisions of law regarding certificates of public convenience and necessity; requiring an applicant for a certificate of public convenience and necessity for the construction of an overhead transmission line to include certain information in its application; requiring the Public Service Commission to consider certain evidence before taking action on a certain application for a certificate of public convenience and necessity; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires applicants for overhead transmission line construction to evaluate and provide evidence for the use of advanced transmission technologies and other alternatives during the certification process. It also mandates that transmission line owners or operators submit quadrennial reports to the Public Service Commission regarding grid congestion and the feasibility of implementing technologies like grid-enhancing hardware or high-performance conductors to improve efficiency.
stakeholders: Electric companies, owners and operators of overhead transmission lines, and Maryland electricity ratepayers.

Title: Baltimore County Board of Education - Alterations of Elected Member Districts and Establishment of Redistricting Process
Synopsis: Requiring certain members of the Baltimore County Board of Education to be elected from certain districts in certain elections; and requiring the chair of the Baltimore County delegation to the General Assembly to introduce legislation to reapportion certain school board districts in a certain manner after each decennial census of the United States.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the composition and election process of the Baltimore County Board of Education by transitioning from councilmanic districts to specific school board districts for electing certain members, starting with the 2034 general election. It establishes a mandatory redistricting process where the chair of the Baltimore County delegation to the General Assembly must introduce legislation to reapportion school board districts after each decennial U.S. Census to ensure they remain equal in population.
responsible_party: Chair of the Baltimore County delegation to the General Assembly
stakeholders: Voters and residents of Baltimore County, and candidates for the Baltimore County Board of Education

Title: Health Occupations - State Board of Massage Therapy Examiners - Revisions
Synopsis: Authorizing an individual registered by the State Board of Massage Therapy Examiners to practice massage therapy in the State to continue to practice massage therapy beyond October 31, 2026; altering the requirements an individual must meet to qualify for a massage therapy license; repealing obsolete qualifications for registered massage practitioners; repealing the requirement that the imposition of a certain administrative penalty be subject to certain hearing requirements; etc.
bill_summary: This bill revises the regulations for massage therapy in Maryland by allowing registered massage practitioners to continue practicing beyond October 2026. It updates licensing requirements to a minimum of 750 contact hours, provides pathways for out-of-state applicants to supplement their training, and simplifies the process for the State Board of Massage Therapy Examiners to impose administrative penalties for failure to report address changes. Additionally, the bill clarifies the procedures and requirements for reinstating or reactivating expired or inactive licenses and registrations, including mandatory criminal history records checks.
responsible_party: State Board of Massage Therapy Examiners
stakeholders: Licensed massage therapists, registered massage practitioners, out-of-state massage therapy applicants, and the State Board of Massage Therapy Examiners

Title: Procurement - Advertising - Local News Organizations (Local Newspapers for Maryland Communities Act of 2026)
Synopsis: Requiring units of State government to ensure that at least 50% of the unit's total dollar value of procurement contracts for print and digital advertising is being made directly to local news organizations.
bill_summary: The Local Newspapers for Maryland Communities Act of 2026 requires Maryland state government units to award at least 50% of the total dollar value of their procurement contracts for print and digital advertising directly to local news organizations. The bill defines local news organizations based on content type, employment within Maryland, and ownership disclosure requirements, while exempting advertising for tourism promotion and employee recruitment conducted outside the state.
stakeholders: Local news organizations, Maryland State government agencies, and Maryland residents

Title: Election Law - Petitions and Ballot Questions - Contents, Plain Language Requirement, and Procedures
Synopsis: Altering the information that is required to be included on the signature page of a petition seeking to place a question on the ballot and with a question on the ballot; requiring that a certain summary included on the signature page of a petition seeking to place a question on the ballot and a certain statement about a question on the ballot be written in plain language; requiring certain boards of elections to post the text of ballot measures for at least 90 days before the general election; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires that summaries on petition signature pages and ballot questions be written in plain, clear language that is easily understood by voters, prohibiting the use of legal jargon, passive voice, and double negatives. It establishes a 15-day public comment period for proposed ballot question language, sets earlier deadlines for the certification of ballot questions, and mandates that the State Board and local boards of elections post detailed information about ballot questions online at least 90 days before a general election.
stakeholders: Maryland voters, petition sponsors, and local boards of elections

Title: Labor and Employment - Mandatory Meetings on Religious or Political Matters - Employee Attendance and Participation (Maryland Worker Freedom Act)
Synopsis: Prohibiting employers and their agents, representatives, and designees from taking certain actions against an employee or applicant for employment because the employee or applicant takes certain actions regarding employer-sponsored meetings during which the employer communicates the opinion of the employer regarding religious matters or political matters; authorizing an employee to file a certain complaint with the Commissioner of Labor and Industry; etc.
bill_summary: The Maryland Worker Freedom Act prohibits employers from discharging, disciplining, or penalizing employees or job applicants who refuse to attend or participate in employer-sponsored meetings intended to communicate the employer's opinions on religious or political matters. The bill establishes a process for employees to file complaints with the Commissioner of Labor and Industry, who is authorized to investigate violations, assess civil penalties up to $25,000, and award relief such as reinstatement and back pay. It also requires employers to post notices and provide information to new hires regarding these protections.
stakeholders: Maryland employees, job applicants, and employers

Title: Sports Wagering - Gambling Prevention Technology Pilot Program - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Gambling Prevention Technology Pilot Program in the State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission; requiring Bowie State University and Morgan State University to participate in the Pilot Program; requiring the Commission, in collaboration with certain entities, to designate certain no gambling zones on each campus, develop certain informational signage, and identify and implement certain technologies; and requiring the Commission to submit a report on the Pilot Program on or before January 1, 2031.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Gambling Prevention Technology Pilot Program within the State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission. Bowie State University and Morgan State University are required to participate in the program, which uses geofencing technology to create 'no gambling zones' on their campuses. Within these zones, online sports wagering platforms must be blocked, and individuals attempting to gamble must be provided with information about the pilot program and resources for responsible gambling.
responsible_party: State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission
stakeholders: Students at Bowie State University and Morgan State University, and online sports wagering operators

Title: Commission on State and Local Government Real Property Bearing Confederate Names - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Commission on State and Local Government Real Property Bearing Confederate Names to develop and implement a framework to identify real property owned by the State or a political subdivision that bears a Confederate name; and requiring the Commission to make recommendations regarding the real property that should be renamed and report its findings to the Governor, the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City, the governing body of each county, and the General Assembly by October 1, 2033.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Commission on State and Local Government Real Property Bearing Confederate Names as an independent unit of the executive branch. The commission is tasked with developing a framework to identify state and locally owned real property, such as streets, buildings, and parks, that bear names commemorating the Confederacy and making recommendations for renaming them. The commission is required to report its findings to the Governor and General Assembly by October 1, 2033, and is scheduled to disband in 2034.
responsible_party: Commission on State and Local Government Real Property Bearing Confederate Names
stakeholders: Maryland state and local government entities, residents of Maryland political subdivisions, and the Maryland State Archives

Title: Family Law - Children in Need of Assistance and Termination of Parental Rights (Right to Fight Act)
Synopsis: Repealing a provision that authorizes a local department of social services to ask the juvenile court to find that reasonable efforts to reunify a child with the child's parent or guardian are not required if the local department concludes that a parent or guardian has involuntarily lost parental rights to a sibling of the child; and repealing the authorization for a juvenile court to waive a local department's obligation to provide certain services if a parent has involuntarily lost certain parental rights.
bill_summary: Known as the Right to Fight Act, this bill repeals provisions that allow a local department of social services to bypass reunification efforts between a child and their parent or guardian solely because the parent has previously involuntarily lost parental rights to a sibling. It also removes the juvenile court's authority to waive a local department's obligation to provide services based on that specific prior loss of parental rights.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Human Services and the Maryland Judiciary
stakeholders: Parents or guardians involved in child welfare cases who have previously lost parental rights to a sibling, children in need of assistance, and local departments of social services.

Title: Public Health - Abortion (Heartbeat Bill)
Synopsis: Requiring that an abortion be performed by a physician, rather than a qualified provider; repealing certain provisions of law related to State interference with an abortion, regulations related to abortion, and liability or criminal punishment for qualified providers who perform an abortion; prohibiting a physician from knowingly performing, inducing, or attempting to perform or induce an abortion under certain circumstances and subject to certain exceptions; etc.
bill_summary: Known as the 'Heartbeat Bill,' this legislation prohibits physicians from performing abortions if a fetal heartbeat is detected, except during medical emergencies. It mandates specific informed consent requirements, including performing a sonogram and providing the woman with the opportunity to hear the fetal heartbeat and view images. Notably, the bill shifts enforcement from state authorities to private citizens, who may bring civil actions against individuals performing or aiding in prohibited abortions for statutory damages of at least $10,000.
stakeholders: Pregnant women, physicians, healthcare facilities, and individuals involved in the provision or funding of abortion services

Title: General Assembly - Special Election to Fill a Vacancy in Office
Synopsis: Proposing a Constitutional Amendment requiring that a special election be held at the same time as the regular statewide primary and general elections that are held in the second year of a term to fill a vacancy in the office of Delegate or Senator in the General Assembly if the vacancy occurs on or before the date that is 55 days before the deadline for filing certificates of candidacy for the regular statewide election that is held in the second year of the term.
bill_summary: This bill proposes a constitutional amendment to require a special election to fill a vacancy in the office of Delegate or Senator in the General Assembly if the vacancy occurs early enough in the term. Specifically, if a vacancy occurs on or before 55 days before the filing deadline for the statewide election in the second year of a term, a special primary and general election must be held concurrently with those regular midterm elections to fill the remainder of the term.
stakeholders: Maryland voters, political candidates, and members of the Maryland General Assembly

Title: Strategic Digital Asset Reserve Act of Maryland
Synopsis: Establishing the Maryland Digital Asset Reserve Fund to serve as a reserve asset for the State through the investment of cryptocurrency; and authorizing the State Treasurer to invest the funds obtained by the State through the enforcement of certain gambling violations into cryptocurrency.
bill_summary: The Strategic Digital Asset Reserve Act of Maryland establishes the Maryland Digital Asset Reserve Fund as a special, nonlapsing fund managed by the State Treasurer. The fund's purpose is to serve as a state reserve asset by investing in decentralized cryptocurrencies with a market capitalization of at least $500 billion. The fund will be composed of money seized and forfeited from gambling law violations, state budget appropriations, and interest earnings.
stakeholders: Maryland State government, law enforcement agencies, and the citizens of Maryland

Title: Election Law - Incarcerated Individuals - Voter Hotline and Voting Eligibility (Voting Rights for All Act)
Synopsis: Requiring the State Board of Elections to provide a toll-free voter hotline for incarcerated individuals to receive information about voting, request election-related materials, and report voting rights violations; and altering the circumstances under which an individual is not qualified to be a registered voter for the purpose of allowing individuals convicted of a felony and serving a court-ordered sentence of imprisonment for the conviction to register to vote.
bill_summary: This bill restores the right to vote for individuals convicted of a felony who are currently serving a court-ordered sentence of imprisonment. It also requires the State Board of Elections to establish and maintain a toll-free voter hotline specifically for incarcerated individuals to request election materials, receive information, and report voting rights violations.
stakeholders: Incarcerated individuals serving sentences for felony convictions

Title: Criminal Law – Nondomesticated Animal Prohibitions – Alterations
Synopsis: Altering an exception to the prohibition against the possession of certain nondomesticated animals in the State by reducing from 10 days to 48 hours the amount of time a nonresident may travel through the State with an otherwise prohibited animal; repealing the exception to the prohibition against the possession by a person with certain disabilities of certain nondomesticated animals for a certain purpose; etc.
bill_summary: This bill expands the list of prohibited nondomesticated animals in Maryland to include kangaroos, wallaroos, wallabies, and zebras. It also shortens the time non-residents can transport such animals through the state from 10 days to 48 hours and removes a previous exception for individuals with disabilities using these animals for assistance. Existing owners of the newly listed species are permitted to keep their animals provided they register them with local animal control by December 1, 2026.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources and local animal control authorities
stakeholders: Exotic animal owners, animal sanctuaries, circuses, veterinarians, and people with disabilities

Title: Task Force to Study Restructuring Maryland's Electric Utility Industry
Synopsis: Establishing the Task Force to Study Restructuring Maryland's Electric Utility Industry to study and make recommendations on restructuring the State's electric utility industry; and requiring the Task Force to report its findings and recommendations to the General Assembly on or before November 1, 2027.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Task Force to Study Restructuring Maryland’s Electric Utility Industry. The task force is responsible for studying alternative utility models, such as publicly owned utilities and cooperatives, evaluating strategies to reduce electricity rates, and assessing the legal and financial implications of transitioning from private to public ownership of electric assets. The task force must report its findings and recommendations to the General Assembly by November 1, 2027.
stakeholders: Maryland electric utility ratepayers, private and public electric utility companies, and the Maryland General Assembly

Title: Vehicle Laws - Speed Monitoring Systems - Residential Districts
Synopsis: Applying statewide certain provisions of law authorizing the use of speed monitoring systems in certain residential districts.
bill_summary: This bill expands the authority to use speed monitoring systems (speed cameras) in residential districts statewide. It removes the previous geographic restrictions that limited such usage to Anne Arundel, Montgomery, and Prince George's counties, allowing any local jurisdiction in Maryland to implement these systems on highways in residential districts with a maximum speed limit of 35 miles per hour.
responsible_party: Local jurisdictions (governing bodies of Maryland counties and municipalities)
stakeholders: Maryland motorists and residents living in residential districts statewide

Title: Districting - Single-Member Districts and Legislative and Congressional Redistricting and Apportionment Convention
Synopsis: Requiring that each legislative district established for the purpose of electing members of the House of Delegates consist of three single-member delegate districts; requiring the General Assembly to enact a law establishing and governing a Legislative and Congressional Redistricting and Apportionment Convention to establish legislative and congressional districts and establishing certain requirements regarding the Redistricting Convention; establishing the Redistricting Convention; etc.
bill_summary: This bill proposes a constitutional amendment and changes to state law to require that all House of Delegates districts be divided into three single-member districts. It also establishes an independent 188-member Legislative and Congressional Redistricting and Apportionment Convention responsible for redrawing legislative and congressional district boundaries after each decennial census, a task previously handled by the Governor and General Assembly.
responsible_party: Legislative and Congressional Redistricting and Apportionment Convention
stakeholders: Maryland voters, candidates for the Maryland General Assembly and U.S. Congress, and residents of Maryland counties

Title: Public Schools - Maryland Civic Excellence Program - Established
Synopsis: Establishing the Maryland Civic Excellence Program in the State Department of Education; authorizing a local school system to participate in the Program to recognize students who meet criteria related to student proficiency in civics and civic literacy; and requiring the Department, no later than the 2027-2028 school year, to develop guidelines to assist participating local school systems.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Maryland Civic Excellence Program within the State Department of Education to recognize public school students who demonstrate proficiency in civics and civic literacy. Participating local school systems will use state-developed guidelines to award a 'Seal of Civic Excellence' to students, which may be signified by a cord, medal, or insignia on their high school diploma.
stakeholders: Public school students and local school systems in Maryland

Title: Transportation - Paratransit Services - Interjurisdictional Routes
Synopsis: Requiring a county that submits an application to the Secretary of Transportation for funding for certain transportation services for elderly and disabled persons to identify interjurisdictional paratransit service routes between facilities within certain networks of providers in the application; requiring the Secretary to adopt procedures to ensure counties cooperate in establishing interjurisdictional paratransit service routes between facilities within certain networks of providers; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires Maryland counties to establish and identify interjurisdictional paratransit routes connecting to major regional healthcare networks as a condition for receiving state funding for elderly and handicapped transportation services. It mandates that the Secretary of Transportation develop procedures to ensure cooperation between counties to provide these transit services across jurisdictional boundaries.
stakeholders: Elderly and handicapped residents, Maryland county governments, and major regional healthcare networks including Adventist Healthcare, Johns Hopkins Medicine, LifeBridge Health, Luminis Health Maryland, MedStar Health, and University of Maryland Medical System

Title: Real Property - Expedited Wrongful Detainer Proceedings - Property for Sale or Lease
Synopsis: Requiring certain expedited proceedings in a wrongful detainer action if the property that is the subject of the action is, at the time of the complaint, advertised or listed for sale or lease by the complainant and requiring that notice of a hearing or appeal be served in person or, under certain circumstances, posted conspicuously on the property; requiring the District Court or the circuit court to issue a warrant within 24 hours if the court rules in favor of the complainant in an expedited wrongful detainer action; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes expedited legal procedures for wrongful detainer actions when the subject property is currently listed or advertised for sale or lease. It shortens the timeframes for court hearings, requires judicial rulings within two business days after a hearing, sets a strict two-day window for appeals, and mandates the issuance of a possession warrant within 24 hours of a ruling in favor of the complainant.
responsible_party: District Court of Maryland, Maryland Circuit Courts, and County Sheriffs
stakeholders: Property owners listing real estate for sale or lease and individuals in possession of such property without legal right

Title: Sickle Cell Disease - Institutions of Higher Education - Policies, Procedures, and Educational Campaigns
Synopsis: Prohibiting an institution of higher education from denying access or services to a student based on the student's diagnosis of sickle cell disease; requiring an institution of higher education to provide reasonable accommodations for students with sickle cell disease; requiring the Maryland Department of Health to develop an education and awareness campaign for institutions of higher education in the State regarding students with sickle cell disease; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires Maryland institutions of higher education to provide reasonable accommodations to students with sickle cell disease and prohibits discrimination against them based on their diagnosis. It mandates the Maryland Department of Health to develop an education and awareness campaign, a framework for assessing and supporting students, and educational materials for faculty and staff. Additionally, the Department, in consultation with the Maryland Higher Education Commission and other stakeholders, must provide technical assistance and monitor the implementation of these procedures beginning in late 2026.
stakeholders: Students with sickle cell disease attending institutions of higher education in Maryland, as well as faculty, health personnel, and administrative staff at these institutions

Title: Financial Institutions – Definition of Student Financing Companies – Alteration
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "student financing company" to exclude an institution of postsecondary education for purposes of certain registration and reporting requirements.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the definition of student financing company under Maryland's financial institution laws to exclude institutions of postsecondary education. This change exempts these educational institutions from specific registration and reporting requirements that apply to other entities providing student financing.
stakeholders: Institutions of postsecondary education, student financing companies, and students in Maryland

Title: Anne Arundel County - Summons for Actions to Repossess for Failure to Pay Rent - Alterations
Synopsis: Requiring the District Court for Anne Arundel County to issue its summons for a trial to repossess for failure to pay rent to any constable or sheriff's designee; providing that a sheriff's designee in Anne Arundel County has the same authority and responsibility as a constable or sheriff in an action to repossess for a failure to pay rent; requiring a sheriff's designee to post a notice of a trial at a certain property or address; etc.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the legal process for property repossession due to nonpayment of rent in Anne Arundel County. It authorizes the District Court to issue summons to a sheriff's designee, extends the time for a trial to be held to 30 days after a complaint is filed, requires a notice period of at least seven days before the trial, and caps the number of such cases scheduled per day at 100.
responsible_party: District Court for Anne Arundel County and the Anne Arundel County Sheriff's Office
stakeholders: Landlords and tenants in Anne Arundel County

Title: Education - Interscholastic and Intramural Junior Varsity and Varsity Teams and Locker Rooms - Designation Based on Sex (Fairness in Girls' Sports Act)
Synopsis: Requiring certain interscholastic and intramural junior varsity and varsity athletic teams or sports sponsored by certain schools and certain locker rooms to be expressly designated based on biological sex; prohibiting certain entities from taking certain adverse actions against a school for maintaining separate interscholastic and intramural junior varsity and varsity athletic teams or sports or locker rooms for students of the female sex; etc.
bill_summary: The Fairness in Girls’ Sports Act requires Maryland public high schools and certain nonpublic high schools to designate interscholastic and intramural athletic teams and locker rooms based on biological sex. It specifically prohibits biological male students from participating on teams or using locker rooms designated for females, protects schools from adverse actions by athletic or governmental entities for following these rules, and creates a right for students and schools to bring civil actions for violations or retaliation.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education and Maryland public and nonpublic high schools
stakeholders: Public and nonpublic high school student athletes, public and nonpublic school administrations, and athletic associations or organizations.

Title: Task Force on Education Funding and Student Population Growth
Synopsis: Establishing the Task Force on Education Funding and Student Population Growth to analyze the challenges related to the delay in student enrollment counts and its effect on school funding and the connection between growing student populations and the provision of school funding; and requiring the Task Force to report its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly on or before December 15, 2026.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Task Force on Education Funding and Student Population Growth to analyze challenges related to the timing of student enrollment counts and the impact of growing student populations on education funding, with a requirement to report findings and recommendations by December 15, 2026.
stakeholders: Maryland students, public school systems, local boards of education, and state education administrators

Title: Estates and Trusts - Fiduciaries - Attorney-Client Privilege
Synopsis: Clarifying that a communication between an attorney and a client that acts as a fiduciary is subject to the attorney-client privilege even if fiduciary funds are used to compensate the attorney for services rendered to the client.
bill_summary: This bill clarifies that communications between an attorney and a client acting as a fiduciary are protected by attorney-client privilege, even if the attorney's fees are paid using fiduciary funds. It also establishes that the existence of a fiduciary relationship between a fiduciary and a beneficiary does not waive this privilege.
stakeholders: Fiduciaries, agents, beneficiaries, and legal professionals

Title: Environment - Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative - Withdrawal (Restoring Energy Freedom Act)
Synopsis: Requiring the Governor to withdraw the State from participation in the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Governor to withdraw Maryland from the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI). It repeals statutory requirements for participation in the initiative, eliminates the deposit of carbon allowance auction proceeds into the Maryland Strategic Energy Investment Fund, and removes various regulatory and program references to RGGI within state environmental and energy laws.
stakeholders: Maryland residents, energy producers, manufacturers, and state environmental agencies

Title: State Government - State House Trust - Ten Commandments Monument Display Act
Synopsis: Requiring a certain Ten Commandments Monument to be placed on the grounds of the Maryland State House; requiring the Commission on Artistic Property to oversee the care and maintenance of the monument; and establishing the Commission on the Ten Commandments Monument.
bill_summary: This bill requires a monument of the Ten Commandments to be placed on the grounds of the Maryland State House. It establishes the Commission on the Ten Commandments Monument to manage the design, construction, and site selection for the monument, specifying that the work must be done by a private entity at no cost to the State. The Commission on Artistic Property is tasked with the long-term care and maintenance of the monument once installed.
responsible_party: Commission on the Ten Commandments Monument and the Commission on Artistic Property
stakeholders: The citizens of Maryland and visitors to the Maryland State House

Title: Motor Vehicles - Special Registration Plates - Old Line Plates (Old Line Plate Program Act of 2026)
Synopsis: Requiring the Motor Vehicle Administration to develop and make available an Old Line Plate with a certain numeric-only registration number for certain motor vehicles.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Old Line Plate Program Act of 2026, requiring the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration to create and issue special numeric-only registration plates styled after Maryland's 1911 license plates. The bill creates a public auction process for individuals to acquire 'registration number rights' for these plates and establishes rules for their transfer, fees, and the reversion of rights back to the state.
stakeholders: Owners of passenger vehicles, small trucks, and multipurpose vehicles in Maryland interested in specialized historical registration plates.

Title: Labor and Employment - Exemptions From Overtime Pay - Administrative, Executive, or Professional Capacity
Synopsis: Altering the exemption from overtime pay for individuals who are employed to work in an administrative, executive, or professional capacity.
bill_summary: This bill alters the criteria for overtime pay exemptions for employees working in administrative, executive, or professional capacities. It establishes a series of increasing minimum weekly salary thresholds starting July 1, 2027, and continuing through July 1, 2031, while also codifying specific primary duty requirements regarding management, business operations, and specialized intellectual or creative work.
responsible_party: Maryland Commissioner of Labor and Industry
stakeholders: Maryland employers and employees working in administrative, executive, or professional capacities.

Title: State Highway Administration - Traffic Calming Devices - Study
Synopsis: Requiring the State Highway Administration to study and make recommendations on the implementation of a consistent statewide policy for the use of traffic calming devices on highways in the State; and requiring the Administration to report its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly on or before December 1, 2026.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland State Highway Administration to conduct a study and develop recommendations for a consistent statewide policy regarding the use of traffic calming devices on state highways. The study must research best practices, provide guidelines for implementation, identify ways to support local governments, and list potential partner entities, with a report due to the Governor and General Assembly by December 1, 2026.
stakeholders: Maryland residents, motorists, pedestrians, and county and municipal governments

Title: Maryland Medical Assistance Program - Psychiatric Rehabilitation Program Services - Reimbursement (Youth Psychiatric Rehabilitation Parity Act of 2026)
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Department of Health to adopt regulations requiring the Maryland Medical Assistance Program to reimburse a psychiatric rehabilitation program for a minimum of 6 and a maximum of 30 psychiatric rehabilitation community psychiatric support services delivered to certain individuals each month.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Health to adopt regulations for the Maryland Medical Assistance Program to reimburse psychiatric rehabilitation programs for a minimum of 6 and a maximum of 30 community psychiatric support services per month provided to individuals with serious emotional disturbances or persistent mental disorders who live with a caregiver.
stakeholders: Individuals with serious emotional disturbances or persistent mental disorders who live with a legal guardian, and psychiatric rehabilitation program providers.

Title: Natural Resources - Edible Forests and Foraging Program - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing an Edible Forests and Foraging Program within the Department of Natural Resources; requiring individuals who forage in designated foraging areas to obtain a foraging permit; requiring the Department to charge a permit application fee and establish a fee waiver process for individuals who demonstrate financial need; requiring the Department to establish and maintain edible forests on State land, subject to available funding; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Edible Forests and Foraging Program within the Department of Natural Resources to manage foraging on State-owned land. It requires foragers to obtain permits for designated areas, provides permit fee waivers for those in financial need, and authorizes the establishment of edible forests where the public can forage for personal use without a permit. The initiative is supported by the newly created Edible Forests and Foraging Fund.
stakeholders: Maryland residents, foragers, and individuals demonstrating financial need

Title: Public Schools - Water Safety and Swimming Course - Established
Synopsis: Requiring the State Board of Education to develop, by July 1, 2027, curriculum content for an elective course in water safety and swimming for public school students in kindergarten through grade 8; requiring, beginning in the 2027-2028 school year, county boards of education to implement the water safety and swimming curriculum content for students in kindergarten through grade 8 in public schools in the county; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland State Board of Education to develop curriculum content standards for a water safety and swimming course for public school students in kindergarten through grade 8 by July 1, 2027. Beginning in the 2027-2028 school year, each county board of education must implement this course, ensure accommodations for students with disabilities, and may partner with local parks and recreation agencies for facility access.
