responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Education and County Boards of Education
stakeholders: Maryland public school students in kindergarten through grade 8 and students with disabilities

Title: State Procurement - Construction and Services - Contract Modification
Synopsis: Requiring a procurement contract for 3 years or more in duration and valued at greater than $2,000,000 for construction or security services to include a clause requiring contract modification for increased costs for compensation and benefits as a result of statutory changes increasing required compensation or benefits; and requiring a certain contract that is modified to be contingent on approval by the Chief Procurement Officer.
bill_summary: This bill requires that State procurement contracts for construction or security services that last at least 3 years and are valued at more than $2 million must include a clause for contract modification. This clause allows for equitable adjustments to the contract price to account for increased costs in employee compensation and benefits resulting from statutory changes or, in the case of security services, collective bargaining. Any such modification is contingent upon the approval of the Chief Procurement Officer.
stakeholders: State procurement contractors in the construction and security service industries, and Maryland state agencies involved in high-value, long-term contracting.

Title: Video Lottery Operations - Prohibitions on Campaign Contributions - Parity Act
Synopsis: Repealing the prohibition on applicants for and holders of video lottery operation licenses and persons who own an interest in video lottery facility operations in the State from directly or indirectly making contributions to certain campaign finance entities.
bill_summary: This bill repeals the legal prohibition that prevented applicants for or holders of video lottery operation licenses and individuals with an interest in video lottery facilities from making campaign contributions to candidates for nonfederal public office in Maryland.
stakeholders: Applicants for and holders of video lottery operation licenses, owners of video lottery facilities, and candidates for nonfederal public office in Maryland

Title: Local School Systems - School Safety - Grant Allocations
Synopsis: Authorizing the reallocation of certain school safety grants to local school systems that have fully expended their grant allocation and demonstrate unmet need within the same fiscal year.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the reallocation of school safety grant funds to Maryland local school systems that have already spent their initial funding and can demonstrate additional unmet financial needs within the same fiscal year. These grants, which total $10 million annually statewide, are intended to assist school systems and law enforcement agencies in providing school resource officers or adequate law enforcement coverage for public schools.
stakeholders: Maryland public school students and staff, local school systems, and local law enforcement agencies

Title: Consumer Protection - Sale and Resale of Event Tickets - Registration and Regulation
Synopsis: Requiring certain ticket resellers to register annually with the Division of Consumer Protection of the Office of the Attorney General to resell an event ticket in the State; regulating the sale and resale of event tickets in the State; establishing that a violation of the Act is an unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practice subject to enforcement and penalty provisions under the Maryland Consumer Protection Act; etc.
bill_summary: The Ticket Resale Consumer Protection and Transparency Act establishes a regulatory framework for the event ticket resale market in Maryland. It requires resellers who sell 50 or more tickets annually to register with the Division of Consumer Protection of the Office of the Attorney General and mandates periodic reporting from both resellers and secondary ticket exchanges. The bill imposes price caps on resold tickets (initial price plus 10%) and limits service fees charged by secondary exchanges. Additionally, it prohibits the sale of speculative tickets, requires clear price and seat disclosure, mandates refunds for counterfeit or canceled events, and requires ticket platforms to implement technology to prevent the use of automated bots for ticket purchases.
responsible_party: Division of Consumer Protection of the Office of the Attorney General
stakeholders: Ticket purchasers (consumers), ticket resellers, secondary ticket exchanges, and ticket issuers including venue operators, performers, and sports teams.

Title: Property Taxes - Authority of Counties to Establish Subclasses and Set Separate Rates for Land and Improvements to Land
Synopsis: Authorizing the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county to establish subclasses of real property consisting of land and improvements to land and set separate real property tax rates for each subclass.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City and the governing bodies of Maryland counties to establish separate subclasses of real property for land and for improvements to land. It permits these jurisdictions to set different property tax rates for each subclass, provided that the tax rates remain uniform throughout the jurisdiction for all property within a specific subclass.
responsible_party: Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county
stakeholders: Property owners in Maryland counties and Baltimore City

Title: Climate Solutions Affordability Act of 2026
Synopsis: Specifying that certain requirements under the Climate Solutions Now Act of 2022 are to be carried out to the extent economically practicable, including requirements concerning achieving certain direct greenhouse gas emissions reductions from certain buildings, measuring and reporting direct emissions data to the Department of the Environment, achieving certain greenhouse gas emissions reduction goals, and achieving zero-emission vehicle goals relating to the State vehicle fleet and local school buses; etc.
bill_summary: The Climate Solutions Affordability Act of 2026 modifies the implementation of the Climate Solutions Now Act. It adds a requirement that various environmental mandates—including building energy performance standards, statewide greenhouse gas reduction goals, the transition to zero-emission school buses and state vehicle fleets, and the adoption of the International Green Construction Code—be carried out only to the extent that they are economically practicable.
stakeholders: Building owners, county boards of education, state agencies, utility contractors, and Maryland residents

Title: Landlord and Tenant - Residential Leases - Fee Disclosures
Synopsis: Requiring a landlord to provide certain information to prospective tenants about fees imposed on tenants and prohibiting a landlord from imposing a mandatory fee that was not disclosed; applying the Act to a lease signed or renewed on or after October 1, 2026, and a landlord that offers four or more dwelling units for rent; and authorizing a tenant to file a claim against a landlord for a violation of the Act on or after February 1, 2027, and during the tenancy or up to 2 years after the tenancy expired.
bill_summary: This bill requires landlords who offer four or more dwelling units for rent to provide prospective tenants with a written itemized list of all mandatory and optional fees, including the amount, basis, and frequency of the fees. It prohibits landlords from imposing mandatory fees that were not disclosed and establishes a legal pathway for tenants to seek treble damages and attorney's fees for violations.
stakeholders: Residential tenants and landlords who offer four or more dwelling units in Maryland

Title: Motor Vehicles - Police Stops - Secondary Enforcement and Excludable Evidence
Synopsis: Requiring a police officer to document all reasons for a traffic stop or other stop on a citation or police report resulting from the stop; establishing that certain evidence obtained from a traffic stop or other stop in violation of certain provisions of law may be excluded as evidence in certain proceedings; authorizing a police officer to enforce certain provisions of the Maryland Vehicle Law only as a secondary action; and applying certain provisions of the Act retroactively.
bill_summary: This legislation requires police officers to document every reason for a traffic stop on any resulting citation or report and permits the exclusion of evidence in court if certain stop requirements are violated. Additionally, it reclassifies numerous motor vehicle infractions—including window tinting, unpaid registration, and certain equipment defects—as secondary offenses, prohibiting officers from initiating a stop solely for these violations unless another offense is suspected.
stakeholders: Maryland motor vehicle drivers, law enforcement officers, and individuals with pending traffic-related legal cases.

Title: Recordation and Transfer Taxes - Exemption for Related Business Entities - Common Law Trusts
Synopsis: Altering an exemption from the recordation tax and State and county transfer tax for transfers between related business entities to include transfers involving common law trusts; and applying the Act to instruments of writing recorded on or after July 1, 2026.
bill_summary: This bill expands the definition of a business entity to include common law trusts within the context of recordation and transfer tax exemptions. This change allows transfers of real property between related business entities involving common law trusts to be exempt from these taxes, provided they meet specific criteria such as no consideration or nominal consideration.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Assessments and Taxation and Clerks of the Circuit Court
stakeholders: Business entities, common law trusts, and owners of real property in Maryland

Title: Family and Law Enforcement Protection Act
Synopsis: Altering and establishing provisions relating to the surrender of firearms by a respondent under the domestic violence statutes; and requiring a local law enforcement authority to take certain actions within 3 business days after service of an order against a respondent who is not in compliance with an order to surrender certain firearms.
bill_summary: The Family and Law Enforcement Protection Act modifies domestic violence statutes to require respondents of temporary or final protective orders to surrender all firearms and handgun licenses to law enforcement within 24 hours of being served. The bill mandates that petitioners provide known information regarding the respondent's firearms and requires law enforcement to verify compliance within three business days, notifying the State’s Attorney's Office of any violations. It also requires that petitioners be provided with safety planning resources and contact information for the Maryland Network Against Domestic Violence.
responsible_party: Local law enforcement authorities, the State’s Attorney’s Office, and the Maryland Judiciary
stakeholders: Domestic violence victims (petitioners), respondents of protective orders, law enforcement agencies, and domestic violence support organizations

Title: Criminal Procedure - Sentencing - Domestic Violence as a Mitigating Factor (Providing Alternatives Through Healing for Justice-Involved Individuals (PATH) Act)
Synopsis: Authorizing the introduction of evidence that a certain defendant was the victim of domestic violence and that the domestic violence was a significant contributing factor to the commission of a certain crime  as a mitigating factor at sentencing of the defendant or a hearing on a motion for modification or reduction of a sentence; and establishing related procedures.
bill_summary: The Providing Alternatives Through Healing for Justice–Involved Individuals (PATH) Act authorizes defendants to present evidence that they were victims of domestic violence and that such violence was a significant factor in the commission of certain crimes. If established at sentencing or a sentence modification hearing, the court must treat this as a mitigating factor and may depart from mandatory minimum sentences or sentencing guidelines to impose a sentence it deems just and appropriate.
stakeholders: criminal defendants who are victims of domestic violence, the state court system, and legal professionals

Title: Corporations and Associations - Cooperative Limited Equity Housing Corporations - Establishment
Synopsis: Authorizing a Maryland nonstock corporation to convert to a cooperative limited equity housing corporation subject to certain requirements; requiring a cooperative limited equity housing corporation to provide a certain notice and offer to certain households under certain circumstances; requiring a cooperative limited equity housing corporation to reimburse certain households for moving expenses; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes Maryland nonstock corporations to convert into cooperative limited equity housing corporations (CLEHCs), a new legal entity designed to provide affordable housing. It establishes the legal procedures for conversion, including voting requirements, mandatory notice to current residents, and limits on the resale appreciation of cooperative interests to ensure long-term affordability. The bill also authorizes the Department of Housing and Community Development to establish a grant program to promote these corporations and prohibits local governments from restricting their formation.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Low-income and moderate-income households, senior citizens, disabled persons, and Maryland nonstock corporations involved in residential housing.

Title: State and Local Employees - Cancer Screening - Paid Leave
Synopsis: Providing that certain State, county, and municipal employees are entitled to up to 4 hours of paid cancer screening in any 12-month period after obtaining approval from their appointing authorities.
bill_summary: This bill entitles State, county, and municipal employees in Maryland to use up to 4 hours of paid leave during any 12-month period for cancer screening. Employees must obtain approval from their appointing authority to use this leave, and the governing bodies of local jurisdictions and the Secretary of State Personnel and Pensions are required to adopt procedures for its implementation.
responsible_party: The Secretary of State Personnel and Pensions and the governing bodies of Maryland counties and municipalities
stakeholders: State, county, and municipal employees in Maryland, including temporary and part-time staff

Title: Income Tax - Energy Efficient Home Improvement Credit
Synopsis: Allowing a credit against the State income tax for certain costs paid or incurred by an individual for certain energy efficient home improvements made to the individual's residence during the taxable year, subject to certain limitations; and applying the Act to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2025.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a State income tax credit for individuals who make energy-efficient improvements to their primary residences. The credit covers up to 30% of the costs for improvements such as home energy audits, windows, doors, heat pumps, and biomass boilers, with a total annual aggregate limit of $3,200 per taxpayer.
stakeholders: Maryland individual taxpayers and residents making energy-efficient home improvements

Title: Health Insurance – Bulk Purchasing Pools for Prescription Drugs
Synopsis: Authorizing certain insurers, nonprofit health service plans, and health maintenance organizations to join bulk purchasing pools for prescription drugs.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes health insurers, nonprofit health service plans, and health maintenance organizations in Maryland to join bulk purchasing pools for prescription drugs, including those that provide coverage through pharmacy benefits managers.
stakeholders: Health insurers, nonprofit health service plans, health maintenance organizations (HMOs), and pharmacy benefits managers.

Title: Baltimore County - Inspector General - Authority Over Baltimore County Public Schools
Synopsis: Authorizing the County Council of Baltimore County, beginning in 2027, to enact a local law granting the Baltimore County Office of the Inspector General the same authority over Baltimore County Public Schools that the Inspector General has over a department of county government.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Baltimore County Council to enact local legislation that grants the Baltimore County Office of the Inspector General investigative and oversight authority over Baltimore County Public Schools, matching the authority the office currently holds over county government departments.
responsible_party: Baltimore County Council and the Baltimore County Office of the Inspector General
stakeholders: Baltimore County Public Schools, the Baltimore County Office of the Inspector General, and the Baltimore County Council

Title: Property Taxes - Authority of Counties to Establish a Subclass and Set a Special Rate for Commercial and Industrial Property
Synopsis: Authorizing the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county to establish, by law, a subclass of real property consisting of certain commercial and industrial property and to set a special property tax rate for certain commercial and industrial property for the purpose of financing certain transportation improvements or the approved budget of the county board of education; applying the Act to all taxable years beginning after June 30, 2026; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes Baltimore City and Maryland counties to create a specific property tax subclass for commercial and industrial real property. Local governments may set a special property tax rate for these properties, capped at 12.5 cents per $100 of assessed value, specifically to fund transportation improvements or the approved budget of the local board of education. The bill requires that the residential portions of mixed-use buildings be exempt from this special rate and allows counties to provide additional tax credits for businesses with 15 or fewer employees.
responsible_party: Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county
stakeholders: Commercial and industrial property owners, small business owners with 15 or fewer employees, owners of mixed-use properties, county boards of education, and the general public benefiting from transportation improvements.

Title: Agriculture - Neonicotinoid Pesticides - Prohibitions
Synopsis: Prohibiting a person from distributing, selling, or using corn, soybean, or wheat seeds that have been coated in or treated with neonicotinoid pesticides; prohibiting an individual from applying neonicotinoid pesticides to treat outdoor ornamental plants and turf; and authorizing the Secretary of Agriculture to temporarily suspend the prohibitions under the Act based on certain determinations made by the Secretary in consultation with the Department of the Environment and the Department of Natural Resources.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits the distribution, sale, or use of corn, soybean, or wheat seeds coated with neonicotinoid pesticides and restricts the use of neonicotinoid pesticides on outdoor ornamental plants and turf. It provides exceptions for certain agricultural uses and invasive species treatment and grants the Secretary of Agriculture the authority to temporarily suspend these prohibitions during seed shortages, financial hardships, or environmental emergencies.
stakeholders: Agricultural producers, seed distributors, certified pesticide applicators, and owners of outdoor ornamental plants and turf.

Title: Environment - Beverage Containers Connected With Plastic Rings - Restriction on Sale
Synopsis: Prohibiting a person from selling, offering for sale, or distributing for sale beverage containers that are connected to other beverage containers with a plastic ring connector unless the plastic ring connector is made of a biodegradable material.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits the sale, offer for sale, or distribution of beverage containers connected by plastic ring connectors unless the connectors are made of biodegradable material. It requires the Maryland Department of the Environment to adopt regulations for enforcement and sets civil penalties for violations.
stakeholders: Beverage manufacturers, distributors, retailers, and consumers in Maryland

Title: Home Builders - Model Homes and Contracts for the Intent to Purchase a New Home - Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring certain home builders that construct model homes to make certain information about the model home available to prospective home buyers in a certain manner; requiring a home builder to provide certain information about model home upgrades to a home buyer at the time of signing a certain contract; providing that a home buyer has a right to rescind a contract for the intent to purchase a new home for any reason within a certain period of time; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires home builders to provide prospective buyers with detailed documentation and signage regarding model home upgrades, including descriptions, costs, and square footage comparisons. It also grants buyers a 5-day right to rescind a contract for the intent to purchase a new home for any reason, ensuring a full refund of deposits minus a potential consultation fee of up to $250, and establishes administrative penalties for builders who fail to comply.
responsible_party: Consumer Protection Division of the Office of the Attorney General
stakeholders: Prospective home buyers and home builders in Maryland

Title: Public Safety - Handgun Permits - Expiration and Renewal Periods for Retired Law Enforcement Officer
Synopsis: Establishing alternative expiration and renewal periods for a handgun permit issued to a retired law enforcement officer who retired in good standing from service with a law enforcement agency of the State or a county or municipal corporation of the State; and providing that a handgun permit issued to a law enforcement officer who retired in good standing expires on the last day of the holder's birth month following 5 years after the date the permit is issued and may be renewed for successive periods of 5 years under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill establishes longer expiration and renewal periods for handgun permits issued to retired law enforcement officers who retired in good standing from Maryland state, county, or municipal agencies. Specifically, it extends the initial permit expiration to five years and sets subsequent renewal periods at five-year intervals.
stakeholders: Retired law enforcement officers from Maryland state, county, or municipal agencies

Title: Family Law - Marriage License Applications - Appearance in Court
Synopsis: Requiring both parties to be married, rather than one party, to appear before the clerk of a circuit court to apply for a marriage license.
bill_summary: This bill requires both parties intending to marry to appear in person before the clerk of a circuit court to apply for a marriage license, replacing the previous requirement that only one party appear. It maintains an exception allowing a single-party affidavit if neither applicant resides in the county where the marriage will occur.
stakeholders: Couples applying for a marriage license in Maryland

Title: Baltimore County School Board Nominating Commission - Membership - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the membership of the Baltimore County School Board Nominating Commission, from 19 to 21 members, to include one representative of the Greater Baltimore County Chamber of Commerce, one representative from the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees Local 3, Council 434, and one representative of the Citizens Advisory Council for Gifted and Talented Education.
bill_summary: This bill increases the size of the Baltimore County School Board Nominating Commission from 19 to 21 members. It adds new representatives from the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees Local 3, Council 434, and the Citizens Advisory Council for Gifted and Talented Education, while updating the name of the chamber of commerce representative's organization.
responsible_party: Baltimore County School Board Nominating Commission
stakeholders: Baltimore County residents, Baltimore County Public Schools students and staff, and educational advocacy organizations.

Title: State Designations - State Shark - Megalodon
Synopsis: Designating the megalodon (Otodus megalodon) as the State shark.
bill_summary: This bill designates the megalodon (Otodus megalodon) as the official State shark of Maryland, recognizing its significance to the state's rich fossil history and scientific heritage, particularly in Calvert County and other regions where fossilized teeth have been discovered.
stakeholders: Residents of Maryland, paleontologists, researchers, and scientific institutions such as the Calvert Marine Museum.

Title: Inheritance Tax - Beneficiaries of Limited Means - Installment Payments
Synopsis: Requiring a register of wills to allow an installment payment plan for the inheritance tax to be paid by a certain beneficiary of limited means under certain circumstances and subject to certain limitations; and applying the Act to all decedents dying on or after July 1, 2026.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Register of Wills to allow beneficiaries of limited means to pay inheritance tax on inherited primary residences or agricultural land through installment plans if a lump-sum payment would necessitate selling the property. Beneficiaries must meet specific income thresholds—under $125,000 for individuals or $250,000 for joint filers—to qualify for the installment options.
stakeholders: Beneficiaries of estates with limited income who inherit a primary residence or agricultural land that they maintain.

Title: Municipalities - Annexed Land - Land Use and Density
Synopsis: Altering the restrictions on a municipality, for a period following an annexation of land, to authorize the development of certain annexed land for certain land uses or certain densities without obtaining the express approval of the county in which the municipality is located; and altering the authority of a municipality to authorize certain land uses or certain densities for certain annexed land with the express approval of the county in which the municipality is located.
bill_summary: This bill updates the rules for land use and density on property recently annexed by a municipality. For five years after annexation, a municipality is prohibited from changing land use or increasing density significantly beyond what was suggested in the county or municipal comprehensive plan at the time of annexation, unless they obtain express approval from the county.
stakeholders: Maryland local governments, real estate developers, and residents of annexed areas

Title: Higher Education - Edward T. and Mary A. Conroy Memorial Scholarship Program - Eligibility
Synopsis: Expanding the eligibility for the Edward T. and Mary A. Conroy Memorial Scholarship Program to an applicant who is or was eligible for the Chapter 35 Survivors' Dependents' Educational Assistance benefit as determined by the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs; and authorizing certain methods for verifying eligibility of these individuals for the Edward T. and Mary A. Conroy Memorial Scholarship Program.
bill_summary: This bill expands the eligibility for the Edward T. and Mary A. Conroy Memorial Scholarship Program to include individuals who are eligible for the federal Chapter 35 Survivors' and Dependents' Educational Assistance benefit and establishes verification procedures for Maryland postsecondary institutions to confirm this eligibility.
stakeholders: Maryland residents who are survivors or dependents of veterans eligible for Chapter 35 benefits and Maryland postsecondary institutions.

Title: Public Broadcasters - Debate for Candidates for Statewide Office - Required Participants
Synopsis: Requiring a public broadcaster that holds a debate between candidates for statewide office to invite all candidates who are certified to the ballot in the general election subject to certain requirements; prohibiting a public broadcaster from using or receiving State funds for the remainder of the fiscal year under certain circumstances; requiring the Governor to approve an amended appropriation to reappropriate State funds from a public broadcaster under certain circumstances; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires any public broadcaster that receives State funding and hosts a debate for statewide office candidates to invite all candidates certified to the ballot for the general election. It prohibits broadcasters from excluding candidates based on polling metrics, fundraising, or party affiliation. If a broadcaster violates these requirements, they are prohibited from receiving or using State funds for the remainder of the fiscal year, and those funds must be reappropriated to other programs.
stakeholders: Public broadcasters, candidates for statewide office, and Maryland voters

Title: Education - Dependent Children of Active Service Members - Advance Enrollment Procedures
Synopsis: Requiring a county superintendent of schools to allow a certain dependent child of an active service member to advance enroll in a school in the county in a certain manner; requiring the remote registration process to provide an opportunity for the service member or other parent or guardian of a dependent child with a disability to note whether the child has an individualized education program or a 504 plan in the sending state; and requiring the Secretary of Veterans and Military Families to publish information on advance enrollment.
bill_summary: This bill requires Maryland county school superintendents to allow dependent children of active-duty military members who are relocating to the state to enroll in school in advance through a remote registration process. It mandates that school systems provide continuity of services for students with disabilities who have Individualized Education Programs (IEPs) or 504 plans and requires the Secretary of Veterans and Military Families to publish and maintain information regarding these enrollment procedures.
responsible_party: The Secretary of Veterans and Military Families and Maryland county superintendents and boards of education
stakeholders: Dependent children of active-duty military service members relocating to Maryland and their families, including students with disabilities

Title: Consumer Protection - Consumer Contracts - Prohibited Waiver
Synopsis: Repealing certain exemptions relating to a prohibition on a consumer contract that sets a shorter time to bring an action under or on the consumer contract under certain circumstances; prohibiting a consumer contract from waiving, limiting, impairing, or disclaiming any right conferred or created or a manner of enforcement established by federal or State law; establishing that a violation of the Act is an unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practice subject to enforcement and certain civil penalties; etc.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits consumer contracts from including provisions that waive, limit, or disclaim rights or enforcement methods established by federal or Maryland law. It specifically repeals certain exemptions for businesses and utilities, making it illegal to shorten the time allowed to file a lawsuit in a consumer contract. Violations are categorized as unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practices, allowing for legal action, injunctions, and civil penalties.
stakeholders: Maryland consumers and businesses involved in contracts for personal, family, or household goods and services

Title: Unhoused Individuals - Rights and Affirmative Defense
Synopsis: Providing that all unhoused individuals have certain rights; establishing an affirmative defense of necessity to certain criminal charges relating to trespass or disturbing the peace; and repealing the authority of a municipality to prohibit vagrancy.
bill_summary: This bill establishes specific rights for unhoused individuals in Maryland, including the right to engage in life-sustaining activities like sleeping, sitting, or eating in public spaces. It prohibits government entities from imposing civil or criminal penalties on individuals for exercising these rights or for providing aid such as food and water to unhoused persons. Additionally, the bill creates an affirmative defense of necessity for unhoused individuals prosecuted for criminal trespass or disturbing the peace if they were engaging in life-sustaining activities and had not been offered adequate alternative shelter. It also repeals the authority of municipalities to prohibit vagrancy.
responsible_party: State and local government entities, including law enforcement and human services agencies
stakeholders: Unhoused individuals, state and local government officials, law enforcement agencies, and individuals providing charitable aid to the homeless

Title: Public Health - Restaurants - Disclosure of Main Food Allergens
Synopsis: Requiring restaurants to make available to each customer a written disclosure of each main food allergen, if any, that is an ingredient in each menu item; and excluding a violation of the Act from certain criminal penalties.
bill_summary: This bill requires restaurants in Maryland to provide customers with written disclosures identifying any main food allergens included as ingredients in menu items. Restaurants may provide this information through menus, separate handouts, or electronic formats. While violations are excluded from certain criminal penalties, they remain subject to civil penalties.
stakeholders: Maryland restaurants and restaurant customers with food allergies

Title: State Personnel - Collective Bargaining - Nontenure Track Faculty
Synopsis: Providing collective bargaining rights to nontenure track faculty at State system institutions, Morgan State University, or St. Mary's College of Maryland; defining "nontenure track faculty" as full-time, part-time, or adjunct nontenure track employees whose assignments involve academic responsibilities, including teachers, researchers, and department heads and those in comparable positions; and establishing a separate collective bargaining unit for nontenure track faculty.
bill_summary: This bill grants collective bargaining rights to nontenure track faculty, including full-time, part-time, and adjunct employees, at certain State institutions of higher education such as the University System of Maryland, Morgan State University, and St. Mary’s College of Maryland. It further requires the establishment of a separate collective bargaining unit specifically for these faculty members.
stakeholders: Nontenure track faculty (full-time, part-time, and adjunct) at the University System of Maryland, Morgan State University, and St. Mary’s College of Maryland

Title: Motor Vehicles - Intelligent Speed Assistance System Pilot Program - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Intelligent Speed Assistance System Pilot Program; requiring individuals whose driver's licenses are subject to certain suspension or revocation to participate in the Program; requiring the Motor Vehicle Administration to issue to participants a restricted license requiring the use of an intelligent speed assistance system; and prohibiting a participant from operating a motor vehicle in violation of the requirements of the Program.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Intelligent Speed Assistance System Pilot Program in Maryland. It requires drivers whose licenses are subject to suspension or revocation due to specific point accumulations to participate in the program for one year. Participants must use a motor vehicle equipped with an intelligent speed assistance system and are issued a restrictive driver's license by the Motor Vehicle Administration. The program is funded through participant fees, with waivers available for indigent individuals.
stakeholders: Drivers with license suspensions or revocations due to specific speeding-related point accumulations, intelligent speed assistance system manufacturers, and certified service providers.

Title: Division of Correction - Release Preparation Program
Synopsis: Establishing the Release Preparation Program in the Division of Correction for the purpose of providing access to formerly incarcerated individuals to State correctional facilities to assist incarcerated individuals with release preparation; and altering the purposes of the Cannabis Regulation and Enforcement Fund to include providing funds to cover the costs of supporting the Release Preparation Program.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Release Preparation Program within the Division of Correction to allow formerly incarcerated individuals access to State correctional facilities to assist current inmates with their release preparation. The program is funded by the Cannabis Regulation and Enforcement Fund and requires the Division of Correction to establish a registration protocol for participants, which must be approved by the Office of the Attorney General.
stakeholders: Incarcerated individuals and formerly incarcerated individuals

Title: Institutions of Higher Education and Elementary and Secondary Schools - Title VI Coordinators
Synopsis: Requiring the governing board of each institution of higher education in the State and local school systems to designate a Title VI Coordinator to ensure compliance with Title VI of the federal Civil Rights Act of 1964; and authorizing a person alleging discrimination under certain provisions of law to file a complaint with a Title VI Coordinator of a local school system, as applicable.
bill_summary: This bill requires every Maryland institution of higher education and every local school system to designate a Title VI Coordinator to ensure compliance with the federal Civil Rights Act of 1964. The coordinators are tasked with investigating discrimination complaints, providing training and resources on anti-discrimination laws, and promoting equal access to educational programs and activities regardless of race, color, or national origin.
responsible_party: Governing boards of Maryland institutions of higher education and Maryland local school systems
stakeholders: Students, parents, and staff of Maryland higher education institutions and local school systems

Title: Motor Vehicles - School Buses - Seat Belts
Synopsis: Requiring the public school safety education program to include student instruction concerning school bus safety and the proper use of seat belts on school buses; requiring that school buses purchased after July 1, 2030, and registered in the State be equipped with, for every seat on the school bus, 3-point seat belts that are accessible to passengers; and prohibiting a civil action for damages based on the failure of a school bus operator to ensure that an occupant of a school bus was wearing a seat belt.
bill_summary: This bill requires public school safety education programs to include instruction on school bus safety and the proper use of seat belts. It mandates that all school buses purchased on or after July 1, 2030, and registered in Maryland must be equipped with 3-point seat belts for every seat. The bill also establishes that school bus operators, schools, and school districts cannot be held criminally or civilly liable for damages if a passenger fails to wear a seat belt.
responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Education and the Motor Vehicle Administration
stakeholders: Public school students, school bus operators, school districts, and municipalities

Title: Family Law - Child Abuse - Definitions
Synopsis: Expanding the definitions of "abuse" and "sexual abuse" for purposes of provisions relating to the reporting and investigation of child abuse and neglect.
bill_summary: This bill expands the definitions of 'abuse' and 'sexual abuse' related to the reporting and investigation of child abuse and neglect. It removes language that restricted these definitions to acts committed by specific individuals, such as parents, household members, or caregivers, thereby broadening the scope of incidents that qualify as child abuse under Family Law.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Human Services (Social Services Administration)
stakeholders: Children under the age of 18, parents and family members, mandatory reporters (including educators, human service workers, and health practitioners), law enforcement agencies, and the Maryland Department of Human Services.

Title: Property Tax - Agricultural Use Assessment - Community Solar Energy Generating Systems
Synopsis: Altering the date from December 31, 2025, to December 31, 2030, by which certain community solar energy generating systems must be approved by the Public Service Commission in order for land that is used by the community solar energy generating systems to qualify for the agricultural use assessment.
bill_summary: This bill extends the deadline from December 31, 2025, to December 31, 2030, for community solar energy generating systems to receive approval from the Public Service Commission for the land they occupy to qualify for an agricultural use property tax assessment, specifically when the land is used for agrivoltaics.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Assessments and Taxation
stakeholders: Agricultural landowners, community solar energy developers, and owners of land used for agrivoltaics

Title: Criminal Procedure - Expungement of Records - Resisting Arrest and Making a False Statement to a Law Enforcement Officer
Synopsis: Adding convictions for resisting arrest, making a false statement to a law enforcement officer, and making a false statement to a law enforcement officer when under arrest to the list of misdemeanor convictions that a person may expunge under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill adds convictions for resisting arrest and making a false statement to a law enforcement officer to the list of misdemeanors that an individual may petition to have expunged from their criminal record.
stakeholders: Individuals convicted of resisting arrest or making a false statement to a law enforcement officer

Title: Motor Vehicles - Accidents - Required Testing for Impaired Driving (Mateo's Law)
Synopsis: Requiring any person involved in a motor vehicle accident that results in the death of, or a life threatening injury to, another person to submit to breath and blood testing for impaired driving.
bill_summary: Known as Mateo's Law, this bill requires any person involved in a motor vehicle accident that results in the death or life-threatening injury of another person to submit to both breath and blood testing for alcohol or drug impairment. The bill removes the prior legal requirement that a police officer must first have reasonable grounds to suspect impairment before requiring such tests in these specific circumstances.
responsible_party: Maryland law enforcement officers and medical personnel
stakeholders: Drivers involved in motor vehicle accidents resulting in death or life-threatening injury to others

Title: Election Law - Individuals Released From State Correctional Facilities - Automatic Restoration of Voter Registration
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services to transmit a list that includes the name and new residential address of individuals released from incarceration at a State correctional facility to the State Board of Elections on a weekly basis; requiring the State Board to automatically restore the voter registration of certain individuals released from State correctional facilities who were registered to vote in the State before being incarcerated; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services to electronically transmit a weekly list of individuals released from state correctional facilities to the State Board of Elections. The State Board of Elections must then automatically restore the voter registration of those individuals who were registered to vote in Maryland prior to their incarceration, updating their status to active at their new residential address.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services and the State Board of Elections
stakeholders: Individuals released from Maryland State correctional facilities who were registered to vote in Maryland prior to being incarcerated

Title: Education - Agreements, Procurement Contracts, and Memoranda of Understanding - Reporting and Publication
Synopsis: Requiring the reporting of certain procurement contracts and memoranda of understanding entered into by certain public elementary and secondary education systems in the State; and requiring each local school system to make publicly available on the local school system's website certain in-kind services agreements, procurement contracts, and memoranda of understanding.
bill_summary: This bill requires Maryland's public elementary and secondary education entities, including the State Board of Education and local school systems, to report and publish their procurement contracts, memoranda of understanding, and in-kind services agreements. Starting in 2026, local school systems must make these agreements available on their websites, and the State Superintendent must compile an annual report of these contracts for specific committees of the General Assembly.
responsible_party: State Superintendent of Schools and the Maryland State Department of Education
stakeholders: Maryland public school systems, county boards of education, State Board of Education, and the general public

Title: Public Schools - Airway Clearing Device Availability and Use - Policy (Bowen Levy Airway Clearing Device Act)
Synopsis: Requiring each county board of education to establish a policy to obtain at least one airway clearing device per school and to authorize school nurses and other school personnel to use an airway clearing device in certain emergency situations; and requiring the State Department of Education to develop and disseminate a form for public schools to report each incident requiring the use of an airway clearing device.
bill_summary: Known as the Bowen Levy Airway Clearing Device Act, this bill requires each county board of education in Maryland to establish a policy for public schools to acquire at least one airway clearing device per school. These devices, which use manual suction to clear obstructions during choking emergencies, must be stored near eating areas. The bill also requires training for school nurses and personnel, establishes reporting protocols for device usage via the State Department of Education, and provides liability protection for staff who use the devices in good faith.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education and county boards of education
stakeholders: Public school students, school nurses, and school personnel

Title: Maryland Money Transmission Act - Definition of Money Transmitter - Alteration
Synopsis: Altering, for a certain licensing requirement, the definition of "money transmitter" under the Maryland Money Transmission Act to exclude a certain person designated as an agent of a payor for the purpose of the agent's provision of payroll processing services under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the Maryland Money Transmission Act to exclude certain payroll processing agents from the definition of a 'money transmitter' and its associated licensing requirements. This exclusion applies if there is a written agreement between the payor and the agent, the payor identifies the agent to employees as its representative, and the payor remains legally responsible for payments even if the agent fails to remit the funds.
stakeholders: payroll processing services, employers (payors), and employees (payees)

Title: Energy Performance Contracts - Navigators, Funding, and Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring a public body that enters into an energy performance contract to comply with certain provisions of law regarding energy performance contracts; requiring the Maryland Clean Energy Center to hire or contract with navigators to assist a public body in creating an energy performance contract; altering the Jane E. Lawton Conservation Loan Program and the Jane E. Lawton Conservation Fund to allow for the issuance of certain grants and loans to certain public bodies; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires public bodies to comply with specific standards when entering into energy performance contracts and mandates that the Maryland Clean Energy Center hire or contract with regional navigators to assist these entities. It also renames the Jane E. Lawton Conservation Loan Program to the Jane E. Lawton Conservation Grant and Loan Program, allowing the Maryland Energy Administration to provide grants to public bodies for energy efficiency projects. The bill mandates an annual $1,500,000 appropriation from the Strategic Energy Investment Fund to support the navigator program.
responsible_party: Maryland Clean Energy Center and Maryland Energy Administration
stakeholders: Public bodies including State agencies, counties, municipal corporations, public institutions of higher education, local boards of education, and State or local hospitals.

Title: Moratorium on Construction of New Data Centers - Co-Location and Generation Contingency
Synopsis: Prohibiting a person from constructing a data center in the State; prohibiting a unit of State or local government from approving a proposal for the construction of a data center in the State; providing for the termination of the Act if the General Assembly enacts legislation regarding the co-location of data centers with a new or existing natural gas power generation facility, nuclear power generation facility, or small module reactor; applying the Act prospectively; etc.
bill_summary: This bill imposes a moratorium on the construction of new data centers in Maryland and prohibits state and local governments from approving such projects. The moratorium remains in effect until the General Assembly enacts legislation requiring new data centers to be co-located with specific power generation facilities, such as natural gas or nuclear plants, that meet the data center's power requirements. The bill applies prospectively and does not affect projects that have already obtained all necessary permits.
responsible_party: Maryland state and local government units
stakeholders: Data center developers, technology companies, and Maryland state and local government agencies

Title: Baltimore County - Alcoholic Beverages - Sale for Off-Premises Consumption
Synopsis: Providing that certain authorization for the holders of certain licenses to sell alcoholic beverages for off-premises consumption in a certain manner applies only if the Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore County has adopted certain regulations; authorizing the holders of certain licenses in Baltimore County that authorize the sale of alcoholic beverages at a restaurant or bar to sell certain alcoholic beverages for off-premises consumption under certain circumstances; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore County to adopt regulations allowing Class B and Class D license holders, such as restaurants and bars, to sell mixed drinks or cocktails for off-premises consumption. Such sales are subject to specific requirements, including being purchased with prepared food, verifying the purchaser is at least 21 years old, using specific sealed containers, and completing the sale before 11 p.m. The Board is prohibited from charging additional fees for this authorization but may limit the quantity of beverages sold per transaction.
responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore County
stakeholders: Class B and Class D alcoholic beverage license holders (restaurants and bars) and consumers in Baltimore County

Title: State Aid - Nonprofits - Status
Synopsis: Prohibiting a unit of State government or other State entity that provides State aid from providing State aid to a nonprofit entity unless the nonprofit is current with certain obligations under federal, State, and local law.
bill_summary: This bill requires nonprofit organizations to be in good legal and tax standing before they can receive any state aid, grants, or subsidies from Maryland state agencies.
responsible_party: Maryland state agencies and entities that provide state aid
stakeholders: Nonprofit organizations seeking or receiving state funding and state government units responsible for distributing aid.

Title: School Systems - Reportable Offenses - Alterations
Synopsis: Including institutions and programs of higher education in which a student is enrolled as part of a dual enrollment program in the definition of "school system"; adding certain offenses to the list of offenses a law enforcement agency must report to certain school personnel under certain circumstances; and authorizing State's Attorneys to make a certain notification if a student is arrested for certain offenses.
bill_summary: This bill expands the definition of 'school system' to include institutions of higher education where students are enrolled in dual enrollment programs and adds several criminal offenses to the list of 'reportable offenses' that law enforcement must report to school officials. It also authorizes State's Attorneys to notify schools of a student's arrest if law enforcement fails to do so and updates annual reporting requirements to include data on students in dual enrollment programs.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education, local school systems, and State law enforcement agencies
stakeholders: Maryland students aged 5 to 22, local school systems, institutions of higher education with dual enrollment programs, law enforcement agencies, and State's Attorneys

Title: Income Tax - Subtraction Modification - Losses From Theft or Fraud
Synopsis: Allowing, subject to certain limitations, a subtraction modification under the Maryland income tax for certain personal casualty losses of certain retirement assets from theft or a fraud scheme; and applying the Act to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2025.
bill_summary: This bill allows Maryland taxpayers to claim an income tax subtraction modification for personal casualty losses, expenses, and penalties resulting from theft or fraud schemes involving assets in qualified retirement plans, provided they submit a police report and evidence of the loss.
stakeholders: Maryland taxpayers who have experienced theft or fraud related to their qualified retirement plan assets

Title: Vehicle Laws – Historic Motor Vehicles – Minimum Age
Synopsis: Requiring that a motor vehicle be at least 25 years old in order to be eligible for registration as a historic motor vehicle.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the criteria for a motor vehicle to be eligible for historic registration in Maryland. It replaces the fixed model year requirement (1999 or earlier) with a requirement that the vehicle must be at least 25 years old. The bill applies to vehicles registered on or after July 1, 2026, and maintains current usage restrictions, which prohibit the use of historic vehicles for general daily transportation or commercial purposes.
stakeholders: Maryland motor vehicle owners seeking historic vehicle registration

Title: Regulated Firearms - Seven-Day Waiting Period - Exceptions
Synopsis: Exempting a sale, rental, or transfer of a regulated firearm from the seven-day waiting period requirement if the purchaser, renter, or receiver of the firearm is a law enforcement officer, a retired law enforcement officer who retired in good standing, or an individual with a permit to wear, carry, or transport a handgun.
bill_summary: This bill creates exceptions to the mandatory seven-day waiting period for the sale, rental, or transfer of regulated firearms for active law enforcement officers, retired law enforcement officers who retired in good standing, and individuals who have been issued a permit to wear, carry, or transport a handgun.
stakeholders: Active law enforcement officers, retired law enforcement officers, handgun permit holders, and licensed firearm dealers.

Title: Baltimore County - Property Tax Credits - Public Safety Officers and Public School System Employees
Synopsis: Requiring the governing body of Baltimore County to grant, by law, a  property tax credit against the county property tax imposed on certain dwellings owned by public safety officers or Baltimore County public school employees under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill requires the governing body of Baltimore County to establish property tax credits for homes owned by public safety officers and employees of the Baltimore County public school system. The county is responsible for determining the specific amount, duration, and eligibility criteria for these credits.
stakeholders: Public safety officers and Baltimore County public school system employees who own dwellings in Baltimore County.

Title: County Boards of Education - Therapy Dogs - Policy for Handling and Use in Schools
Synopsis: Requiring a county board of education to allow, subject to certain requirements and policies, the use of therapy dogs in public schools in the county.
bill_summary: This bill requires each county board of education in Maryland to allow the use of therapy dogs in public schools. It mandates that each board adopt a formal policy governing the use and handling of therapy dogs, which must include certification or registration requirements, guidelines for handlers, specific rules for when and where dogs are allowed in school buildings, notification procedures for the school community, and protocols for accommodating individuals with allergies or fears.
stakeholders: Public school students needing emotional support, parents, school faculty and staff, and therapy dog handlers

Title: Public Funding - Nonprofit Entities - Reporting
Synopsis: Requiring a nonprofit entity that receives at least 50% of its funding each year from a grant from the State, a county, or a municipality, the State capital budget, or certain local impact grants to report certain information to the Comptroller; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires nonprofit entities that receive 50% or more of their annual funding from state, county, or municipal sources to report their funding amounts and usage to the State Comptroller. The Comptroller is then responsible for summarizing these reports and submitting an annual summary to the General Assembly.
stakeholders: Nonprofit entities receiving 50% or more of their funding from government sources in Maryland

Title: Criminal Law - Deed Fraud - Prohibition, Deed Fraud Prevention Grant Fund, and Task Force to Study Deed Fraud
Synopsis: Prohibiting the intentional fraudulent sale, conveyance, or lease or attempted sale, conveyance, or lease of real property by a person who does not own the real property; prohibiting the acquisition, sale, or conveyance or the attempted acquisition, sale, or conveyance of real property by deception, intimidation, threat, or undue influence; establishing the Deed Fraud Prevention Grant Fund; and establishing the Task Force to Study Deed Fraud.
bill_summary: This bill defines and criminalizes deed fraud, specifically prohibiting the unauthorized sale, lease, or conveyance of real property and the use of counterfeit deeds. It establishes the Deed Fraud Prevention Grant Fund to support law enforcement, legal services for victims, and emergency housing for displaced individuals. Additionally, it creates a Task Force to Study Deed Fraud to analyze crime trends and develop recommendations for intergovernmental coordination and prevention.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
stakeholders: Victims of deed fraud, real property owners, law enforcement agencies, and legal service providers

Title: Criminal Procedure - Expungement - Adverse Actions and Removal From Maryland Electronic Courts (MDEC) System
Synopsis: Clarifying that refusal by a person to disclose information about criminal charges that have been expunged may not be the sole reason for a unit, an official, or an employee of the State or a political subdivision of the State to deny the person's application for a license, permit, registration, or governmental service; providing that refusal by a person to disclose information about criminal charges that have been expunged may not be the sole reason for an educational institution to expel or refuse to admit the person; etc.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits state agencies and educational institutions from denying licenses, services, or admission based on a person's refusal to disclose expunged criminal charges. It also mandates that the Maryland Electronic Courts (MDEC) system and Maryland Judiciary Case Search remove all references to criminal cases where cannabis possession was the only charge and was disposed of before July 1, 2023.
responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary and the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
stakeholders: Persons with expunged criminal records, applicants for State licenses or governmental services, students and applicants of educational institutions, and individuals with prior cannabis possession charges.

Title: Wiretapping and Electronic Surveillance - Intercepted Communications - Admissibility of Evidence
Synopsis: Providing that the contents of a certain intercepted communication and evidence derived from the communication may be received in evidence in a certain criminal proceeding under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill modifies Maryland's rules of evidence to allow the contents of intercepted wire, oral, or electronic communications to be admitted in criminal trials and hearings under specific circumstances. For such evidence to be admissible, a court must determine that the case involves a crime against an individual, the evidence is material and highly probative, and its admission serves the interest of justice, provided the interception was not conducted by state law enforcement and proper notice is given to the adverse party.
responsible_party: The Maryland District Court and Circuit Court
stakeholders: Criminal defendants, crime victims, and legal practitioners within the Maryland judicial system

Title: Income Tax and Sales and Use Tax - Rate Reductions and Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the State individual and corporate income tax rates; increasing, from 2% to 3%, the income tax rate imposed on the net capital gains attributable to certain sources of income; exempting from the income tax on net capital gains the first $10,000 in net capital gains of an individual who is at least 65 years old; reducing, from 6% to 3%, the sales and use tax rate; reducing, from 9% to 3%, the sales and use tax rate on alcohol and cannabis sales; repealing the sales and use tax on the sale of certain technology services; etc.
bill_summary: This bill significantly reduces Maryland's individual and corporate income tax rates to a flat 3% and lowers the general sales and use tax rate from 6% to 3%. It modifies the taxation of net capital gains, including a new 3% additional tax rate while providing a $10,000 exemption for individuals aged 65 and older, and repeals sales taxes on specific information technology services and custom computer software.
stakeholders: Maryland individual and corporate taxpayers, consumers, seniors aged 65 and older, and the information technology and software services industry.

Title: Family Law - Incapacitated or Protected Persons - Petition for Visitation
Synopsis: Establishing a rebuttable presumption relating to the best interest of an alleged incapacitated or protected person in an action under the Act; authorizing a certain person to petition a certain court for reasonable visitation with a certain alleged incapacitated or protected person; authorizing the court to impose certain restrictions on a certain visitation; establishing a certain immunity from civil liability under certain circumstances; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a legal framework allowing family members and interested parties to petition a court for visitation with an incapacitated or protected person. It creates a rebuttable presumption that visitation with close relatives is in the person's best interest, outlines the petition process, authorizes the court to impose visitation restrictions, and requires authorized decision-makers to provide information regarding the person's residence and funeral arrangements upon request.
stakeholders: Incapacitated or protected persons, their spouses, adult children, adult grandchildren, parents, adult siblings, court-appointed guardians, and authorized decision-makers.

Title: Economic Development - Tax Increment Financing - Noncontiguous Areas
Synopsis: Authorizing the governing body of a political subdivision to designate certain noncontiguous blighted areas as development districts.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes local governments in Maryland, including Baltimore City, to designate noncontiguous blighted areas as development districts for the purposes of tax increment financing. It defines a blighted area as one where buildings have significantly declined in productivity due to obsolescence or depreciation and allows these areas to be part of a development district even if they are not physically connected.
stakeholders: Local governments, real estate developers, and residents or property owners in blighted urban areas.

Title: Maryland Public Ethics Law - Officials of the Legislative Branch - Gifts of Food and Beverages
Synopsis: Altering an exemption that allows an official of the Legislative Branch to accept a gift of food or beverages as part of a meal or reception to which a legislative unit is invited to instead allow an official of the Legislative Branch to accept a gift of food or beverages at a meal or reception to which all members of the General Assembly are invited and that was open to the public; altering the written invitation and registration report requirements a regulated lobbyist must meet under certain circumstances; etc.
bill_summary: This bill modifies Maryland Public Ethics Law regarding gifts of food and beverages to legislative officials. It restricts the gift exemption for meals and receptions to only those events where every member of the General Assembly is invited and the event is open to the public. It also requires regulated lobbyists to register such events with the Department of Legislative Services 14 days in advance, rather than the previous 5 days, and mandates that the Department post the event details on the General Assembly website.
responsible_party: Maryland State Ethics Commission and Department of Legislative Services
stakeholders: Members of the Maryland General Assembly, regulated lobbyists, and the general public

Title: Family Law - Child Custody Evaluators - Qualifications
Synopsis: Establishing qualifications for an individual to be appointed by a court as a custody evaluator; and authorizing a court to waive certain requirements for a court employee or an individual under contract with the court under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill establishes specific professional and educational qualifications for individuals appointed by a court to serve as child custody evaluators. It requires evaluators to be licensed mental health professionals, such as psychiatrists, psychologists, or social workers, and mandates training in areas including domestic violence, child abuse, and family dynamics, while allowing for certain waivers for long-term court employees.
stakeholders: Children and families involved in contested custody or visitation cases, and licensed mental health professionals serving as court-appointed custody evaluators

Title: Criminal Law - Third-Degree Sexual Offense - Burglary
Synopsis: Establishing that engaging in sexual contact with another without the consent of the other in connection with a first-, second-, or third- degree burglary constitutes sexual offense in the third degree; and altering the definitions of "tier I sex offender", "tier II sex offender", and "tier III sex offender" applicable to provisions relating to sex offender registration to include certain acts constituting sexual offense in the third degree.
bill_summary: This bill establishes that nonconsensual sexual contact committed during a first-, second-, or third-degree burglary is a third-degree sexual offense. It also updates the definitions of Tier I, Tier II, and Tier III sex offenders to include these offenses based on the age of the victim for the purpose of sex offender registration requirements.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
stakeholders: Individuals convicted of sexual offenses in connection with burglary, victims of such crimes, law enforcement agencies, and the Maryland judicial system.

Title: Sales and Use Tax - Tax-Free Day - Veterans' Day
Synopsis: Establishing November 11 as a tax-free day each year during which an exemption from the sales and use tax is provided for sales to certain veterans if the taxable price of the item for sale is less than $2,000; authorizing the Comptroller, in the Comptroller's sole discretion, to suspend the tax-free day; and requiring an individual, in order to qualify for the exemption, to provide to the vendor evidence of eligibility for the exemption.
bill_summary: This bill establishes an annual sales and use tax-free day in Maryland on November 11 (Veterans' Day) for veterans. The exemption applies to items with a taxable price of less than $2,000, provided the individual presents evidence of veteran status, such as a notation on a driver's license. The Comptroller is authorized to suspend this tax-free day at their discretion.
stakeholders: Veterans in Maryland

Title: County Boards of Education and Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners - Vacancy Procedures - Alterations
Synopsis: Requiring each county board of education and the Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners to hold an election for a vacant elected board member position that occurs 55 days or more before the candidate filing deadline for a certain election; requiring each county board and the Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners to appoint a replacement for a vacant elected board member position that occurs 54 days or less before a certain candidate filing deadline for a certain election; etc.
bill_summary: House Bill 140 establishes uniform procedures for filling vacancies on Maryland county boards of education and the Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners. Vacancies for elected positions occurring 55 days or more before a term's second-year primary filing deadline must be filled by election at the next general election. Vacancies occurring after this deadline, or those without qualified candidates, must be filled by the remaining board members through a public process including advertising, resume reviews, and livestreamed interviews. Vacancies for appointed positions must be filled within 60 days using the board's existing appointment methods.
responsible_party: Maryland county boards of education and the Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners
stakeholders: Maryland voters, candidates for school board positions, and members of county boards of education and the Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners

Title: State Personnel - Collective Bargaining - Graduate Assistants
Synopsis: Providing collective bargaining rights to certain graduate assistants  at a system institution, Morgan State University, or St. Mary's College of Maryland; defining "graduate assistant" as a graduate student at a system institution, Morgan State University, or St. Mary's College of Maryland who is a teaching, administrative, or research assistant or in a comparable position, a fellow, or a postdoctoral intern; and establishing a separate collective bargaining unit for the graduate assistants.
bill_summary: This bill grants collective bargaining rights to graduate assistants at certain Maryland public higher education institutions, including the University System of Maryland, Morgan State University, and St. Mary’s College of Maryland, and establishes a separate collective bargaining unit for them.
stakeholders: Graduate assistants at the University System of Maryland, Morgan State University, and St. Mary’s College of Maryland

Title: Child Support - Earnings Withholdings Limits
Synopsis: Specifying that the amount of earnings withholding or a wage withholding order for child support may not exceed 25% of the obligor's disposable earnings under certain circumstances; requiring an earnings withholding order or earnings withholding notice sent to an obligor's employer to include information on certain limits on earnings withholding; and authorizing an employee to contest the amount of an earnings withholding order based on certain limits.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a cap on child support earnings withholdings at 25% of an obligor's disposable earnings if the obligor's income is at or below 250% of the federal poverty guidelines, provided they were not found to be voluntarily impoverished. It further requires that withholding orders and notices include information regarding these limits and allows employees to contest withholdings that exceed these legal thresholds.
responsible_party: Child Support Administration of the Department of Human Services
stakeholders: Child support obligors with incomes at or below 250% of the federal poverty guidelines, child support recipients, and employers.

Title: Electric Company Contracts, Capacity Market Models, and Regional Transmission Organizations - Studies
Synopsis: Requiring the Public Service Commission and the Maryland Energy Administration jointly, in consultation with neighboring states, to study the benefits and costs of, and make recommendations on, potential options for certain actions with regard to withdrawing from the PJM Interconnection, LLC capacity market model, developing a certain multistate compact, withdrawing from PJM Interconnection, LLC, and establishing or joining an alternative regional transmission organization; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Public Service Commission, in coordination with the Maryland Energy Administration, to conduct studies on electric capacity markets and regional transmission organizations. Specifically, it mandates an evaluation of the costs and benefits of requiring electric companies to secure long-term contracts for their energy capacity and examines the potential for Maryland to withdraw from the PJM Interconnection capacity market or the organization itself to join or create an alternative regional transmission entity.
responsible_party: Maryland Public Service Commission and the Maryland Energy Administration
stakeholders: Maryland electricity ratepayers and electric utility companies

Title: Commercial Law – Fair Pricing and Market Competition Fund – Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Fair Pricing and Market Competition Fund as a special, nonlapsing fund to provide additional operating funds for the Antitrust Division of the Office of the Attorney General; requiring that certain civil penalties, damages, attorney's fees, and costs awarded to the State be credited to the Fund; and requiring, for fiscal years 2028 through 2033, that the Governor include in the annual budget bill a certain appropriation to the Fund.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Fair Pricing and Market Competition Fund as a special, nonlapsing fund designed to provide additional resources for the Antitrust Division of the Office of the Attorney General. The fund will be supported by civil penalties and other awards from antitrust cases, and the bill specifically mandates funding for one full-time investigator position from fiscal year 2028 through 2033.
stakeholders: Maryland consumers and businesses, and the Antitrust Division of the Office of the Attorney General

Title: Election Law - Election Misinformation, Election Disinformation, and Deepfakes
Synopsis: Requiring the State Administrator of Elections to take certain actions if the State Administrator receives a credible report that election misinformation or election disinformation, including a deepfake, has been or is being communicated, disseminated, or distributed; requiring the Administrator to communication correct information to the public; prohibiting a person, under certain circumstances, from knowingly or with reckless disregard using or disseminating a deepfake to produce materially false information; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland State Board of Elections to maintain a public portal for reporting election-related misinformation and disinformation. It mandates the State Administrator to disseminate accurate information to correct credible reports of falsehoods and authorizes the State Board to seek injunctions or file civil actions to recover costs associated with these corrections. Additionally, the bill prohibits the use of generative AI-created deepfakes intended to influence voters or misrepresent election processes, establishing criminal penalties for such actions.
responsible_party: State Board of Elections and the State Administrator of Elections
stakeholders: Maryland voters, candidates, political campaigns, political action committees, and media organizations

Title: Environment - On-Site Wastewater Systems - Requirements for Inspection and Pumping Services and Implementation Dates
Synopsis: Requiring a landlord of property that is served by an on-site wastewater system to ensure, on or before July 1, 2028, and before each new tenant occupies the property thereafter, that the system has been inspected and pumped out in a certain manner; requiring a landlord or an owner of property to notify a certain delegated approval authority that an on-site sewage disposal system is failing and when the system is fixed, under certain circumstances; extending certain dates; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes requirements for the inspection and pumping of on-site wastewater systems, such as septic tanks, during property transfers and for rental properties. Landlords must ensure systems are inspected and pumped by July 1, 2028, and before new tenancies begin. Contracts for the sale of real property must include similar requirements starting in July 2028. Additionally, the bill extends the deadlines for the Department of the Environment to issue regulations and for wastewater professionals to become licensed.
stakeholders: Landlords, property owners, home buyers, tenants, and licensed on-site wastewater professionals

Title: Nonprofit Organizations Navigator - Termination Provision - Repeal
Synopsis: Repealing a termination provision relating to provisions of law establishing a nonprofit organizations navigator within the Department of Commerce.
bill_summary: This bill makes the nonprofit organizations navigator position within the Department of Commerce permanent by repealing its scheduled termination date of June 30, 2027.
