The navigator provides technical assistance to nonprofit organizations for state grant applications, helps resolve procedural complexities in grant-making, and shares information on grant opportunities.
stakeholders: Nonprofit organizations in Maryland

Title: Consumer Protection and Labor and Employment - Surveillance-Based Price and Wage Setting - Prohibition
Synopsis: Prohibiting a person from engaging in certain surveillance-based price setting; making a certain violation of the Act an unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practice that is subject to enforcement and penalties under the Maryland Consumer Protection Act; and prohibiting an employer from engaging in certain surveillance-based wage setting.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits businesses and employers from using surveillance-based price and wage setting. It defines these practices as the use of automated decision systems and surveillance data—such as behavioral, biometric, or personal information—to offer customized prices to consumers or customized wages to employees. The bill establishes that violations of the price-setting prohibition are unfair or deceptive trade practices, and it empowers the Commissioner of Labor and Industry to investigate wage-setting violations. Exceptions are provided for legitimate cost-of-service price differences, uniform discounts, and performance-based or location-based wages with proper disclosure.
responsible_party: Maryland Attorney General and the Commissioner of Labor and Industry
stakeholders: Maryland consumers, employees, and employers

Title: Fire Prevention - Assistant Fire Marshals, Residential Rental High-Rise Property Fire Safety Equipment, and Fire Alarm System Technicians
Synopsis: Authorizing a county or municipal corporation to designate certain fire marshals with the approval of the State Fire Marshal or to request that the State Fire Marshal designate certain fire marshals and requiring the State Fire Marshal to adopt certain regulations governing the qualifications, training, standards, and certification of designees; requiring installation of certain fire prevention in certain high-rise residential buildings; etc.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the designation process for Assistant State Fire Marshals, requiring the State Fire Marshal to establish specific training and certification regulations. It mandates that residential rental high-rise buildings undergoing substantial renovations starting October 1, 2026, must install automatic fire sprinklers and other specific life safety features such as smoke alarms, rated stairwells, and smokeproof exit enclosures. Furthermore, it directs the State Fire Prevention Commission to create a licensing and regulatory program for fire alarm system technicians and fire alarm system companies.
responsible_party: State Fire Marshal and State Fire Prevention Commission
stakeholders: Owners and residents of residential rental high-rise buildings, fire alarm system technicians and companies, and local fire marshals or fire officials.

Title: Circuit Court Judges - Selection and Retention Elections
Synopsis: Proposing amendments to the Maryland Constitution relating to the selection and tenure of circuit court judges; altering the method of filling vacancies in the office of a judge of a circuit court; providing for retention elections following an appointment to fill a vacancy in the office of a judge of a circuit court; providing for a transitional period during which the terms of certain amendments are to become effective; and submitting this amendment to the qualified voters of the State for their adoption or rejection.
bill_summary: This bill proposes a constitutional amendment to alter the selection and tenure of Maryland circuit court judges. It replaces the current system of contested elections with a process where the Governor appoints judges with the advice and consent of the Senate, followed by non-competitive retention elections every 10 years where voters decide whether a judge should remain in office.
responsible_party: The Governor of Maryland, the Maryland State Senate, and the Maryland State Board of Elections
stakeholders: Circuit court judges, judicial candidates, and Maryland voters

Title: Sales and Use Tax - Distribution of Cannabis Sales Tax Revenue - Maryland Veterans Trust Fund
Synopsis: Requiring 3% of the sales and use tax revenue collected from the sale of cannabis to be distributed to the Maryland Veterans Trust Fund.
bill_summary: This bill requires that 3% of the sales and use tax revenue collected from cannabis sales be distributed to the Maryland Veterans Trust Fund. The fund is used to provide monetary and other assistance to veterans, members of the Maryland National Guard, and their families, as well as to supporting public and private programs.
stakeholders: Maryland veterans, members of the Maryland National Guard, and their families

Title: Consumer Protection - Electronic Funds Transfers - Regulations (Elder Fraud Prevention Act of 2026)
Synopsis: Providing that consumer wire transfers involving electronic funds transfers made ancillary to bank-to-bank transfers via a wire service are subject to certain provisions of the federal Electronic Funds Transfer Act of 1978.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Elder Fraud Prevention Act of 2026, requires consumer wire transfers involving electronic funds transfers made through bank-to-bank wire services to comply with the federal Electronic Funds Transfer Act of 1978. It applies to all financial institutions operating in Maryland and aims to enhance consumer protection standards for these transactions.
stakeholders: Consumers using wire transfer services and financial institutions operating in Maryland

Title: Residential Rental Apartments - Air-Conditioning Requirement
Synopsis: Requiring a landlord to provide air-conditioning to residential rental units in apartment buildings with four or more individual dwelling units in a certain manner beginning June 1, 2026, for newly constructed residential rental units and beginning October 1, 2026, for residential rental units that undergo renovation that includes the replacement or substantial upgrade of electrical systems or heating systems; and applying the Act prospectively.
bill_summary: This bill requires landlords of residential apartment buildings with four or more units to provide air-conditioning to tenants. Starting June 1, 2026, for new constructions and October 1, 2026, for renovated units, landlords must maintain a temperature of no more than 80 degrees Fahrenheit from June 1 through September 30. The bill exempts historic properties and specific Baltimore City public housing developments.
stakeholders: Tenants and landlords of residential apartment buildings with four or more units in Maryland

Title: Open Meetings Act - County Boards of Education - Enhanced Requirements (Local Boards of Education Transparency Act)
Synopsis: Establishing enhanced requirements under the Open Meetings Act for county boards of education and the Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners; and requiring county boards and the Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners to maintain on their respective websites a complete and unedited archived video recording of each open meeting for which live video streaming was made available for a minimum of 5 years after the date of the meeting.
bill_summary: This bill establishes enhanced transparency requirements for county boards of education and the Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners under the Open Meetings Act. It requires these boards to provide meeting agendas, minutes, and live video streaming of open sessions on their websites, and mandates that archived video recordings of these meetings be maintained for at least five years.
responsible_party: County boards of education and the Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners
stakeholders: Maryland county boards of education, the Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners, and the general public

Title: Public Safety - Law Enforcement Officers - Prohibition on Face Coverings
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission to develop a model policy prohibiting the use of a face covering in the performance of duty; requiring a law enforcement agency to adopt a policy consistent with the model policy developed by the Commission; and prohibiting a certain law enforcement officer from wearing a certain face covering while in the performance of duty in the State, except when actively engaged in an undercover operation.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits law enforcement officers from wearing face coverings, such as balaclavas or ski masks, while performing their duties in Maryland, with certain exceptions for undercover operations, medical masks, religious garments, and specific safety equipment. It requires the Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission to create a model policy for law enforcement agencies to adopt. Violations are classified as a misdemeanor and constitute police misconduct.
responsible_party: Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission
stakeholders: Law enforcement officers and the general public in Maryland

Title: Election Law - Affiliating With a Party and Voting - Unaffiliated Voters
Synopsis: Authorizing unaffiliated voters to request to affiliate with a political party at an early voting center during a primary election and vote a provisional ballot for the voter's preferred political party; and requiring an election judge to determine whether the voter resides in the county in which the voter seeks to vote.
bill_summary: This emergency bill authorizes voters who have declined to affiliate with a political party to change their affiliation to a political party at an early voting center during a primary election. It further permits these voters to cast a provisional ballot for their newly chosen political party.
responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Elections and local boards of elections
stakeholders: Unaffiliated voters in Maryland

Title: Election Law - Campaign Finance - Exploratory Committees
Synopsis: Applying certain campaign finance requirements for a political committee to exploratory committees; establishing requirements and prohibitions for exploratory committees relating to the establishment of the committees, receipt of funds, and permissible disbursements; requiring an authorized candidate campaign committee that results from the exploratory committee to make any equipment purchases from the exploratory committee at the fair market value of the equipment; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes legal requirements and campaign finance regulations for exploratory committees created by potential candidates to test their viability for public office. It defines permissible disbursements, prohibits advance payments for future campaign activities, and mandates the distribution of remaining funds within 120 days of a candidacy decision. The bill also specifies that donations to exploratory committees are not subject to contribution limits.
stakeholders: Potential candidates for public office, campaign donors, and political party committees.

Title: Maryland Medical Assistance Program - Maternal Health Monitoring Pilot Program
Synopsis: Establishing the Maternal Health Monitoring Pilot Program in the Maryland Department of Health to support pregnant and postpartum Maryland Medical Assistance Program recipients who have higher risks of pregnancy complications because of maternal hypertension or maternal diabetes; requiring the Department to select at least one managed care organization to administer the Program; requiring the managed care organizations to contract with a technology vendor to offer remote patient monitoring services to participants; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Maternal Health Monitoring Pilot Program within the Maryland Department of Health to provide remote patient monitoring and clinical support for pregnant and postpartum Maryland Medical Assistance Program recipients who are at high risk due to maternal hypertension or maternal diabetes.
stakeholders: Pregnant and postpartum Maryland Medical Assistance Program recipients diagnosed with maternal hypertension or maternal diabetes

Title: Mail Theft
Synopsis: Altering the prohibition against taking and breaking open a letter; providing that a person may not knowingly and intentionally open mail addressed to another without permission of the person or an authorized designee; providing certain penalties for violations of the Act; prohibiting the theft of mail under certain circumstances; prohibiting a person from possessing an arrow key under certain circumstances; and providing for concurrent jurisdiction in the District Court and circuit court to try a violation of the Act.
bill_summary: House Bill 159 establishes and modifies criminal penalties related to the unauthorized opening and theft of mail. It defines 'mail' to include items delivered by the U.S. Postal Service or common carriers, prohibits possessing an 'arrow key' with the intent to commit mail theft, and sets varying levels of penalties based on the number of mail items stolen or the use of specialized tools. It also grants concurrent jurisdiction to the District Court and circuit courts for these offenses.
responsible_party: Maryland State Courts and law enforcement agencies
stakeholders: Maryland residents and businesses receiving mail, and individuals subject to prosecution for mail theft

Title: State and Local Government - Real Property - Confederate Naming Prohibited
Synopsis: Prohibiting a State entity or a political subdivision of the State from assigning a Confederate name to real property owned by the State or political subdivision.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits Maryland State entities and local political subdivisions from assigning Confederate names to newly acquired or named public real property, including streets, buildings, and parks. A Confederate name is defined as one that commemorates the Confederate States of America or any person who served voluntarily with the Confederacy. The prohibition is prospective only, meaning it does not require the renaming of existing property named before the bill's effective date of October 1, 2026.
responsible_party: State entities (Executive, Legislative, and Judicial branches) and political subdivisions (including counties, municipal corporations, school districts, and special districts)
stakeholders: Maryland state and local government units, political subdivisions, school districts, and the general public

Title: Property Tax Credit - Retail Service Station Conversions
Synopsis: Authorizing the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation to grant, by law, a credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax on real property if use of the real property has been converted from a retail service station to other certain uses; authorizing the State to pay to each county or municipal corporation that grants the property tax credit under the Act 50% of forgone revenue; and applying the Act to all taxable years beginning after June 30, 2026.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes Baltimore City and other Maryland counties and municipal corporations to grant a property tax credit for real property that has been converted from a retail service station into residential, retail, or mixed-use property. The credit is intended to help property owners offset the costs of removing underground storage tanks and cleaning up environmental contamination. The bill also allows the State to reimburse local governments for up to 50% of the property tax revenue lost as a result of granting the credit.
responsible_party: Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation
stakeholders: Owners of former retail service stations, local governments, and the State of Maryland

Title: Department of Aging - Maryland Access Point - Dementia-Friendly Communities
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of Aging to provide resources, training, grants, and other support to the Maryland Access Point network to create dementia-friendly communities through community-based efforts; and requiring the Maryland Access Point network to provide certain public awareness and educational materials to communities regarding community-based ways to support individuals with dementia.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Aging to support the Maryland Access Point network in establishing dementia-friendly communities. The Department will provide resources, training, and grants to foster community-based efforts that reduce the stigma of dementia, improve physical safety and accessibility, and promote social inclusion. The program will also facilitate specialized training for first responders, local businesses, and public agencies.
stakeholders: Individuals with dementia, families of individuals with dementia, care partners, first responders, local businesses, public agencies, and community groups

Title: County Boards of Education - Student Technology Use Policy - Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring a county board of education to develop and adopt a policy on the use of personal electronic devices during school hours; requiring the policy to restrict or limit the use of personal electronic devices by students during school hours, except for any purpose documented in the student's education program or Section 504 plan, to monitor or address a student's health issue, or for certain educational purposes; and requiring the policy to be published on the county board's website and in student handbooks.
bill_summary: This bill requires Maryland county boards of education to adopt and enforce policies that prohibit or limit the use of personal electronic devices, such as smartphones and tablets, by students during school hours. It mandates a prohibition for elementary and middle school students and a limitation for high school students, while providing exceptions for health monitoring, individualized education programs, and specific educational purposes directed by staff.
responsible_party: Maryland county boards of education and the Maryland State Department of Education
stakeholders: Elementary, middle, and high school students, teachers, school administrators, and parents in Maryland.

Title: State Buildings and State Highways - Collection and Disposal of Yard Waste
Synopsis: Prohibiting a person from disposing of yard waste collected on the grounds of a State building or State highway in single-use plastic container; requiring a person to collect yard waste on the grounds of a State building or State highway in a container that will not be discarded with the yard waste or in a compostable paper bag; and requiring all yard waste collected on the grounds of a State building or State highway to be disposed of in a certain manner under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill requires that yard waste collected from State buildings and State highways be gathered in reusable containers or compostable paper bags and prohibits the use of single-use plastic containers for disposal. It further mandates that such yard waste be disposed of at an organics recycling facility, a natural wood waste recycling facility, or a State facility with on-site mulching capacity, provided a facility is within a 30-mile radius and has the capacity to accept it. These requirements apply to State employees and contractors but exclude the disposal of noxious weeds and invasive species.
responsible_party: Maryland State agencies and departments responsible for the maintenance of State buildings and highways, and their contractors
stakeholders: State employees, landscaping and maintenance contractors, and organics and wood waste recycling facilities

Title: Courts - Sheriffs' Salaries - Alterations
Synopsis: Requiring that the salary of certain Sheriffs to be equal to the salary of certain State's Attorneys.
bill_summary: This bill requires that the annual salaries for sheriffs in several Maryland counties be equal to the annual salaries of the State's Attorneys for those same counties, with most changes taking effect in 2027 or at the start of the next term of office.
responsible_party: County Commissioners and County Councils of the affected Maryland counties
stakeholders: Sheriffs of Allegany, Calvert, Caroline, Carroll, Cecil, Dorchester, Frederick, Garrett, Harford, Kent, St. Mary's, Somerset, Talbot, Washington, Wicomico, and Worcester counties

Title: Public Health – Henrietta Lacks Commission – Establishment (Henrietta Lacks Commission of Maryland Act of 2026)
Synopsis: Establishing the Henrietta Lacks Commission to take certain actions related to the legacy of Henrietta Lacks and the use of HeLa cells; and requiring the Commission, beginning in 2027, to report by December 1 annually to the Governor and the General Assembly on its activities regarding oversight of life sciences activities in the State and promotion of education on the life of Henrietta Lacks.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Henrietta Lacks Commission to honor and manage the legacy of Henrietta Lacks. The Commission is responsible for bioethical oversight of life sciences research involving human subjects and tissue donation, promoting education on Henrietta Lacks and HeLa cells, curating a registry of tributes, coordinating with state tourism, and supporting economic development in the Turner Station community of Dundalk.
stakeholders: Maryland residents, the Turner Station community of Dundalk, life sciences researchers, students, and the Maryland tourism industry.

Title: Gasoline-Powered Leaf Blowers - Purchase and Use - Prohibitions
Synopsis: Prohibiting the State from purchasing gasoline-powered leaf blowers beginning July 1, 2026; prohibiting the State or any contractor or subcontractor employed by the State from using gasoline-powered leaf blowers beginning January 1, 2031; and requiring the State or any contractor or subcontractor employed by the State to comply with certain local government standards.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits the State of Maryland from purchasing gasoline-powered leaf blowers starting July 1, 2026. Additionally, beginning January 1, 2031, the State and its contractors are prohibited from using gasoline-powered leaf blowers on State-owned land. The bill excludes certain emergency and fire management activities and requires the State to adhere to local government standards regarding leaf blowers if they are more stringent than State law.
responsible_party: Each agency in the Executive Branch of State government
stakeholders: Maryland State agencies, state contractors and subcontractors, and individuals residing near or visiting State-owned land.

Title: Housing and Community Development - Affordable Housing - Educator Workforce Housing and Municipal Corporations
Synopsis: Establishing that providing educator workforce housing is an eligible use of certain financial assistance provided by the Department of Housing and Community Development; establishing that teachers and other employees of a local school system shall be considered a specified group for purposes of the federal Low-Income Housing Tax Credit program; and altering the eligible recipients of certain financial assistance.
bill_summary: This bill establishes educator workforce housing as an eligible use for financial assistance provided by the Department of Housing and Community Development. It defines educator workforce housing as affordable housing reserved for teachers and other employees of a local school system and designates these employees as a specified group for the federal Low-Income Housing Tax Credit program. The bill also expands the list of eligible recipients for the Housing Innovation Fund and the Housing Innovation Pilot Program to include municipal corporations and county boards of education.
responsible_party: Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Teachers and employees of local school systems, county boards of education, municipal corporations, local housing authorities, and housing developers

Title: Criminal Procedure - Expungement of Records - Good Cause
Synopsis: Authorizing a person to file a petition for expungement of any misdemeanor or felony conviction a certain period of time after the completion of the sentence, parole, probation, and any other form of mandatory treatment associated with the conviction; authorizing a court to grant a petition on a showing of good cause; and providing that a denial of a petition may not be appealed and a subsequent petition may not be filed for a certain period of time.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes individuals to petition for the expungement of any misdemeanor conviction at least 5 years after completing their sentence and related requirements, and any felony conviction at least 7 years after completion. The court is empowered to grant these petitions upon a showing of 'good cause,' taking into account the nature of the crime, the petitioner's character, public safety risk, rehabilitation success, and the impact of the record on the petitioner's life. Denied petitions may not be appealed, and the petitioner must wait at least 3 years before filing a subsequent petition for the same conviction.
stakeholders: Individuals with prior misdemeanor or felony convictions

Title: Commission to Study African American Civil War Sailors in Maryland
Synopsis: Establishing the Commission to Study African American Civil War Sailors in Maryland; requiring the Commission to study the history of the African American sailors who fought for the Union Navy; requiring the Commission to make certain recommendations regarding the funding, design, construction, and location of an appropriate memorial dedicated to African American Civil War sailors; and requiring the Commission to report its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly by December 1, 2026.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Commission to Study African American Civil War Sailors in Maryland. The Commission is responsible for researching the history of Maryland's African American sailors who fought for the Union Navy and providing recommendations for the funding, design, and location of a dedicated memorial.
stakeholders: Descendants of African American Civil War sailors, historians, and the general public of Maryland.

Title: Criminal Law - Drug Trafficking Crime - Definition
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "drug trafficking crime" applicable to prohibitions against possessing, using, wearing, carrying, or transporting a firearm during and in relation to a drug trafficking crime.
bill_summary: This bill expands the definition of "drug trafficking crime" to include specific cannabis-related misdemeanors, such as possession with intent to distribute and unlawful cultivation. By including these offenses, the bill ensures that individuals who possess, use, or carry a firearm during these crimes are subject to felony charges and mandatory minimum prison sentences.
stakeholders: Individuals involved in cannabis distribution or cultivation who possess firearms, law enforcement agencies, and the Maryland court system.

Title: Municipalities - Enforcement Officers - Body-Worn Cameras
Synopsis: Including a certain municipal enforcement officer in the definition of "law enforcement officer" for purposes of a certain exception to prohibitions against wiretapping and electronic surveillance relating to the use of body-worn cameras; authorizing a municipality to adopt an ordinance or a resolution authorizing an official who is authorized to act as an enforcement officer to utilize a body-worn camera; and requiring that a certain municipality publish its policy for the issuance and use of body-worn cameras by enforcement officers.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes Maryland municipalities to allow code, parking, and traffic enforcement officers to use body-worn cameras during their duties. It amends state wiretapping and electronic surveillance laws to include these officers in the definition of "law enforcement officer" for the specific purpose of using body-worn digital recording devices. Municipalities that choose to authorize camera use must develop and publish a policy for their issuance and use that is consistent with the standards established by the Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission.
stakeholders: Municipal code enforcement officers, parking enforcement officers, traffic enforcement officers, and the general public within Maryland municipalities

Title: State Designations - State Natural Science Museum - Natural History Society of Maryland
Synopsis: Designating the Natural History Society of Maryland as the State natural science museum.
bill_summary: This bill designates the Natural History Society of Maryland as the official State natural science museum.
stakeholders: Natural History Society of Maryland and the general public

Title: Motor Vehicles and Marine Vessels - Transfer-on-Death Designations
Synopsis: Authorizing an individual who is the sole owner of a marine vessel or multiple individuals who jointly co-own a marine vessel to apply to the Department of Natural Resources to designate a beneficiary to take ownership of the marine vessel on the death of the owner or each co-owner; and altering certain provisions of law governing the transfer-on-death designation for motor vehicles to allow multiple individuals who jointly co-own a motor vehicle to designate a transfer-on-death beneficiary.
bill_summary: This bill allows sole owners and co-owners of marine vessels and motor vehicles to designate a 'transfer-on-death' (TOD) beneficiary on the vehicle or vessel title, ensuring ownership passes directly to the beneficiary upon the death of the owner or the last surviving co-owner.
responsible_party: The Maryland Department of Natural Resources and the Motor Vehicle Administration
stakeholders: Sole owners and co-owners of motor vehicles and marine vessels in Maryland, and their designated beneficiaries.

Title: Income Tax Credit - Venison Donation - Alterations
Synopsis: Repealing the limitation on the maximum amount of a credit against the State income tax that an individual may claim for certain expenses incurred for a donation of deer meat to certain organizations; and applying the Act to all taxable years beginning after December 31, 2025.
bill_summary: This bill removes the $300 annual cap on the Maryland income tax credit available to individuals for expenses incurred to butcher and process antlerless deer for donation to nonprofit venison donation programs. While individuals can still claim up to $75 per deer, they are no longer restricted by a total yearly maximum for these claims.
stakeholders: Individual hunters in Maryland who donate venison to charitable organizations and 501(c)(3) venison donation programs.

Title: State Department of Assessments and Taxation and Department of General Services - Property Appraisal Aids - Geographic Images
Synopsis: Requiring the State Department of Assessments and Taxation to prepare, install, and maintain certain appraisal aids that consist of a database of statewide and local geographic images; requiring each county and Baltimore City to reimburse the State for 100% of the costs of the database less than $1,000,000 and 50% of the costs over $1,000,000; and requiring, by June 30, 2026, the Department to develop policies to protect the identity of any individual whose image is captured by oblique aerial photographic imagery.
bill_summary: This bill requires the State Department of Assessments and Taxation (SDAT) to create and maintain a database of geographic images, including Geographic Information System (GIS) visualizations and oblique aerial photography, to be used as property appraisal aids. The Department of General Services is tasked with procuring the necessary uniform system and tools for these aids. The bill establishes a cost-sharing model where Maryland's counties and Baltimore City must reimburse the State for 100% of the database costs up to $1,000,000 and 50% of any costs exceeding that amount. Additionally, SDAT must develop and report on policies to protect the privacy of individuals captured in aerial imagery.
responsible_party: State Department of Assessments and Taxation and Department of General Services
stakeholders: Property owners, county governments, and Baltimore City

Title: Vehicle Laws - Bicycles, Play Vehicles, and Unicycles - Crosswalks
Synopsis: Authorizing a person operating a bicycle, play vehicle, or unicycle at an intersection who is facing a red signal to enter the intersection to cross the highway in the direction of a pedestrian control "walk" signal displayed for the portion of the highway on which the bicycle, play vehicle, or unicycle is traveling; and requiring, before entering an intersection, a person operating a bicycle, play vehicle, or unicycle to yield the right-of-way to any vehicle or pedestrian lawfully using the intersection.
bill_summary: This bill permits individuals operating bicycles, play vehicles, or unicycles to enter an intersection while facing a red traffic signal if a pedestrian 'walk' signal is active in their direction of travel. Operators must yield the right-of-way to any other vehicles or pedestrians lawfully using the intersection before proceeding.
stakeholders: Bicyclists, individuals using play vehicles or unicycles, pedestrians, and motor vehicle drivers in Maryland.

Title: Public Health - Sickle Cell Disease - Specialized Clinics and Scholarship Program for Medical Residents
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Department of Health to establish certain specialized clinics for the management and treatment of sickle cell disease and establish a scholarship program for medical residents who specialize in classical hematology with a focus on sickle cell disease; and requiring the Governor for fiscal year 2028 to include in the annual budget bill an appropriation of $6,138,000 to support clinic operations, staffing, training, and social support services.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Health to establish three specialized clinics for the management and treatment of sickle cell disease in Montgomery County, Harford County, and on the Eastern Shore. It also mandates the creation of a scholarship program for medical residents specializing in classical hematology with a focus on sickle cell disease in exchange for a commitment to practice in Maryland for a specified period.
stakeholders: Individuals with sickle cell disease, medical residents specializing in classical hematology, community-based organizations, and sickle cell disease nonprofit organizations in Maryland

Title: Department of Commerce - Complaint Portal and Annual Report
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of Commerce to create and maintain a complaint portal for reporting when a governmental unit takes longer than 60 days to process an application for a license, form, certificate, certification, permit, or registration for a business or nonprofit organization; and requiring the Department, by September 15, 2026, and each September 15 thereafter, to submit an annual report to certain committees of the General Assembly on the complaints filed through the portal.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Commerce to establish and maintain an online portal where businesses and nonprofit organizations can file complaints if a governmental unit takes more than 60 days to process applications for licenses, permits, certificates, or registrations. The Department must submit an annual report to the General Assembly identifying the responsible agencies and summarizing the complaints while anonymizing the data to protect the privacy of the organizations involved.
stakeholders: Maryland businesses, nonprofit organizations, and state and local governmental units.

Title: Criminal Procedure - Incompetency to Stand Trial Dismissal
Synopsis: Altering the time period after which a court is required to dismiss a certain charge against a defendant found incompetent to stand trial under certain circumstances; and requiring a court to provide a certain notice and provide an opportunity to be heard to the State's Attorney and a certain victim or victim's representative before dismissing a certain charge against a defendant found incompetent to stand trial.
bill_summary: This bill alters the timeframes after which a court must dismiss charges against a defendant found incompetent to stand trial, specifically setting a 10-year limit for first-degree murder or rape. It mandates that courts notify the State's Attorney and victims before dismissal, providing an opportunity to be heard, and permits the State to petition for extensions in cases of extraordinary cause.
stakeholders: Defendants found incompetent to stand trial, State's Attorneys, crime victims and their representatives, and the Maryland court system.

Title: Public Health – Restaurants – Disclosure of Main Food Allergens
Synopsis: Requiring restaurants to make available to each customer a certain written disclosure of each main food allergen, if any, that the restaurant knows or reasonably should know is an ingredient in each menu item.
bill_summary: This bill requires restaurants in Maryland to provide customers with written disclosures of any main food allergens contained in their menu items. Restaurants may provide this information through their standard menus, digital formats like QR codes, or separate allergen charts and booklets. Failure to provide these disclosures can result in misdemeanor charges or civil penalties.
stakeholders: Restaurant owners and operators, and restaurant customers with food allergies

Title: Election Law - Presidential Electors - Selection and Voting
Synopsis: Altering the procedures for the selection of presidential elector nominees and alternate presidential elector nominees; requiring the State Administrator of Elections to preside at a certain meeting of certain presidential electors; altering the procedures for the meeting of presidential electors; and establishing procedures for the preparation, delivery, signing, and transmission of an amended certificate of ascertainment after the vote of the State's presidential electors under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the selection and voting procedures for presidential electors in Maryland. It requires political parties and unaffiliated presidential candidates to nominate both a presidential elector and an alternate, who must pledge to vote for their party's or candidate's nominees. The bill also tasks the State Administrator of Elections with presiding over the meeting of electors, establishes procedures for filling elector vacancies with alternates or substitutes, and requires the Governor to submit amended certificates of ascertainment if the final list of electors changes.
stakeholders: Presidential elector nominees, alternate presidential elector nominees, political parties, unaffiliated presidential candidates, and the Governor of Maryland.

Title: Vehicle Laws - Vehicle Emissions Inspection Program - Repeal
Synopsis: Repealing the Vehicle Emissions Inspection Program.
bill_summary: This bill repeals the Motor Vehicle Emissions Inspection Program (VEIP) in Maryland, effectively ending the requirement for biennial exhaust emissions tests and emissions equipment inspections for motor vehicles registered in the state.
responsible_party: Motor Vehicle Administration and the Secretary of the Environment
stakeholders: Maryland vehicle owners, certified repair technicians and facilities, the Motor Vehicle Administration, and the Maryland Department of the Environment

Title: Criminal Law - Identity Fraud - Artificial Intelligence and Deepfake Representations
Synopsis: Prohibiting a person from utilizing certain personal identifying information or engaging in certain conduct in order to cause physical injury, serious emotional distress, or economic damages; prohibiting a person from using certain artificial intelligence or certain deepfake representations for certain purposes; providing penalties of 5 years of imprisonment and a fine of up to $10,000 or both where one victim is involved, and for two or more victims the term of imprisonment is up to 10 years and the fine is up to $15,000 or both; etc.
bill_summary: This bill updates Maryland's identity fraud laws to include specific prohibitions on the use of artificial intelligence and deepfake representations for fraudulent purposes. It establishes criminal penalties for using these technologies to impersonate others, create false records, or cause harm, and grants victims the right to bring civil actions for injunctions and other relief.
stakeholders: Maryland residents and victims of identity fraud or deepfake impersonation

Title: Estates and Trusts - Spousal Lifetime Access Trusts
Synopsis: Adding to the circumstances under which an individual who creates a trust for the benefit of the individual's spouse may not be considered the settlor of the trust with regard to the individual's interest in the trust.
bill_summary: This bill updates Maryland trust law regarding Spousal Lifetime Access Trusts. It provides that a person who sets up an irrevocable trust for their spouse is not legally considered the creator (settlor) of that trust if they later become a beneficiary of it after their spouse dies through a power of appointment. This status protects the trust's assets from being seized by the original creator's creditors.
stakeholders: Married individuals, trust beneficiaries, estate planning attorneys, and creditors.

Title: Natural Resources - Bow Hunting - Sundays
Synopsis: Authorizing the Department of Natural Resources to allow statewide a person to hunt deer on Sundays throughout the deer bow hunting season and to hunt turkey using a bow and arrow on Sundays throughout the turkey hunting season.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland Department of Natural Resources to allow bow hunting for deer and turkey on Sundays throughout their respective seasons in various counties across the state, expanding existing hunting regulations that previously restricted Sunday hunting times and dates.
stakeholders: Bow hunters and residents of Maryland counties, including Allegany, Anne Arundel, Baltimore City, Baltimore County, Calvert, Caroline, Carroll, Cecil, Charles, Dorchester, Frederick, Garrett, Harford, Howard, Kent, Montgomery, Prince George's, Queen Anne's, St. Mary's, Somerset, Talbot, Washington, Wicomico, and Worcester.

Title: Criminal Procedure - Expungement - No Finding and Case Terminated Without Finding
Synopsis: Authorizing the expungement of a disposition under a certain provision of law if the disposition was included in a case that was disposed of by the court with a no finding designation or designated by the court as having been terminated without finding.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the expungement of criminal records for cases that were disposed of by a court with a 'no finding' designation or marked as 'terminated without finding.' It updates the Criminal Procedure Article to ensure that such dispositions can be expunged even if other convictions within the same case unit might otherwise limit eligibility.
stakeholders: Individuals with criminal records in cases that were disposed of by a court with a no finding designation or terminated without finding

Title: Unemployment Insurance Modernization Act of 2026
Synopsis: Repealing and establishing the methodology used to calculate the weekly benefit amount; altering the taxable wage base used to determine employer contributions to the Unemployment Insurance Trust Fund and the amount of earned wages subtracted from a weekly benefit amount; requiring the Maryland Department of Labor to determine and make available online the State annual average wage applicable to the rate of contribution; requiring, beginning in 2027, the maximum weekly benefit to be 40% of the state average weekly wage; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, the Unemployment Insurance Modernization Act of 2026, restructures the methodology for calculating unemployment benefits and employer contributions in Maryland. It replaces the existing fixed benefit schedule with a system tied to the State average weekly wage, sets a new taxable wage base for employers as a percentage of the State average annual wage, and requires the Maryland Department of Labor to calculate and publish these wage benchmarks annually. The bill establishes gradual increases to reach a target maximum weekly benefit of 40% of the State average weekly wage by 2027 and a taxable wage base of 16% of the average annual wage by 2029.
stakeholders: Maryland employers and unemployment insurance claimants

Title: Public Middle, High, and Charter Schools - Start Time for Instruction
Synopsis: Requiring, beginning in the 2028-2029 school year, each public middle school and each public high school to begin instruction not earlier than 8 a.m. and 8:30 a.m., respectively, unless granted a waiver by the State Board of Education under certain circumstances; and requiring each county board of education and each public charter school to implement a certain public service campaign to raise awareness of sleep deprivation and later school start times.
bill_summary: This bill requires Maryland public middle schools to begin instruction no earlier than 8:00 A.M. and public high schools no earlier than 8:30 A.M. starting in the 2028-2029 school year, with provisions for waivers in certain circumstances. Additionally, it mandates that each county board of education and public charter school implement a public awareness campaign during the 2027-2028 school year to educate the community on the health benefits of later school start times and the impacts of sleep deprivation on students.
responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Education and county boards of education
stakeholders: Middle and high school students, parents, teachers, school administrators, coaches, and county boards of education

Title: Constitutional Amendment - Form of County Government - Requirement to Adopt Charter Home Rule
Synopsis: Requiring each county to adopt a charter by December 31, 2032, using a certain procedure; altering the method by which a county shall adopt a charter under certain circumstances; requiring the charter to provide for the election of members of the county council by the voters of councilmanic districts; limiting the applicability of certain constitutional provisions governing code home rule counties; and requiring the amendment proposed by the Act be submitted to the qualified voters of the State for approval or rejection.
bill_summary: This constitutional amendment requires every Maryland county and Baltimore City to adopt a charter form of government by December 31, 2032. The bill outlines specific procedures for appointing charter boards and adopting charters, mandates the election of county council members by councilmanic districts, and limits the application of existing code home rule provisions once a charter is adopted.
responsible_party: Maryland county governments, specifically Boards of County Commissioners and appointed Charter Boards
stakeholders: Residents and registered voters of Maryland counties and Baltimore City, and local county government administrative bodies.

Title: Consumer Protection - Retail Transactions - Cash Payments
Synopsis: Prohibiting a merchant, in a certain transaction, from prohibiting a person from making a cash payment to purchase a good or service; requiring a person to purchase a good or service by using a credit or debit card, or charging or collecting from a person a fee for making a cash payment for the purchase of a good or service; and establishing that a violation of the Act is an unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practice subject to certain enforcement and penalty provisions under the Maryland Consumer Protection Act.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits Maryland merchants from refusing cash payments for in-person retail transactions totaling between $5 and $300. It also prevents merchants from requiring credit or debit cards for these transactions or charging extra fees for paying in cash. The bill exempts telephone, mail, and internet transactions, as well as parking fees. Violations are classified as unfair trade practices subject to enforcement by the Division of Consumer Protection, which must provide two warnings before issuing civil fines of up to $5,000 for initial violations and $10,000 for subsequent offenses.
responsible_party: Division of Consumer Protection of the Office of the Attorney General
stakeholders: Maryland retail merchants and consumers

Title: Maryland Higher Education Commission - Religious Educational Institutions - Certificate of Approval
Synopsis: Exempting certain religious educational institutions accredited by accrediting bodies recognized by the U.S. Department of Education from the requirement to obtain a certificate of approval from the Maryland Higher Education Commission to operate in the State.
bill_summary: This bill exempts certain religious educational institutions from the requirement to obtain a certificate of approval from the Maryland Higher Education Commission. To qualify for this exemption, the institution must have been authorized to operate and in continuous operation in Maryland since before January 1, 2013, even if it is accredited by a body recognized by the U.S. Department of Education.
stakeholders: Religious educational institutions operating in Maryland since before January 1, 2013, and students enrolled in these institutions.

Title: State Procurement - Transparency and Procedures
Synopsis: Requiring a unit of State government to provide a certain debriefing of a contract award to certain persons on request; adding an exemption to the prohibition on an individual who assists in the drafting of specifications, an invitation for bids, or a request for proposals from submitting a bid or proposal or assisting in the submission of a bid or proposal; requiring a procurement contract to include a certain clause pertaining to certain contract modifications related to changes in law; altering the required contents of a certain change order; etc.
bill_summary: This bill updates Maryland's state procurement laws by requiring state agencies to provide debriefings to unsuccessful bidders upon request and adjusting the timelines and procedures for contract protests and claims. It also mandates that procurement contracts include clauses allowing for adjustments due to changes in law and extends certain claim procedures previously specific to construction contracts to other types of state procurement.
responsible_party: Office of State Procurement and procurement officers within units of State government
stakeholders: State contractors, unsuccessful bidders (offerors), and Maryland state agencies

Title: Incarcerated Job Training Act
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services to develop and offer an apprenticeship program in skilled trades for incarcerated individuals; establishing that the purpose of the program is to assist incarcerated individuals to develop marketable job skills and to earn money that can be used once the individual is released from incarceration; authorizing the Department to pay all or part of an incarcerated individual's wages to a spouse, child, or other dependent in need of financial support; etc.
bill_summary: The Incarcerated Job Training Act requires the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services to establish an apprenticeship program for incarcerated individuals. This program aims to provide paid opportunities in skilled trades with state/local government agencies or private entities, helping participants gain marketable job skills and financial savings for their eventual release.
responsible_party: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
stakeholders: Incarcerated individuals, state and local government agencies, and private entities.

Title: State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission - Authority to Conduct Studies on the Use of Emerging Technology - Collaboration
Synopsis: Requiring the State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission to conduct studies of the State lottery and gaming program that identify certain trends and emerging technology to create a safe and transparent gambling environment; requiring the Commission to analyze certain technology that may be used by the Commission to carry out its duties in implementing certain provisions of law concerning sports wagering; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires the State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission to conduct studies on emerging technologies, such as artificial intelligence, cybersecurity, and digital identity verification, to enhance the safety and transparency of the State's lottery and gaming programs. It mandates that the Commission collaborate or contract with Maryland institutions of higher education, foundations, or private entities to perform these analyses if the Commission lacks the necessary internal resources or expertise.
responsible_party: State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission
stakeholders: Maryland lottery and gaming participants, the State Lottery and Gaming Control Agency, and Maryland institutions of higher education, foundations, and private technology entities.

Title: Public Health - Baby Food Testing - Definition of Baby Food
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "baby food" for purposes of certain provisions of law governing baby food testing to include, rather than exclude, infant formula and to include infant cereal; and altering the defined term "toxic heavy metal" to be "toxic element" for purposes of certain provisions of law governing baby food testing.
bill_summary: This bill updates the legal definition of 'baby food' to include infant formula and infant cereal. This change subjects these products to existing Maryland law which requires manufacturers to test for toxic heavy metals—specifically arsenic, cadmium, lead, and mercury—and mandates that testing results be made available to the public online and through QR codes on product packaging.
stakeholders: Babies and children under the age of 2, parents and guardians, and manufacturers of infant formula and infant cereal

Title: Comprehensive Community Safety Funding Act
Synopsis: Imposing an excise tax on certain gross receipts of certain firearms dealers derived from the sales of firearms, firearm accessories, and ammunition in the State and sales of firearms to residents of the State; requiring the Comptroller to distribute a portion of the tax revenues to the Maryland Violence Intervention Program, the Center for Firearm Violence Prevention, the Coordinated Community Supports Partnership, the Survivors of Homicide Victims Program, the Trauma Physician Services Fund, and the Cowley Shock Trauma Center; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes an 11% excise tax on the gross receipts of federally licensed firearms dealers from the retail sale of firearms, ammunition, and firearm accessories in Maryland. The revenue generated from this tax will be distributed to several existing state funds and programs dedicated to violence intervention, firearm violence prevention, community supports, trauma physician services, and grants for survivors of homicide victims.
stakeholders: Federally licensed firearms dealers, residents and purchasers of firearms and ammunition in Maryland, and organizations or individuals supported by state violence intervention and trauma programs

Title: School Systems - Reportable Offenses - Notification of Student as Suspect
Synopsis: Requiring law enforcement agencies to notify the State's Attorney if a student is a suspect in an investigation of certain offenses and if the student no longer is a suspect; authorizing the State's Attorney to notify the local superintendent or the superintendent's designee if the student is a suspect in an investigation of certain offenses; and requiring the State's Attorney to notify the local superintendent or the superintendent's designee if a student is no longer a suspect in certain investigations.
bill_summary: This bill requires law enforcement agencies to notify the State's Attorney when a student is identified as a suspect in a felony or crime of violence investigation and when the student is no longer a suspect. It permits the State's Attorney to share this information with local school superintendents and requires school systems to include data on these notifications in annual reports, while establishing confidentiality and record-keeping protocols for the shared information.
responsible_party: Law enforcement agencies, State's Attorneys, local school superintendents, and the Maryland State Department of Education
stakeholders: Students aged 5 to 21, local public and nonpublic school systems, and law enforcement agencies

Title: Estates - Maryland Uniform Simultaneous Death Act
Synopsis: Conforming the Maryland Uniform Simultaneous Death Act to the Uniform Simultaneous Death Act; providing that a surviving individual who does not survive the death of another individual for at least 120 hours is deemed to have predeceased the other individual for purposes relating to the inheritance of property; establishing evidentiary procedures for determining an individual's death or survival in certain circumstances; providing for liability under the Act in connection with the distribution of disputed assets; etc.
bill_summary: This bill updates the Maryland Uniform Simultaneous Death Act to align with the national Uniform Simultaneous Death Act. It establishes a requirement that an individual must be proven by clear and convincing evidence to have survived another individual by at least 120 hours to be considered to have survived them for purposes of property inheritance and devolution. The bill also outlines evidentiary procedures for determining death, clarifies property distribution for co-owners with rights of survivorship, and provides legal protections for third-party payors, such as insurers or trustees, who distribute assets in good faith.
stakeholders: Heirs, beneficiaries, co-owners of property, estate executors, and financial institutions or payors responsible for distributing assets from estates and trusts.

Title: Sale of Residential Real Property - Required Flood Risk Disclosure
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of the Environment to develop, publish, and maintain a real property flood risk disclosure statement form that includes certain information about a property's flood risk and history; and requiring, beginning July, 1, 2027, a vendor of residential real property to provide the purchaser with a completed real property flood risk disclosure statement form before entering into a contract for the sale of the property.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of the Environment to develop and maintain a residential real property flood risk disclosure statement form. Beginning July 1, 2027, sellers of residential property must provide this completed form, along with any relevant FEMA elevation certificates and flood claim histories, to buyers before entering into a contract of sale.
stakeholders: Vendors and purchasers of residential real property in Maryland

Title: Income Tax - Tips or Gratuities - Subtraction Modification (No Income Taxes on Tips Act)
Synopsis: Providing a subtraction modification under the Maryland income tax for compensation received in the form of a tip or gratuity for the performance of certain work in a food service facility, business licensed for on-sale consumption of alcoholic beverages, or hotel, for providing passenger-for-hire services, or for providing taxicab services; and applying the Act to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2025.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a subtraction modification under the Maryland income tax for compensation received as tips or gratuities by individuals employed in food service facilities, hotels, businesses licensed for on-sale alcoholic beverages, and passenger-for-hire or taxicab services.
stakeholders: Employees in the food service, hospitality, and transportation industries who receive tips or gratuities as part of their compensation.

Title: Public Health - Social Isolation and Loneliness Pilot Grant Program - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Social Isolation and Loneliness Pilot Grant Program in the Maryland Department of Health to provide grants for the operating costs associated with the maintenance or expansion of programs that target vulnerable populations with socioemotional support addressing social isolation and loneliness; requiring the Governor to include in the budget bill for fiscal year 2028 an appropriation of $100,000 for the Program; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Social Isolation and Loneliness Pilot Grant Program within the Maryland Department of Health to provide grants to organizations that support vulnerable populations suffering from social isolation and loneliness. The program targets youth, seniors, and rural populations, providing up to $20,000 per grant for operating costs like personnel and venue fees, with the aim of evaluating the impact of these interventions on mental and physical health.
stakeholders: Vulnerable populations including youth, seniors, and rural residents, as well as nonprofit and community organizations providing socioemotional support.

Title: Labor and Employment - Training Repayment Agreements - Prohibition
Synopsis: Prohibiting employers from requiring, as a condition of employment, employees or prospective employees to enter into training repayment agreements; defining "training repayment agreement" as one that requires an employee to pay an employer or a third party, such as a training provider, a sum of money if the employee voluntarily or involuntarily leaves employment with the employer; and providing that an agreement that constitutes a training repayment agreement is null and void as being against the public policy of the State.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits Maryland employers from requiring employees or prospective employees to sign training repayment agreements as a condition of employment. These agreements, which require workers to pay back the cost of training if they leave a job, are declared null and void as a matter of public policy. The bill authorizes the Commissioner of Labor and Industry to investigate complaints and assess civil penalties for violations, and it allows individuals to sue for economic damages and restitution.
stakeholders: Maryland employers, employees, and prospective employees

Title: Drinking Water - Regulation - Control and Prevention of Waterborne Disease
Synopsis: Establishing minimum detectable disinfectant residual level requirements, disinfectant residual testing requirements, and related requirements for the control of Legionella bacteria and other pathogens in the public water supply; requiring suppliers of water to provide certain notices and records regarding disruptions in the water distribution system; establishing requirements for the investigation of reported cases of Legionnaires' disease; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes regulations to control and prevent waterborne diseases, specifically Legionnaires' disease, by setting minimum disinfectant levels and testing requirements for public water systems. It mandates that the Maryland Department of Health investigate reported cases of Legionnaires' disease, including testing at water exposure points, and requires owners of certain large buildings to implement water management programs. Additionally, the bill establishes a public awareness campaign and consumer education program to inform the public about Legionella prevention and safety measures.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment and Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Public water system suppliers, owners and operators of large buildings (covered buildings), individuals diagnosed with Legionnaires' disease, and vulnerable populations at risk for waterborne diseases.

Title: Violent Criminals - Parole Limitation and Legislative Testimony Removal (Sexual Offender Accountability and Victim Protection Act)
Synopsis: Providing that an incarcerated individual who is serving a certain sentence for a certain sexual crime may be considered for parole only one time after becoming eligible; providing that if a victim, victim's family, victims' advocacy organization, or victim's representative objects to the granting of parole to a certain individual, parole shall be denied permanently; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Sexual Offender Accountability and Victim Protection Act, limits individuals serving a sentence of life plus additional years for specific sexual crimes to only one parole consideration. It mandates that parole be permanently denied if a victim, their family, or an advocacy group objects. Furthermore, the bill requires the Maryland General Assembly to remove written and audiovisual records of legislative testimony from its website if the testimony was provided by an individual convicted of a crime of violence, upon the request of the victim or their representative.
responsible_party: Maryland Parole Commission and Maryland General Assembly
stakeholders: Incarcerated individuals convicted of sexual crimes or crimes of violence, victims of such crimes and their families, and victims' advocacy organizations.

Title: General Assembly - Membership, Election Timing for State Senators, and Eligibility
Synopsis: Altering the membership of the Senate and the House of Delegates beginning with the 2033 legislative session; altering the method and timing of the election of State Senators; and requiring a Delegate who seeks election for a certain Senate term to vacate the seat of Delegate on the first day of the next immediately following legislative session.
bill_summary: This bill proposes a constitutional amendment to increase the number of seats in the Maryland Senate from 47 to 48 and the House of Delegates from 141 to 144 starting with the 2033 legislative session. It also establishes a system for staggering the terms of State Senators beginning with the 2032 election and requires current Delegates to vacate their seats if they seek a Senate term that begins before their Delegate term expires.
stakeholders: Registered voters in Maryland and candidates/members of the Maryland General Assembly

Title: Election Law - Certificate of Candidacy for Congressional Offices - Stock Trading Activities (Congressional Stock Trading Transparency Act)
Synopsis: Requiring the State Board of Elections to include the option on the certificate of candidacy form for candidates for congressional offices to indicate that, if elected, the candidate and the candidate's spouse will not engage in certain stock trading activities during the candidate's term of office; and requiring the State Board to publish on its website information concerning candidates for congressional offices who make that indication.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Congressional Stock Trading Transparency Act, requires the State Board of Elections to include an option on the certificate of candidacy for individuals running for the U.S. Senate or House of Representatives to pledge that they and their spouses will not engage in individual stock trading if elected. If a candidate makes this indication, the State Board is required to publish that information on its official website.
stakeholders: Candidates for the United States Senate or Representative in Congress and their spouses

Title: Courts - Evidence - Proof of Ownership of Real Property
Synopsis: Establishing that certain documentation relating to real property may be used to establish a rebuttable presumption of ownership of the property in certain court proceedings.
bill_summary: This bill establishes that certain documentation, such as a HUD-1 settlement statement, closing disclosure, or a certified copy of a recordation intake sheet, may be used in court proceedings to create a rebuttable presumption of real property ownership. The purpose is to allow new property owners to protect their interests during the time it takes for a deed to be officially recorded.
stakeholders: New real property owners, legal professionals, and the Maryland judicial system

Title: Health Care Providers - Assisted Reproductive Treatment - Informed Consent and Fraud
Synopsis: Prohibiting a health care provider from using the health care provider's human reproductive material when providing assisted reproductive treatment without the consent of the recipient of the treatment; prohibiting a health care provider from using a donor's human reproductive material to provide assisted reproductive treatment without the donor's informed consent or in a manner that is inconsistent with the donor's consent; etc.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits health care providers from using their own human reproductive material or a donor's material without proper informed consent during assisted reproductive treatments. It requires providers to obtain written and witnessed consent, disclose any errors or misrepresentation to the patient, and report such incidents to their respective licensing boards. The legislation establishes civil liability for violations and classifies the unauthorized use of a provider's own reproductive material as a felony offense.
responsible_party: Maryland health care provider licensing boards
stakeholders: Health care providers, recipients of assisted reproductive treatment, donors of reproductive material, and children born from assisted reproductive treatments.

Title: Motor Vehicles - Out-of-State Drivers - Automated Enforcement (Out-of-State Driver Accountability Act)
Synopsis: Requiring each county and municipal automated traffic enforcement program to submit to the Vision Zero coordinator a quarterly report containing certain information regarding each citation issued under the program during the quarter to a motor vehicle registered in another state.
bill_summary: The Out-of-State Driver Accountability Act requires county and municipal automated traffic enforcement programs to submit quarterly reports to the State's Vision Zero coordinator. These reports must detail citations issued to out-of-state vehicles, including registration information, payment status, and cumulative summaries of paid and past-due fines.
responsible_party: The Vision Zero coordinator and Maryland county and municipal automated traffic enforcement programs
stakeholders: Out-of-state motor vehicle owners, Maryland local governments, and the Maryland Department of Transportation

Title: Baltimore County – Property Tax Credit – Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 34
Synopsis: Authorizing the governing body of Baltimore County to grant, by law, a property tax credit against the county property tax imposed on certain real property owned by the Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 34.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the governing body of Baltimore County to grant a 100% property tax credit for real property owned by the Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 34, specifically for the property located at 730 Wampler Road in Middle River, Maryland.
stakeholders: Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 34, Baltimore County government

Title: Vehicle Laws - Out-of-State Vehicles - Improper Registration
Synopsis: Establishing a certain process for bringing vehicles owned by State residents that are improperly registered in another state into compliance with the Maryland Vehicle Law; providing that if a vehicle's owner fails to properly register the vehicle within 60 days after issuance of a warning, the Administration will begin to assess a civil fine of $7 per day up to 60 days; providing that if the vehicle is not registered within 120 days after the warning, the vehicle may be immobilized by towing and impoundment or by booting.
bill_summary: This bill establishes an enforcement process for Maryland residents who improperly register their vehicles in other states. It authorizes the Motor Vehicle Administration to issue warnings, assess a civil fine of $7 per day for up to 60 days for non-compliance, and eventually notify local jurisdictions to pursue civil action for vehicle immobilization or impoundment.
responsible_party: Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration and County State's Attorneys
stakeholders: Maryland residents with vehicles registered out-of-state, the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration, and local law enforcement

Title: Evidence – Interception of Oral Communications – Fair Housing Testing
Synopsis: Providing that it is lawful for a person to intercept an oral communication if the person is working as a fair housing tester for a fair housing testing program operated by the federal government, the State, a local government, or a nonprofit civil rights organization under certain circumstances; and providing that the contents of an intercepted oral communication may be used only for the purpose of enforcing federal, State, or local fair housing laws.
bill_summary: This bill allows fair housing testers working for government agencies or nonprofit civil rights organizations to lawfully record oral communications to which they are a party, provided the interception is for the purpose of obtaining evidence of fair housing violations. It also establishes that these recordings may only be used as evidence for the enforcement of federal, state, or local fair housing laws.
responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary and fair housing testing programs operated by federal, state, or local governments and nonprofit civil rights organizations
stakeholders: Fair housing testers, housing providers, nonprofit civil rights organizations, and individuals seeking housing.

Title: Higher Education - Academic Forgiveness Policy - Established
Synopsis: Requiring institutions of higher education to develop and implement an academic forgiveness policy on or before August 1, 2026, that applies to applicants who earned unsatisfactory or failing grades at a prior institution of higher education under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill requires Maryland institutions of higher education that receive state funding to develop and implement an academic forgiveness policy by August 1, 2026. The policy must allow applicants to have failing or unsatisfactory grades from a prior institution disregarded during the admissions process, provided the grades were earned at least seven years before the application and the applicant chooses to participate.
responsible_party: Maryland institutions of higher education that receive State funds
stakeholders: Applicants to Maryland institutions of higher education who earned failing or unsatisfactory grades seven or more years prior to their application

Title: Continuing Care Providers - Financial Stress Tests, Transparency, and Governing Bodies
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of Aging to conduct an annual financial stress test for each continuing care in a retirement community provider; requiring a continuing care in a retirement community provider to meet with a resident association at least quarterly and in a certain manner; requiring a provider to make agendas and minutes of certain meetings accessible to the provider's subscribers; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Aging to conduct annual financial stress tests on continuing care retirement community providers and publish the results online. It also mandates that providers meet with resident associations at least quarterly, requires the transparency of meeting agendas and minutes, and requires that resident representatives on the community's governing body be elected by the resident association and granted equal authority regarding financial and asset control matters.
stakeholders: Residents and subscribers of continuing care retirement communities, continuing care providers, and the Maryland Department of Aging

Title: Criminal Law - Benefits Exploitation
Synopsis: Prohibiting a person from knowingly recruiting, harboring, transporting, or obtaining an individual for the purpose of appropriating the government benefits of an individual for the benefit of the person or another through deception, coercion, exploitation, isolation, or any other means; prohibiting a person from aiding, abetting, or conspiring with one or more persons to violate a certain provision of the Act; establishing that a violation of the Act is a felony; etc.
bill_summary: This bill creates the felony of benefits exploitation, prohibiting the recruitment, harboring, or transport of individuals for the purpose of misappropriating their government benefits—such as Social Security, Medicare, or SNAP—through coercion, deception, or isolation. It establishes penalties of up to 25 years in prison and a $15,000 fine for violators.
stakeholders: Recipients of government benefits, including the elderly and individuals with disabilities; Maryland law enforcement and the court system.

Title: General Provisions - Commemorative Month - Maryland Native Plant Month
Synopsis: Requiring the Governor to annually proclaim May as Maryland Native Plant Month in recognition of the benefits that native plants have on Maryland's natural environment; and requiring the proclamation to urge educational and environmental organizations and businesses to observe Maryland Native Plant Month properly.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Governor of Maryland to annually proclaim the month of May as Maryland Native Plant Month to recognize the ecological benefits of native plants. The proclamation will urge educational and environmental organizations and businesses to observe the month with appropriate programs, events, and activities.
stakeholders: Educational organizations, environmental organizations, businesses, and the general public of Maryland.

Title: Office of the Attorney General - Environmental and Natural Resources Crimes Unit - Reporting Requirement
Synopsis: Altering the date, from November 30 to October 1 each year, by which the Office of the Attorney General must report on certain activities of the Office's Environmental and Natural Resources Crimes Unit and certain activities taken by the Department of the Environment and the Department of Natural Resources in response to findings of the Unit.
bill_summary: This bill changes the annual reporting deadline for the Environmental and Natural Resources Crimes Unit within the Office of the Attorney General from November 30 to October 1. It also clarifies that the annual report to the Governor and General Assembly must cover the Unit's activities during the previous fiscal year.
stakeholders: Governor, General Assembly, Office of the Attorney General, Department of the Environment, and Department of Natural Resources

Title: Maryland Voting Rights Act of 2026 - Voter Intimidation and Suppression
Synopsis: Altering public notice requirements of the State Board of Elections, local boards of elections, and certain municipal corporations with respect to changes in administrative policy affecting voting rights; prohibiting acts of intimidation, deception, or obstruction that interfere with the right to vote; prohibiting local governments from taking any action related to the election process that results in a disparity between members of a protected class and other members of the electorate; etc.
