bill_summary: The Maryland Voting Rights Act of 2026 establishes comprehensive protections against voter intimidation, deception, and suppression. It requires the State Board of Elections, local boards, and municipalities to provide at least 15 days of public notice before changing administrative policies that affect voting rights, with shortened notice periods during election cycles. The bill prohibits local governments from implementing election policies that result in a material disparity in participation or access for protected classes based on race, color, or language. It authorizes the Attorney General and aggrieved parties to take legal action to enforce these rights, empowers the Circuit Court for Anne Arundel County to order specific remedies such as expanded voting hours or additional polling locations, and mandates the reimbursement of legal fees for prevailing plaintiffs.
responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Elections and the Office of the Attorney General
stakeholders: Maryland voters, specifically members of protected classes based on race, color, or language minority groups, and local government entities

Title: Environment - Water - Individual Unit Meters
Synopsis: Authorizing the installation of individual unit meters, used to determine the actual use of water, for certain apartment houses and dwelling units; prohibiting the owner, operator, or manager of an apartment house, or a contractor hired by the owner, operator, or manager, from imposing certain costs on a unit; requiring each individual unit meter to include a leak detection monitor; requiring the maintenance of adequate records regarding individual unit meters; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the installation of individual unit water meters in apartment houses and residential condominiums to allow for the fair allocation of water costs based on actual consumption. It establishes regulations for the accuracy and testing of these meters, mandates the inclusion of leak detection monitors, and requires owners or managers to maintain transparent billing records for tenant inspection. The bill prohibits owners from charging tenants for water leaks caused by poor maintenance or for common area usage, caps administrative fees at $1 per month, and stipulates that unpaid water bills cannot be used as a basis for eviction. Additionally, it provides a legal framework for occupants to file complaints through local landlord-tenant or consumer protection agencies.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment and Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Owners, operators, and managers of apartment houses and residential condominiums; tenants and occupants of multi-unit residential facilities; and local housing authorities.

Title: Election Law - Primary Elections - Change of Political Party Affiliation
Synopsis: Proposing an amendment to the Maryland Constitution authorizing a voter to change the voter's political party affiliation at an early voting center or a precinct polling place during a primary election and vote the ballot for the voter's new political party affiliation.
bill_summary: This bill proposes an amendment to the Maryland Constitution and changes to state election law to allow registered voters to change their political party affiliation in person at an early voting center or a precinct polling place during a primary election and immediately vote using the ballot of their new party affiliation.
responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Elections and local boards of elections
stakeholders: Maryland voters wishing to change their political party affiliation during primary elections

Title: Educational Institutions - Opioid Overdose-Reversing Medications - Policy Requirements (Naloxone Access Act)
Synopsis: Requiring the State Board of Education to update a certain drug addiction and prevention education program to include information on the mitigating effects of naloxone or other opioid overdose-reversing medication; requiring each county board of education and certain institutions of higher education to update certain policies to include information on authorized possession of naloxone or other opioid overdose-reversing medication by certain individuals and immunity from liability; etc.
bill_summary: The Naloxone Access Act requires Maryland public schools and institutions of higher education to include information about the mitigating effects of naloxone or other opioid overdose-reversing medications within their drug addiction and prevention education programs. The bill also mandates that these educational institutions update their policies to authorize students, staff, and visitors to possess such medications and provides legal immunity for any individual who administers them in good faith during an overdose emergency.
responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Education, county boards of education, and Maryland institutions of higher education
stakeholders: Students, staff, and visitors at Maryland public schools and institutions of higher education

Title: Center for Firearm Violence Prevention and Intervention - Resources, Tools, and Educational Materials
Synopsis: Altering the powers of the Center for Firearm Violence Prevention and Intervention to include the creation of certain resources, tools, and educational materials related to firearms; and authorizing the Center to consult with State and local agencies and third-party organizations in carrying out those powers.
bill_summary: This bill expands the authority of the Center for Firearm Violence Prevention and Intervention to include the creation of educational materials, tools, and resources regarding firearm safety. Specifically, the Center is authorized to develop materials on the secure storage of firearms, extreme risk protective orders, and suicide prevention (including the 9-8-8 Suicide and Crisis Lifeline). The Center may consult with state and local agencies as well as third-party organizations to develop these public awareness and educational initiatives.
responsible_party: Center for Firearm Violence Prevention and Intervention
stakeholders: Maryland residents, firearm owners, communities impacted by firearm violence, health care professionals, and community and faith-based organizations

Title: Reentry and Reintegration Support Program - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing a coordinated, interagency partnership among the Department of Human Services, the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, and the Maryland Department of Health to create a voluntary prerelease benefits and identification application process for covered benefits for individuals being released from State correctional facilities; requiring by April 1, 2027, the Departments to enter into a memorandum of understanding to establish a secure data sharing process for certain purposes; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Maryland Reentry and Reintegration Support Program, a coordinated interagency partnership between the Department of Human Services, the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, and the Maryland Department of Health. The program provides voluntary prerelease application assistance to incarcerated individuals expected to be released within 90 days, helping them apply for SNAP, temporary cash assistance, and medical assistance, and obtain necessary identification documents at no cost to ensure benefits are active upon release.
responsible_party: The Department of Human Services, the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, and the Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Returning citizens (individuals confined in State correctional facilities expected to be released within 90 days)

Title: Maryland Horse Industry Board - Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the Maryland Horse Industry Board in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law) by extending to July 1, 2036, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board.
bill_summary: This bill extends the operational life of the Maryland Horse Industry Board by moving its termination date under the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law) from July 1, 2026, to July 1, 2036.
stakeholders: Maryland horse industry, horse owners, and entities regulated by the Maryland Horse Industry Board

Title: Department of Disabilities - Housing Programs and Affiliated Foundations - Establishment
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of Disabilities to establish affordable and accessible housing programs; authorizing the Department to establish one or more affiliated foundations to work with certain programs and units of the Department to solicit and accept funds, partner with individuals and entities, and promote certain activities that support certain projects; and requiring the Department by September 1 each year to report to the Governor, the Legislative Policy Committee, and the Ethics Commission certain information related to the programs.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Disabilities to establish affordable and accessible housing programs and authorizes the creation of affiliated foundations. These foundations are designed to solicit and accept private and public funds, form partnerships, and promote activities that support assistive technology, disability employment advancement, and integrated housing opportunities for individuals with disabilities.
stakeholders: Individuals with disabilities in Maryland

Title: Maryland Environmental Service - Authorizations and Requirements - Alterations
Synopsis: Expanding the authority of the Treasurer of the Maryland Environmental Service to delegate certain functions to the Deputy Treasurer of the Service; increasing the threshold amount from $25,000 to $50,000 or less for estimated contract costs under which the Service may use the small procurement process; and altering the process for providing notice of the establishment or adjustment of certain rates charged for Service projects, products, or services.
bill_summary: This bill updates administrative and operational procedures for the Maryland Environmental Service. It expands the delegation of duties from the Treasurer to the Deputy Treasurer, increases the limit for small procurement contracts from $25,000 to $50,000, and alters public notification requirements for rate changes to allow digital notifications via websites, email, or text in addition to newspaper notices.
stakeholders: Residents and property owners in service districts, ratepayers, and vendors or contractors bidding on Maryland Environmental Service projects.

Title: Horse Racing - Prohibited Acts - Slaughter of Racehorses for Commercial Purposes
Synopsis: Prohibiting a person from slaughtering or causing the slaughter of a racehorse in the State for certain commercial purposes; prohibiting a person from purchasing, selling, transferring, offering for sale, importing into the State, or transporting a racehorse if the person knows or reasonably should know that the racehorse will be slaughtered for certain commercial purposes; requiring certain fines collected by the State Racing Commission to be distributed to the racing Special Fund; etc.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits the slaughter of racehorses for commercial purposes, including for human or animal consumption, within Maryland. It further prohibits the purchase, sale, transfer, or transport of racehorses intended for commercial slaughter and establishes criminal penalties for violations. The State Racing Commission and the State Department of Agriculture are authorized to revoke or suspend the licenses of violators, and all fines collected under these provisions are to be distributed to the racing Special Fund.
responsible_party: State Racing Commission and the State Department of Agriculture
stakeholders: Racehorse owners, breeders, trainers, licensed veterinarians, and entities involved in the Maryland horse racing industry.

Title: Maryland Transportation Authority - Revenue Bond Limit - Increase
Synopsis: Increasing, from $4,000,000,000 to $5,000,000,000, the limit on the amount of certain revenue bonds that the Maryland Transportation Authority may have outstanding and unpaid on June 30 each year; etc.
bill_summary: This bill increases the limit on the aggregate outstanding and unpaid principal balance of revenue bonds secured by toll revenue that the Maryland Transportation Authority may have from $4 billion to $5 billion.
stakeholders: Maryland Transportation Authority and users of Maryland's transportation infrastructure and toll facilities.

Title: Transportation - Consolidated Transportation Program - Prioritization (Transportation Investment Priorities Act of 2026)
Synopsis: Altering the required elements of the Consolidated Transportation Program; requiring the Department of Transportation to develop a certain project-based scoring system, identify certain funds available for certain purposes, and solicit requests from certain entities for certain projects; requiring the Department to evaluate and score certain major surface transportation projects; altering the makeup, chair, frequency of meetings, and responsibilities of the Maryland Transportation Commission; etc.
bill_summary: The Transportation Investment Priorities Act of 2026 requires the Maryland Department of Transportation to develop and implement a project-based scoring system to evaluate and prioritize major surface transportation projects for inclusion in the Consolidated Transportation Program. The bill also modifies the composition and duties of the Maryland Transportation Commission, requiring it to review transportation policy, budget updates, and the project-scoring guidelines.
stakeholders: Maryland residents, local government jurisdictions, transit agencies, and metropolitan planning organizations.

Title: Higher Education - Guaranteed Access Grant Program - Applicability
Synopsis: Delaying the decentralization of the Guaranteed Access Grant Program until the 2029-2030 financial aid award year.
bill_summary: This bill delays the decentralization of the Guaranteed Access Grant Program until the 2029–2030 financial aid award year. It shifts the timeline for when Maryland institutions of higher education will take over the process of offering grant awards based on state-certified lists and receiving reimbursements from the state Office of Student Financial Assistance.
stakeholders: Maryland institutions of higher education and students applying for Guaranteed Access Grants

Title: Maryland Military Department – National Guard – Tuition Assistance
Synopsis: Expanding the institutions to include trade, or career schools recognized by the Maryland Higher Education Commission or the Maryland Apprenticeship and Training Council and the types of expenses in connection with which tuition assistance may be provided for certain eligible Maryland National Guard service members.
bill_summary: This bill expands the Maryland National Guard tuition assistance program by adding coverage for training assistance expenses, such as tools, uniforms, and certification costs, and broadening the eligibility of private vocational and career schools recognized by the state.
stakeholders: Active members of the Maryland National Guard

Title: Education - Public School Construction - Alterations
Synopsis: Clarifying the type of proposals and plans that require the approval of the State Superintendent of Schools; requiring a county board of education to request and receive approval from the State Superintendent before a county board may proceed with certain actions; authorizing the Interagency Commission on School Construction to adopt requirements for eligibility for certain State funding; repealing the requirement for the Commission to approve 75% of the preliminary school construction allocation by a certain date; etc.
bill_summary: This bill modifies and clarifies the administrative and regulatory processes for public school construction projects in Maryland. It specifies that the State Superintendent must approve proposals for school sites or renovations exceeding $1,000,000 that affect student-occupied spaces, increases the threshold for requiring change order approvals to $200,000, and updates the reporting timelines and assessment protocols for the Interagency Commission on School Construction. The act also establishes an appeal process for local jurisdictions regarding project funding and clarifies rules regarding state debt service reimbursement for schools no longer used for educational purposes.
responsible_party: Interagency Commission on School Construction and the State Superintendent of Schools
stakeholders: County boards of education, local jurisdictions, and Maryland public school students

Title: Public Safety - Police Employees and Deputy State Fire Marshals - Repeal of Pay Rate Restriction on Promotion
Synopsis: Repealing a requirement that a certain police employee or deputy State fire marshal is entitled to a certain pay rate on promotion to a higher rank if a certain other police employee or deputy State fire marshal in the same rank is at a lower pay rate.
bill_summary: This bill repeals a restriction on pay rates for Maryland State Police employees and deputy State fire marshals upon promotion. Specifically, it eliminates a rule that required a promoted employee to be placed in a lower pay step if their previous step was higher than that of an existing employee in the same rank who had equal or more total service time.
stakeholders: Maryland State Police employees and Deputy State Fire Marshals

Title: Housing and Community Development - Neighborhood Business Development Program - Local Approval Requirement
Synopsis: Repealing a certain requirement for approval by a political subdivision of a certain application for financial assistance under the Neighborhood Business Development Program from the Department of Housing and Community Development.
bill_summary: This bill removes the requirement that a local political subdivision must approve an application for financial assistance from the Neighborhood Business Development Program before the Department of Housing and Community Development can approve it. The Department is still required to provide written notice to the local political subdivision, but the affirmative resolution or letter of support is no longer necessary for the application to proceed.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Small businesses, nonprofit organizations, microenterprises, and local political subdivisions in Maryland.

Title: State Athletic Commission - Blood Testing of Contestants - Timing
Synopsis: Extending from 30 to 90 days the period of time before applying for a license to participate in a boxing, kick boxing, wrestling, or mixed martial arts contest and before participating in the contest during which certain blood testing may be conducted for purposes of submission of the results to the State Athletic Commission.
bill_summary: This bill extends the timeframe for required blood testing for boxing, kickboxing, wrestling, and mixed martial arts contestants. It increases the validity period of tests for HIV, Hepatitis B, and Hepatitis C from 30 days to 90 days prior to a license application or participation in a contest.
stakeholders: Contestants in boxing, kickboxing, wrestling, and mixed martial arts competitions

Title: Commercial Law - Earned Wage Access - Revisions
Synopsis: Prohibiting a lender from accepting a tip from a consumer or giving a consumer the option to provide a tip; altering the timeline for certain refunds; subjecting certain earned wage access providers and loan lenders to certain consumer loan requirements; etc.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits lenders and earned wage access (EWA) providers from accepting tips or offering tipping options to consumers. It reduces the timeframe for lenders to return received tips to consumers from 30 days to 7 days and subjects EWA providers to specific consumer loan regulations. Additionally, EWA providers are required to offer at least one no-cost service option and must disclose that they are legally prohibited from accepting tips or gratuities.
stakeholders: Consumers using earned wage access services and consumer loans, and financial lenders and earned wage access providers.

Title: Maryland Heritage Area Authority and Heritage Areas - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the voting membership of the Maryland Heritage Area Authority; increasing the number of voting members of the Authority that constitutes a quorum from 9 to 10; repealing the requirement that the Authority send copies of boundary maps to certain county clerks; etc.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the composition and operations of the Maryland Heritage Area Authority by adding new members, adjusting quorum requirements, and streamlining the ways state agencies support heritage areas. It also provides the Authority with greater flexibility in awarding grants and loans for the preservation and revitalization of certified heritage areas by removing specific matching fund caps and allowing the Authority to establish its own terms for financial assistance.
stakeholders: Maryland local jurisdictions, state departments (including Planning, Agriculture, and Education), heritage area management entities, and organizations focused on historic preservation and heritage tourism.

Title: Land Use - Zoning - Limitations (Starter and Silver Homes Act of 2026)
Synopsis: Prohibiting local jurisdictions from adopting or enforcing certain zoning provisions relating to lot size, dimensions, setback requirements, lot coverage, and design or architectural elements for certain single-family homes; prohibiting local jurisdictions from prohibiting certain housing types in certain zones; and prohibiting local jurisdictions from prohibiting certain subdivisions of certain lot types.
bill_summary: The Starter and Silver Homes Act of 2026 limits the authority of local jurisdictions to impose certain zoning restrictions on single-family homes and townhouses. Specifically, it prohibits local laws from requiring lot sizes larger than 5,000 square feet in areas with public water and sewer, limits building setbacks, and prevents the enforcement of specific architectural design elements. Additionally, the bill allows property owners to subdivide improved lots in single-family zones into up to three smaller lots and prohibits local governments from banning townhouses in areas zoned for single-family residential use.
responsible_party: Local legislative bodies and the Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Maryland residents, property owners in single-family residential areas, housing developers, and local government jurisdictions

Title: Local Comprehensive Plans - Guidance Materials and Notification to the Department of Planning
Synopsis: Requiring a local planning commission to notify the Department of Planning when beginning the review of the local jurisdiction's comprehensive plan; requiring the Department, within 60 days of receiving the notification, to provide guidance materials relating to State law, best practices for local comprehensive plans, and any other resources to support the plan's review; and requiring the Department to develop and maintain certain guidance materials in consultation with certain other State agencies and offices.
bill_summary: This bill requires local planning commissions to notify the Maryland Department of Planning when they begin reviewing or revising their comprehensive plans. Within 60 days of such notification, the Department of Planning must provide guidance materials, best practices, and other resources to assist the local jurisdiction. The bill also updates terminology in land use law by replacing the term 'visions' with 'planning principles.'
stakeholders: Local planning commissions, local jurisdictions, and the Maryland Department of Planning

Title: Business Occupations and Professions - State Boards and Commissions - Sunset Extensions
Synopsis: Continuing the State Board of Barbers, the State Board of Cosmetologists, the State Board for Professional Land Surveyors, the State Commission of Real Estate Appraisers, Appraisal Management Companies, and Home Inspectors, and the State Board of Individual Tax Preparers in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law) by extending to July 1, 2032, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the boards and commission; etc.
bill_summary: This bill extends the termination dates for several state boards and commissions under the Maryland Department of Labor—including those for barbers, cosmetologists, professional land surveyors, real estate appraisers, appraisal management companies, home inspectors, and individual tax preparers—until July 1, 2032. It also mandates that the Department of Labor submit specific reports on these entities to the Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee by July 1, 2030.
stakeholders: Barbers, cosmetologists, professional land surveyors, real estate appraisers, appraisal management companies, home inspectors, and individual tax preparers.

Title: Unemployment Insurance - Confidentiality of Information
Synopsis: Altering requirements related to the confidentiality of unemployment insurance information to ensure compliance with federal law and regulations; altering existing confidentiality requirements related to inspection of employment records and claim information by agents of child support enforcement units; establishing exceptions to confidentiality requirements in accordance with federal law and regulations; etc.
bill_summary: This bill updates Maryland's unemployment insurance laws to align with federal confidentiality regulations by defining confidential information and establishing strict protocols for its disclosure to public officials, child support enforcement units, and authorized third parties. It also sets criminal penalties for the unauthorized use or disclosure of this sensitive data by current or former employees of the Maryland Department of Labor and other data recipients.
stakeholders: Unemployment insurance claimants, employers, and employees of the Maryland Department of Labor.

Title: Land Use - Comprehensive and General Plans - Alteration of Elements
Synopsis: Altering the required elements of comprehensive and general plans for charter counties and other local jurisdictions; establishing requirements and guidelines for each element; and requiring certain State agencies to provide charter counties and other local jurisdictions with assistance and information relevant to the preparation of each element.
bill_summary: This bill redefines and updates the mandatory elements required in comprehensive and general land use plans for Maryland's charter counties and other local jurisdictions. It replaces previous planning categories with eight specific elements: Land, Transportation, Housing, Economy, Equity, Resilience, Place, and Ecology. The bill outlines detailed requirements for each element and requires various State agencies, led by the Department of Planning, to provide data and technical assistance to local governments for their planning processes.
stakeholders: Local governments (charter counties and municipal corporations), Maryland residents, commercial watermen, and residents of overburdened or underserved communities.

Title: Natural Resources – Vessel Transfers – Transfer–on–Death Beneficiary Designation
Synopsis: Authorizing an individual who is the sole owner of a certain vessel to apply to the Department of Natural Resources to designate a beneficiary to take ownership of the vessel on the death of the owner; requiring a designated beneficiary who survives the owner of a vessel to apply to the Department for a new certificate of title for the vessel; and requiring an application for a certificate of title for a vessel to contain certain information.
bill_summary: This bill allows a sole owner of a vessel to designate a beneficiary on the certificate of title who will receive ownership of the vessel upon the owner's death. It establishes the process for the owner to designate, change, or cancel a beneficiary and outlines the requirements for a surviving beneficiary to apply for a new title, including providing a death certificate and proof of identity.
stakeholders: Individual vessel owners in Maryland and their designated beneficiaries

Title: Maryland Energy Administration - Jane E. Lawton Conservation Loan Program and Maryland Strategic Energy Investment Fund
Synopsis: Transferring the Jane E. Lawton Conservation Loan Program from the Maryland Energy Administration to the Maryland Clean Energy Center; repealing the authority of the Maryland Energy Administration to adopt regulations to implement the Program; and altering reporting requirements for the Maryland Strategic Energy Investment Fund.
bill_summary: This bill transfers the administration of the Jane E. Lawton Conservation Loan Program from the Maryland Energy Administration to the Maryland Clean Energy Center. It also modifies the reporting requirements for the Maryland Strategic Energy Investment Fund, specifying that the Maryland Energy Administration must account for disbursements exceeding $10,000 and estimate greenhouse gas emissions reductions resulting from program activities.
stakeholders: Nonprofit organizations, local jurisdictions, Maryland State agencies, and eligible businesses.

Title: Video Tolls - Class G (Trailer) Vehicles - Liability
Synopsis: Establishing that the registered owner of a Class G (trailer) vehicle is liable to the Maryland Transportation Authority for payment of a video toll assessed at the time of passage through a toll collection facility, subject to certain standards and procedures for the transfer of liability.
bill_summary: This bill establishes that the registered owner of a Class G (trailer) vehicle is liable for paying video tolls incurred when passing through a toll collection facility. It defines the notification process for tolls due, sets procedures for contesting liability or transferring it to other parties such as lessees or operators of the towing vehicle, and allows for the suspension of vehicle registration for failure to pay.
responsible_party: Maryland Transportation Authority and the Motor Vehicle Administration
stakeholders: Registered owners, lessors, lessees, and operators of Class G (trailer) vehicles

Title: Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area Protection Program - Variances - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering certain standards and requirements for variances from land use requirements under the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area Protection Program.
bill_summary: This bill alters the standards and requirements for granting variances from land use regulations under the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area Protection Program. It establishes a rebuttable presumption that existing accessory structures demonstrate reasonable use, prohibits certain types of variance applications such as those for unauthorized uses or mitigation adjustments, and requires applicants to demonstrate a substantial need that is not based on convenience or financial advantage. Additionally, it mandates that local boards of appeals hear variance appeals on the record and grant deference to administrative findings of fact.
responsible_party: Maryland Critical Area Commission and local jurisdictions
stakeholders: Property owners in the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area and local government zoning and appeals boards

Title: Motor Vehicle Administration - Identification Cards, Licenses, and Permits - Repeal of Color Photograph Requirement
Synopsis: Repealing the requirement that the photograph included on an identification card, a driver's license, or a moped operator's permit issued by the Motor Vehicle Administration be in color.
bill_summary: This bill repeals the requirement that photographs on Maryland identification cards, driver's licenses, and moped operator's permits be in color, allowing the Motor Vehicle Administration more flexibility in the photographic format of these documents.
stakeholders: Maryland residents applying for or renewing identification cards, driver's licenses, or moped operator's permits

Title: Vehicle Laws - Automated Enforcement - Reciprocal Agreements, Arrangements, and Declarations
Synopsis: Altering the policy of the State regarding reciprocal vehicle registration agreements, arrangements, and declarations; and authorizing the Motor Vehicle Administrator to enter into reciprocal agreements, arrangements, or declarations to provide for reciprocal enforcement of violations recorded by traffic control signal monitoring systems and speed monitoring systems.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administrator to enter into reciprocal agreements, arrangements, or declarations with other jurisdictions for the enforcement of traffic violations captured by automated systems, such as red-light and speed cameras. It grants the Motor Vehicle Administration the authority to refuse the registration or renewal of a motor vehicle for violations occurring in participating jurisdictions.
stakeholders: Motor vehicle owners and drivers in Maryland and other jurisdictions with reciprocal traffic enforcement agreements

Title: Environment - Water Resources and Wetlands - Enforcement
Synopsis: Authorizing the Department of the Environment to impose an administrative penalty for certain violations related to the appropriation or use of water and dam safety; repealing a certain limitation on the Department's authority to issue certain orders and send certain notices related to dam safety; authorizing the Department to impose an administrative penalty of up to $5,000 for each violation, not to exceed $100,000, for certain violations related to wetlands construction, modification, or development; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland Department of the Environment to impose administrative penalties for violations related to water resources, dam safety, and wetlands. It establishes penalty limits of up to $5,000 per violation with a $100,000 total cap, defines specific criteria for assessing these penalties, and requires the funds to be deposited into the Maryland Clean Water Fund or the Private Dam Repair Fund. The bill also expands the Department's authority to issue corrective orders and notices for dam safety violations by removing previous limitations.
stakeholders: Individuals and entities involved in water appropriation, dam operation, or wetlands development; local governments; and the Maryland Department of the Environment.

Title: Vehicle Laws - Transfer of Used Vehicles - Repeal of Notarized Bill of Sale Requirement
Synopsis: Repealing the requirement that a notarized bill of sale be submitted to the Motor Vehicle Administration when transferring ownership of a certain used vehicle.
bill_summary: This bill repeals the requirement that individuals submit a notarized bill of sale to the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration when transferring ownership of a used vehicle, specifically in cases where the sale price is significantly lower than the vehicle's established retail value.
stakeholders: Maryland residents buying or selling used vehicles through private (non-dealer) transactions

Title: Environment – Lead Paint Abatement Services – Performance Bond and Liability Insurance
Synopsis: Authorizing regulations adopted by the Department of the Environment to include requirements for any person who is accredited by the Department to provide lead paint abatement services to be covered by a reasonable performance bond or reasonable liability insurance.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland Department of the Environment to include requirements for performance bonds or liability insurance in the regulations governing individuals and entities accredited to provide lead paint abatement services.
stakeholders: Accredited lead paint abatement service providers, including contractors, supervisors, and inspectors, and the Maryland Department of the Environment.

Title: Vehicle Laws - Heavy Weight Port Corridor Permits - Regulations
Synopsis: Altering the requirements for regulations related to the issuance of a heavy weight port corridor permit.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the regulatory requirements for heavy weight port corridor permits, which allow vehicles transporting international freight in sealed seagoing containers to exceed certain weight limits. It streamlines the criteria for authorized routes and requires the Secretary of Transportation to establish specific destinations accessible from the Seagirt Marine Terminal through these permits.
stakeholders: Commercial vehicle operators and companies transporting international freight from the Seagirt Marine Terminal, the Maryland Department of Transportation, and local highway authorities.

Title: Supporting Inclusive Community Adaptation Act
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of Natural Resources to facilitate community participation in project planning and development; establishing the Resilience Through Restoration Capital Grant Fund to provide funding for nature-based restoration projects intended to reduce the State's climate change vulnerability; requiring, by October 1, 2027, the Department to develop a website, guidance, and training for certain tools and resources; requiring, by December 31, 2035, the Department to take certain actions relating to climate change; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Natural Resources (DNR) to facilitate community involvement in project planning and creates the Resilience Through Restoration Capital Grant Fund to support nature-based projects that address climate change vulnerabilities. It mandates that DNR develop online planning tools, guidance, and training for local governments by 2027, and requires the evaluation of climate risks on State-managed lands by 2035. Additionally, the bill updates the Shore Erosion Control Construction Loan Fund to allow for loan forgiveness and ensures interest earnings are retained within the respective funds.
stakeholders: State agencies, local jurisdictions, nonprofit organizations, and Maryland residents in communities vulnerable to climate change hazards such as flooding and sea level rise

Title: Natural Resources - Pamela J. Kelly Tree-Mendous Maryland Program - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the stated purpose of the Pamela J. Kelly Tree-Mendous Maryland Program to include the advancement of forest health and resilience through the promotion and maintenance of native trees and shrubs.
bill_summary: This bill expands the purpose of the Pamela J. Kelly Tree-Mendous Maryland Program within the Department of Natural Resources to include the advancement of forest health and resilience. It broadens the program's scope from simply planting native trees and shrubs to also include their promotion and maintenance on public lands, community open spaces, school grounds, and rights-of-way.
stakeholders: Maryland residents, local communities, schools, and public land managers

Title: Motor Vehicles – Speed Monitoring Systems – Safety Corridors (Vulnerable Road User Protection Act of 2026)
Synopsis: Authorizing the State Highway Administration to implement a program of safety corridor speed monitoring systems for use in areas determined to be of high risk to vulnerable road users; authorizing a local jurisdiction to use speed monitoring systems in safety corridors under certain circumstances; authorizing the Comptroller to distribute revenue from the fines collected under the program to the State Highway Administration and the Transportation Trust Fund; etc.
bill_summary: The Vulnerable Road User Protection Act of 2026 authorizes the Maryland State Highway Administration (SHA) to establish and operate speed monitoring systems within designated safety corridors—segments of highway identified as high-risk for pedestrians, bicyclists, and other vulnerable road users. The bill also allows local jurisdictions to use these systems under certain conditions, establishes a tiered civil penalty structure for speeding violations (ranging from $40 to $425), and directs the resulting fine revenue into a special fund for program administration, general highway safety, and system preservation.
stakeholders: Motorists, vulnerable road users (including pedestrians, bicyclists, and persons using mobility devices), and local jurisdictions in Maryland.

Title: Environment - Flood-Related Watershed Studies and Comprehensive Flood Management Grant Program
Synopsis: Requiring, by January 1, 2028, and every 5 years thereafter, and after consultation with local jurisdictions and State agencies, the Department of the Environment to designate priority watersheds for the purpose of requiring subdivisions to conduct flood-related watershed studies; requiring a subdivision that contains a designated priority watershed to conduct a watershed study and submit the study to the Department for review and approval; specifying the required contents of a flood-related watershed study required under the Act; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Department of the Environment to designate priority watersheds every five years and mandates that local subdivisions within those watersheds conduct comprehensive flood-related studies. It updates the Comprehensive Flood Management Grant Program to allow grants for these studies, establishes new limits on grant awards, and requires that at least 40% of program funding be used for projects benefiting underserved or overburdened communities.
stakeholders: Maryland counties and municipalities, residents and property owners in flood-prone areas, and underserved or overburdened communities

Title: Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area Protection Program - Standards and Procedures
Synopsis: Altering and updating the standards and procedures governing the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area Protection Program related to the approval of regulations, local program comprehensive reviews, locational standards for growth allocation, correcting mapping mistakes, and tree replanting.
bill_summary: This bill updates administrative standards and procedures for the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area Protection Program. It extends the required cycle for local program comprehensive reviews from 6 to 10 years, clarifies that growth allocations must be contiguous and adjoining to existing developed areas, and updates the timeline for correcting mapping mistakes. Additionally, it expands the types of qualified professionals who can prepare tree replanting plans for violations and redirects certain damage payments to local jurisdictions instead of the state department.
stakeholders: Local jurisdictions within the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Areas, property owners, developers, licensed foresters, and licensed landscape architects.

Title: Financial Institutions - Maryland Community Investment Venture Fund and Regulation of Entities - Revisions
Synopsis: Repealing certain fees charged to certain banking institutions by the Commissioner of Financial Regulation; altering certain provisions relating to the Maryland Community Investment Venture Fund, including the purpose and administration of the Fund; altering the date by which the Commissioner may match certain investments in the Fund from June 30, 2028, to June 30, 2030; altering and providing for certain assessment offset credits for certain banking institutions and credit unions; etc.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the administration and purpose of the Maryland Community Investment Venture Fund, extending its investment matching period to June 30, 2030. It focuses on promoting financial innovations, grants, and investments for consumers and businesses in low- to moderate-income areas. Additionally, the bill introduces assessment offset credits for financial institutions that offer 'Maryland Opportunity Accounts,' repeals specific administrative fees for banks, and updates the definition of an emergency to include cybersecurity incidents for the purpose of bank closures.
stakeholders: Banking institutions, credit unions, and consumers and businesses in low- to moderate-income census tracts.

Title: Public Financing Act – Fair Campaign Financing Fund – Distributions
Synopsis: Altering, from January 1 of the year of the election to July 1 of the year before the election, the earliest date on which the State Board of Elections may begin making distributions from the Fair Campaign Financing Fund.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the timing for the distribution of money from the Fair Campaign Financing Fund, allowing the State Board of Elections to begin making distributions as early as July 1 of the year before an election, rather than January 1 of the election year.
stakeholders: Maryland political candidates qualifying for public financing and the State Board of Elections

Title: State Procurement - Competitive Proof of Concept Procurement
Synopsis: Establishing competitive proof of concept procurements as an authorized procurement method; providing that a competitive proof of concept procurement may have multiple phases of evaluation; requiring a unit of State government to obtain the approval of the Chief Procurement Officer or a designee before conducting a certain competitive proof of concept procurement; altering the required contents of a competitive proof of concept procurement solicitation; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes 'competitive proof of concept procurement' as an authorized procurement method for Maryland State agencies. It defines a proof of concept as a test or pilot project used to evaluate if a good, service, or technology can be successfully deployed. The bill outlines approval processes through the Chief Procurement Officer or the Secretary of Information Technology, requires solicitations to be posted on eMaryland Marketplace Advantage, and allows for multi-phase evaluations and subsequent contracts for full implementation. It also addresses participation goals for minority and veteran-owned small businesses within this new procurement framework.
stakeholders: State government units, private vendors, minority business enterprises, and veteran-owned small business enterprises

Title: State Government – Council for Open Data – Membership and Responsibilities
Synopsis: Renaming the Council on Open Data to be the Council for Open Data; altering the membership and member terms of the Council; and altering the Council's responsibilities to include advising on data initiatives and priorities, and identifying and exploring ways in which partnerships may be developed and strengthened to connect Maryland data with communities and social service organizations.
bill_summary: House Bill 262 renames the Council on Open Data to the Council for Open Data, reduces its membership from 37 to 11 members, and designates the State Chief Data Officer as the Chair. The bill also updates the Council's responsibilities to include advising on data initiatives and exploring partnerships to connect Maryland data with communities and social service organizations.
stakeholders: State and local government officials, private and academic data experts, and social service organizations

Title: Election Law - Early Voting Centers - Bus Stops
Synopsis: Requiring buses operating on fixed local routes funded by a county or municipal corporation and operated by a county or municipal corporation or a contractor for a county or municipal corporation to allow passengers to embark and disembark at the entrance of early voting centers located within one-half mile of the route.
bill_summary: This bill requires county or municipal fixed-route buses to allow passengers to embark and disembark at the entrance of early voting centers if the center is located within a half-mile of the bus route. This requirement applies only during early voting days and excludes express or commuter routes, as well as routes operated by the Maryland Transit Administration or the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority.
stakeholders: Registered voters using local public transportation and local government transit agencies

Title: Maryland Data Privacy and Protection Act of 2026
Synopsis: Limiting the personal information that may be collected, maintained, processed, and retained by units of State government under certain circumstances; requiring certain personal information to be deleted or de-identified under certain circumstances; requiring each unit to post a certain privacy notice on its Internet website and establishing certain requirements for privacy notices and privacy policies; requiring each unit of State government to designate a Privacy Officer; etc.
bill_summary: The Maryland Data Privacy and Protection Act of 2026 regulates how State government units collect, maintain, and retain personal information. It requires agencies to limit data collection to the minimum necessary for legitimate government purposes, mandates the secure deletion or de-identification of data once it is no longer needed, and requires the appointment of a Privacy Officer for each unit. The bill also expands the legal definition of 'personal information' to include sensitive data such as biometric information, geolocation, and health data, while requiring the Department of Information Technology to set security and privacy standards for third-party government contracts.
stakeholders: Maryland residents, State government agencies, and third-party government contractors

Title: State Board of Elections - Address Confidentiality Program - Designation of Contact Person
Synopsis: Requiring the State Board of Elections to designate a contact person for the Address Confidentiality Program; and providing the contact person acts as the contact for inquiries about the Program from local boards of elections and Program participants on matters related to the implementation of the Address Confidentiality Program.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland State Board of Elections to designate a contact person for the Address Confidentiality Program to manage inquiries from local boards of elections and program participants regarding election-related implementation.
stakeholders: Survivors of threatened, attempted, or actual domestic violence, sexual assault, stalking, harassment, or human trafficking who are participants in the Address Confidentiality Program

Title: Department of Information Technology – Information Technology Investment Fund – Uses
Synopsis: Authorizing the Information Technology Investment Fund, at the discretion of the Secretary of Information Technology, to be used to support State-owned communication sites, communication facilities, and telecommunications equipment used in connection with certain technology agreements.
bill_summary: This bill expands the authorized uses of the Information Technology Investment Fund. It grants the Secretary of Information Technology the discretion to use money from the fund to support State-owned communication sites, facilities, and telecommunications equipment used in connection with certain information technology agreements, including program management for these activities.
stakeholders: Maryland State government agencies, first responders, and the Department of Information Technology staff

Title: Election Law - Campaign Finance Entities - Oversight and Control of Campaign Funds
Synopsis: Altering the manner in which the chair of a campaign finance entity is appointed; providing that the treasurer is the financial steward of a campaign finance entity; altering requirements for assets received by or on behalf of a campaign finance entity and disbursements made by or on behalf of a campaign finance entity; repealing the authority of the chair of a campaign finance entity to approve a disbursement on behalf of the campaign finance entity under certain circumstances; etc.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the management and oversight of campaign funds by establishing the treasurer as the primary financial steward of a campaign finance entity. It prohibits candidates from directly accessing or making disbursements from their designated campaign accounts and repeals the authority of committee chairs to approve expenditures in the treasurer's absence. Instead, it allows treasurers to designate authorized agents in writing to handle disbursements, clarifies that assets are owned by the campaign entity, and sets civil penalties for unauthorized financial activities.
stakeholders: Political candidates, campaign treasurers, campaign managers, committee chairs, and political action committees (PACs) in Maryland.

Title: Information Technology - Establishment of the Office of Enterprise Data and State Chief Data Officer and Collaboration With Agency Data Officers
Synopsis: Establishing the position and responsibilities of the State Chief Data Officer; establishing the Office of Enterprise Data in the Department of Information Technology and the responsibilities of the Office; and requiring certain units of State government and authorizing certain units of State government to appoint an Agency Data Officer and establishing the responsibilities of Agency Data Officers.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Office of Enterprise Data and the position of State Chief Data Officer within the Maryland Department of Information Technology. It mandates that principal State departments appoint Agency Data Officers to manage data quality, privacy, and sharing, and requires the development of a statewide data strategy, including guidelines for the ethical use of artificial intelligence and other emerging technologies.
stakeholders: Maryland State agencies and departments, state employees, and Maryland residents

Title: Maryland Public Ethics Law - Financial Disclosure Statements - State Officials of and Candidates to be a State Official of the Judicial Branch
Synopsis: Requiring the Administrative Office of the Courts or another body designated by the Supreme Court of Maryland to administer and implement certain provisions of law relating to financial disclosure statements for State officials of the Judicial Branch and candidates to be a State official of the Judicial Branch and maintain and make available to the public the records and statements of State officials of the Judicial Branch and candidates to be a State official of the Judicial Branch; etc.
bill_summary: This bill reassigns the responsibility for administering and implementing financial disclosure requirements for Maryland Judicial Branch officials and candidates from the State Ethics Commission to the Administrative Office of the Courts or another body designated by the Supreme Court of Maryland. It requires the designated judicial body to maintain these records and make them available for public inspection, while removing the requirement that the Supreme Court of Maryland transmit copies of these statements to the State Ethics Commission.
responsible_party: Administrative Office of the Courts or another body designated by the Supreme Court of Maryland
stakeholders: State officials of the Judicial Branch, candidates for the Judicial Branch, and the general public

Title: Military Family Inclusion Act
Synopsis: Altering the membership of the Maryland Trust Fund Board of Trustees, the Maryland Veterans Commission, the Maryland Commission on Caregiving, and the Maryland Youth Advisory Council.
bill_summary: The Military Family Inclusion Act modifies the membership of several Maryland state boards and commissions to increase representation for military families and caregivers. It adds a family caregiver of a service-disabled veteran to the Maryland Commission on Caregiving, includes a representative from a military family organization on the Maryland Veterans Commission, and adds a youth from a military family to the Maryland Youth Advisory Council. The bill also updates the list of veterans' organizations represented on the Veterans Commission and clarifies the status of ex officio members on the Maryland Trust Fund Board of Trustees.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Veterans and Military Families
stakeholders: Military families, service-disabled veterans, family caregivers of veterans, and youth with immediate family members who are service members.

Title: State Procurement - Streamlining Contract Modifications
Synopsis: Authorizing the approval of certain contract modifications to State contracts if the modification does not materially change the scope of the work and does not increase the contract by more than a certain amount; altering the definition of "contract modification" for certain State procurements; and requiring a procurement officer to document certain contract modifications.
bill_summary: This bill streamlines the Maryland State procurement process by establishing specific authorities and thresholds for contract modifications. It authorizes procurement officers to approve modifications that do not materially change the scope of work or exceed small procurement cost limits, while allowing higher-level procurement officials to approve modifications up to five times the small procurement limit. The bill also updates the definition of 'contract modification' and mandates documentation of all changes in the procurement file.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of General Services, the Chief Procurement Officer, and State procurement officers
stakeholders: Maryland State agencies and private contractors engaged in State procurement contracts

Title: Food Establishments - Lavatory Requirement and On-Farm Food Service Facility License
Synopsis: Altering the type of toilet that certain food establishments may use to comply with the requirement to provide a convenient lavatory; requiring that the fee for an on-farm food service facility license be determined by the Maryland Department of Health based on certain factors and prohibiting the fee from exceeding $100; establishing the term of an on-farm service facility license; and requiring the Department, in consultation with certain other departments, to adopt regulations governing on-farm service facility licenses.
bill_summary: This bill creates a dedicated annual license for on-farm food service facilities, replacing the previous temporary licensing system and setting a maximum fee of $100. It also updates sanitation requirements to allow agritourism businesses, wineries, and breweries to use portable toilets rather than specifically chemical toilets, and it requires the Maryland Department of Health to adopt regulations regarding water access, wastewater, and food preparation for these facilities.
stakeholders: Agritourism businesses, Class 4 limited wineries, Class 8 farm breweries, on-farm food service facility operators, and their patrons.

Title: Health Insurance – Small Business Health Options Program (SHOP) Enrollment – Effective Dates
Synopsis: Altering the effective dates of enrollment in a Small Business Health Options (SHOP) Exchange plan for individuals who enroll during certain special enrollment periods.
bill_summary: This bill updates and simplifies the effective dates for health insurance coverage enrollment through the Small Business Health Options Program (SHOP) for individuals qualifying for special enrollment periods. Specifically, for life events like court orders, death, divorce, or legal separation, it standardizes the start of coverage to the first day of the month following the plan selection, removing previous rules that delayed coverage if the selection was made in the second half of the month.
stakeholders: Small business employees and their dependents enrolled in the Small Business Health Options Program (SHOP) Exchange

Title: State Board of Environmental Health Specialists - Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the State Board of Environmental Health Specialists, in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law), by extending to July 1, 2032, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board.
bill_summary: This bill extends the termination date for the State Board of Environmental Health Specialists from July 1, 2027, to July 1, 2032, ensuring the continued operation of the board in accordance with the Maryland Program Evaluation Act.
responsible_party: State Board of Environmental Health Specialists
stakeholders: Environmental health specialists and the Maryland Department of Health

Title: Medicare Supplement Policies - Issuance - Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring a carrier that issues Medicare supplement policies to issue a Medicare supplement policy to an individual who meets certain criteria during certain special enrollment periods.
bill_summary: This bill requires health insurance carriers to issue Medicare supplement policies to individuals who lose their Maryland Medical Assistance Program coverage after being enrolled for at least six months, or who qualify under certain federal special enrollment periods. The bill prohibits carriers from denying coverage or using medical underwriting to discriminate in pricing based on health status during these specified enrollment windows.
stakeholders: Medicare-eligible individuals transitioning out of Medicaid, individuals qualifying for federal special enrollment periods, and insurance carriers issuing Medicare supplement policies in Maryland.

Title: State Emergency Medical Services Board - Public Access Automated External Defibrillator Program - Revisions
Synopsis: Altering the Public Access Automated External Defibrillator Program, including by establishing requirements regarding an automated external defibrillator (AED) coordinator, repealing certain provisions of law regarding regional council AED committees, and exempting certain law enforcement agencies from being required to obtain a certificate for an AED deployed in a patrol vehicle of the law enforcement agency; etc.
bill_summary: This bill revises the Public Access Automated External Defibrillator Program by establishing the role of an AED coordinator for registered entities and updating certification requirements. It exempts law enforcement patrol vehicles from needing specific AED certificates, repeals regional council AED committees, and mandates that grocery stores and restaurants comply with the program's general standards.
stakeholders: Maryland businesses, organizations, law enforcement agencies, grocery stores, restaurants, and individuals requiring emergency cardiac care

Title: Insurance – Third Party Administrators – Enforcement
Synopsis: Altering the grounds on which the Maryland Insurance Commissioner may deny an applicant for registration as or refuse to renew, suspend, or revoke the registration of a third party administrator; and altering the violations for which the Commissioner may impose civil penalties against a third party administrator.
bill_summary: This bill expands the enforcement authority of the Maryland Insurance Commissioner over third party administrators. It broadens the grounds for denying, suspending, or revoking a registration to include violations of any Maryland insurance law or failure to comply with regulations or orders, and it allows for civil penalties for any violation of the state's insurance laws by an administrator.
stakeholders: Third party administrators and insurance plan participants and beneficiaries in Maryland

Title: Human Services - Department of Aging and Commission on Aging (The Longevity Ready Maryland Act)
Synopsis: Requiring the Secretary of Aging to lead implementation of the Longevity Ready Maryland Plan which is a multisector plan on aging that transforms programs, services, policies, institutions, and systems to address the growing population of older adults in the State; repealing, adding, and altering certain duties of the Secretary to enable the implementation, reporting, and evolution of the Longevity Ready Maryland Plan; and requiring the Department of Aging to staff the Commission on Aging.
bill_summary: The Longevity Ready Maryland Act requires the Secretary of Aging to lead the implementation of the Longevity Ready Maryland Plan, a multisector strategy to transform policies and services for the state's growing population of older adults. The bill updates the roles and responsibilities of the Secretary and the Commission on Aging, modifies the Commission's membership to include diverse experts and stakeholders, and mandates annual progress reports and a comprehensive plan update every four years.
stakeholders: Older adults, caregivers, Area Agencies on Aging, and state and local government agencies.

Title: Correctional Services - Medication Review Committee - Administration of Psychotropic Medication to an Incarcerated Individual
Synopsis: Authorizing the establishment of a medication review committee within the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services that convenes to determine whether to approve the administration of psychotropic medication to a certain incarcerated individual under certain circumstances; providing that psychotropic medication may not be administered to an incarcerated individual who refuses the medication except under certain circumstances; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services to establish medication review committees to determine whether psychotropic medication may be administered to incarcerated individuals in state correctional mental health infirmaries who refuse it. The bill outlines specific clinical criteria for involuntary administration, establishes procedural rights for incarcerated individuals (including the right to a lay advisor and to present evidence), and provides for administrative and judicial appeal processes.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
stakeholders: Incarcerated individuals in State correctional facilities, psychiatric and mental health professionals, lay advisors, and administrative law judges.

Title: Health Insurance - Mental Health and Substance Use Disorders - Codification of Federal Requirements
Synopsis: Codifying in State law certain provisions of the Code of Federal Regulations related to mental health parity and clarifying the authority of the Maryland Insurance Administration to enforce certain laws; requiring health insurance carriers to collect and report on data in a certain manner; requiring health insurance carriers to provide certain benefits under certain circumstances; requiring health insurance carriers to explain differences in access to care under certain circumstances; etc.
bill_summary: This bill codifies federal mental health and substance use disorder parity requirements into Maryland law. It requires health insurance carriers to collect and report data to ensure that access to mental health and substance use disorder benefits is comparable to medical and surgical benefits. The bill also empowers the Maryland Insurance Commissioner to enforce these standards and requires carriers to address any material differences in access to care.
stakeholders: Health insurance carriers and Maryland residents with health benefit plans requiring mental health or substance use disorder services.

Title: Family Law - Child Care Providers - Criminal Background Investigations
Synopsis: Altering provisions relating to criminal background investigations for certain individuals who care for or supervise children; requiring certain facilities to apply to the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository for a national and State criminal history records check for each employee, employer, individual, or volunteer; and altering provisions relating to the process under which a certain State or local law enforcement agency conducts a certain name-based check on certain individuals.
bill_summary: This emergency bill updates and expands the requirements for criminal background investigations for individuals who care for or supervise children. It requires specific child care facilities, institutions, and schools to conduct both state and national criminal history records checks on all employees, employers, and volunteers. Additionally, the bill establishes protocols for law enforcement to conduct name-based criminal checks in emergency situations where a child must be placed with a non-relative, such as a neighbor or friend, due to the sudden unavailability of a primary caretaker.
responsible_party: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
stakeholders: Child care providers, employees and volunteers at child care centers and schools, foster parents, individuals seeking adoption or guardianship, and adults providing emergency child care such as neighbors and friends.

Title: Adult Protective Services – Modifications
Synopsis: Altering provisions relating to the reporting and investigation of abuse, neglect, self-neglect, and exploitation of vulnerable adults; and requiring the local department of aging to complete an investigation and make an indicated, not indicated, or undetermined finding within 60 days.
bill_summary: This bill modifies Maryland's Adult Protective Services laws by updating the definitions of abuse, neglect, and exploitation to include psychological harm and sexual abuse, specifically focusing on actions by individuals in a 'relationship of trust.' It standardizes investigation outcomes into findings of 'indicated,' 'not indicated,' or 'undetermined,' introduces an online reporting portal for suspected maltreatment, and establishes a 60-day timeline for completing investigations.
stakeholders: Vulnerable adults, health practitioners, police officers, and human service workers

Title: Property Insurance - Settlement of Claims and Notices
Synopsis: Establishing the method for calculating the measure of the actual cash value recovery in the settlement of a first-party claim under a residential or commercial property insurance policy issued or renewed on or after October 1, 2026; and requiring an insurer that renews a policy of homeowner's insurance or renter's insurance to notify the insured, in advance of the renewal, of certain differences between the expiring policy and the renewal policy.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a standardized method for calculating the actual cash value recovery in property insurance claim settlements, specifically prohibiting the depreciation of labor costs in those calculations. It also requires property insurers to provide policyholders with a written notice at least 45 days prior to renewal that details any differences in coverage limits, covered risks, or deductibles between the expiring and renewal policies.
stakeholders: Residential and commercial property insurance policyholders and insurance companies in Maryland

Title: Public Safety - Licensed Firearms Dealers - Notification Regarding Potential Compromise of Security Features
Synopsis: Requiring a certain licensed firearms dealer to notify the Secretary of State Police within 24 hours after discovering that certain security features may have been compromised.
bill_summary: This bill requires licensed firearms dealers in Maryland to notify the Secretary of State Police within 24 hours after discovering that their required security features, such as video surveillance or alarm systems, may have been compromised by a burglary, theft, robbery, or similar event. This requirement is in addition to any reports made to local law enforcement or federal authorities, and failure to comply can result in civil penalties or the suspension/revocation of the dealer's license.
stakeholders: licensed firearms dealers

Title: Correctional Services - Home Detention - Monitoring and Security
Synopsis: Transferring the monitoring and security of the home detention programs of the Division of Correction to the Warrant Apprehension Unit of the Intelligence and Investigative Division within the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.
bill_summary: This bill transfers the responsibility for monitoring and security of incarcerated individuals in home detention programs from the Division of Correction to the Warrant Apprehension Unit within the Intelligence and Investigative Division of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services. It also clarifies the legal authority of the Warrant Apprehension Unit to execute warrants and make arrests for violations within these programs.
responsible_party: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
stakeholders: Incarcerated individuals in home detention programs and employees of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services

Title: Vehicle Laws - Ignition Interlock System Program - Required Participation
Synopsis: Requiring an individual to be a participant in the Ignition Interlock System Program as a condition of modification of a suspension or revocation of a license or issuance of a restricted license if the individual violated certain alcohol restrictions.
bill_summary: This bill requires individuals who have violated specific alcohol restrictions to participate in the Ignition Interlock System Program as a condition of modifying a driver's license suspension or revocation, or for the issuance of a restricted license.
stakeholders: Drivers in Maryland with license suspensions or revocations due to alcohol or drug-related violations, specifically those under the age of 21 or those who violated alcohol restrictions.

Title: Criminal Procedure - Lifetime Sexual Offender Supervision - Conditions, Violations, and Petitions for Discharge
Synopsis: Requiring inclusion of certain conditions for lifetime sexual offender supervision; requiring a sexual offender management team to report a certain violation of a condition of lifetime sexual offender supervision to the office of a certain State's Attorney; requiring a certain judge to conduct a certain hearing; requiring a certain sentencing court to adjudicate rather than hear and adjudicate a certain petition; altering the period before a certain petition may be renewed after being denied; etc.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the conditions and procedures for lifetime sexual offender supervision. It mandates that supervision include all standard and special conditions from the sentencing court and the Maryland Parole Commission, requires violation reporting to State's Attorneys, and alters the petition process for discharge from supervision, including longer waiting periods after denials and requirements for polygraph exams and victim notification.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
stakeholders: Individuals under lifetime sexual offender supervision, victims of sexual offenses, State's Attorneys, and Maryland courts.

Title: State Superintendent of Schools - Prolonged State of Emergency - Authority to Declare
Synopsis: Authorizing the State Superintendent of Schools to declare a prolonged state of emergency for an event that prevents regular, in-person attendance at a public school for at least 14 consecutive school days.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland State Superintendent of Schools to declare a prolonged state of emergency when an event prevents regular, in-person attendance at a public school for at least 14 consecutive school days. This declaration permits county boards of education to implement virtual education plans.
stakeholders: Maryland public school students, teachers, staff, and county boards of education

Title: Video Lottery Facility Payouts - Intercepts for Restitution Payments, Child Support Payments, and Debts Owed to the State
Synopsis: Authorizing the Central Collection Unit and the Child Support Administration to certify certain information about restitution or child support obligors to a video lottery operator for purposes of enforcing a requirement to intercept certain prize payouts; requiring a video lottery operator to provide certain notice to a debtor that wins a prize to be paid by the licensee and withhold all or part of the prize; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland Central Collection Unit and the Child Support Administration to certify information regarding individuals who owe restitution, child support, or other debts to the state to video lottery operators. It requires video lottery operators to intercept casino prizes requiring IRS form W-2G to satisfy these debts and provides a process for debtors to appeal the interception.
responsible_party: Central Collection Unit, Child Support Administration, and State Lottery and Gaming Control Agency
stakeholders: Individuals with outstanding child support, restitution, or state debt who win prizes at video lottery facilities; video lottery operators

Title: Income Tax – Cybersecurity Technology and Service Tax Credit – Alterations
Synopsis: Establishing the Buy Maryland Cybersecurity Tax Credit; stating the purpose of the credit is to promote the cybersecurity industry in the State by helping Maryland businesses and nonprofits purchase cybersecurity technology services from Maryland companies; altering eligibility for the credit; increasing from $200,000 to $1,000,000 the aggregate amount of credits that may be issued for certain cybersecurity purchases; making the credit refundable; etc.
bill_summary: This bill renames the existing cybersecurity tax credit as the Buy Maryland Cybersecurity Tax Credit and modifies its provisions to promote the state's cybersecurity industry. Key changes include expanding eligibility by removing the 50-employee limit for buyers, increasing the annual revenue cap for qualified sellers to $10 million, making the credit refundable, increasing the maximum aggregate credits per seller to $1 million, and setting a program sunset for taxable years beginning after 2030.
stakeholders: Maryland businesses and nonprofit organizations purchasing cybersecurity services; Maryland-based cybersecurity companies with less than $10 million in revenue or owned by veterans or historically disadvantaged groups.

Title: Sports Wagering Proceeds - Promotional Play Exclusion - Limitation
Synopsis: Authorizing the State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission to establish a certain limit, by regulation, on the amount of money given away as free promotional play by a sports wagering licensee that may be excluded from sports wagering proceeds.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission to establish a regulatory limit on the amount of free promotional play that sports wagering licensees may exclude from their taxable proceeds. This cap, to be determined by the Commission, applies after the first full fiscal year of operations and is based on a percentage of the licensee's proceeds from the preceding fiscal year.
responsible_party: State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission
stakeholders: Sports wagering facility licensees, mobile sports wagering licensees, and the State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission

Title: State Department of Assessments and Taxation – Local Reimbursement for Administration Costs – Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the schedule by which a county and Baltimore City must reimburse the State Department of Assessments and Taxation for the Department's administrative costs.
